How To Profit From MAKING MONEY: Last In The 11-Part SeriesThe IBD 50 list is the signature standard among IBD's CAN SLIM-focused arsenal of investing tools.Compiled weekly from stocks showing strong fundamentals and promising chart action, it is the top-shelf source for savvy investors building watch lists.The list leads the MAKING MONEY section on Mondays. It also runs on the eTables page at Investors.com and is updated daily on Leaderboard. Few leaders squeak by and into rally-leading roles without passing through the IBD 50 ranks near the beginning of their runs.The 50-stock roster lists the strongest stocks first. This week, Apple (AAPL), Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) and Lululemon Athletica (LULU) top the list. All carry a best-possible Composite Rating of 99 from IBD.The last three names on this week's list are no weaklings. Netease.com (NTES) carries a Composite Rating of 96 and is up 29% year-to-date. Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT) rates a 93 and has gained 56%. Salix Pharmaceuticals (SLXP) also rates a 96. It has gained 11% so far this year, and just cleared its first base, with a 50.86 buy point, since exiting a 14-month correction.The IBD 50 is not a buy list.In a market correction, even IBD 50 stocks can drop fast. In fact, leading stocks can fall 1-1/2 to 2-1/2 times the decline of the major indexes. So always make sure that the Market Pulse in The Big Picture points to a market in uptrend before putting cash to work.Also, pay close attention to the stock mini-charts, at the bottom of which you will find concise analysis of the stock's most recent action and guidance on the appropriate buy point.The left side of each page names each company and includes a blurb about fundamentals or news. This feature also includes 10 separate data points, including earnings, sales, relative strength, return on equity and management ownership data.The charts present a dense array of vital information on company fundamentals, share float, debt and numerous other factors.Going back to the NYSE composite's follow-through on Oct. 12 last year provides a good gauge of the list's effectiveness.Numerous stocks on the list, ranging from Tractor Supply (TSCO) to Fastenal (FAST), have gained 30% to 50% or more since the market's follow through. Not all were in bases or near buy points at the time of the follow through.Some, like Alexion, barely paused for the market's July-to-August correction. Others did not break out until January of this year.Don't treat the IBD 50 as a fool-proof investing advisor. Arco Dorados (ARCO) and Eldorado Gold (EGO) are just two examples of stocks on the list that have had problems since the Oct. 12 follow through.Investors must always keep their sell rules handy.
As stocks sustained big, broad losses for a second straight week and the market correction continued, just a few leading names showed strength.
Dollar Tree (DLTR) and SolarWinds (SWI) managed to gain ground for the week, albeit less than 1%.

Dollar Tree staged a big upside reversal Monday after finding support near 72. The stock has pulled back to the vicinity of its 10-week moving average for the third time since a breakout in late August.
SolarWinds has held near its Nov. 16 high, as it remains well extended past a 25.72 buy point that it cleared Oct. 27 in huge volume.
Intuitive Surgical (ISRG), Panera Bread (PNRA) and Ross Stores (ROST) also acted well, ceding little ground for the week.

Intuitive remains above its recent 402.45 buy point and its 10-week line, while Panera has continued to trade tightly and near its last entry point at 133.53. Ross has pulled back to support at its 10-week moving average.

But overall, IBD 50 stocks struggled in a tough week that was shortened by the Thanksgiving holiday. They lost 5.2% on average, while the NYSE composite lost 5.3%, the Nasdaq shed 5.1% and the S&P 500 retreated 4.7%.
Accretive Health (AH) fared the worst among stocks in last week's IBD 50 lineup.

The May 2010 IPO tumbled 15.5% for the week, putting it well below its 10-week and 40-week lines. After clearing its first base in December 2010, Accretive enjoyed a great run through April of this year. But it has displayed choppy, sideways action since then.

Some IBD 50 stocks fell below their 50-day moving averages this week — not what you want to see. Red Hat (RHT) made that move Wednesday, while Tractor Supply (TSCO) did it Friday. Each stock is also below its recent buy point.
With the market in correction, IBD-style investors ought to be looking for top-rated stocks to add to their watch lists, so they're ready to jump in when the overall climate improves.

You want to keep an eye out for stocks that are shaping bases, such as Rackspace Hosting (RAX). Stocks were little changed early Monday as the market sought direction.The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and NYSE composite were up 0.1% each. They were up 0.2% to 0.4% after the opening bell. Volume was tracking sharply lower across the board compared with Friday's levels at this time. Technology stocks continued to show some weakness.MIPS Technologies (MIPS) gapped below its 50-day moving average and dropped 6%. The chip design company had found support at the line last month. Capstone downgraded the chip designer to sell from hold. MIPS reports earnings Tuesday after the close. Analysts see profit rising 33% to 12 cents a share. Revenue is slated to rise 46% to $22.1 million.Baidu (BIDU) fell 2%, dropping further below its 50-day moving average. Earlier Monday, Macquarie started coverage of the Chinese Internet search engine at outperform. Baidu has been shaping a base, although it is a later-stage pattern.On the upside, JinkoSolar (JKS) rose 3% to its best levels in more than three months. The stock is forming a deep base after tumbling nearly 53% from its Nov. 4 record high. Deep corrections make for riskier bases. JinkoSolar is a Chinese maker of solar cells and modules. It reports earnings Feb. 28. Analysts expect a profit of $1.49 a share, up 176% from a year ago.LDK Solar (LDK) and Trina Solar (TSL) rallied 7% and 2%, respectively.Tractor Supply (TSCO) rose 2% in fast trade. Earlier Monday, Deutsche Bank started coverage of the farming supplies retailer with a buy rating. The broker also set a price target at 54, about 15% above current levels. Tractor Supply reports Q4 results Wednesday after the close. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters are expecting 62 cents a share on sales of $976.4 million. The company is featured in the Managing For Success section on Page A7.
The picture improved for stocks in Your Weekly Review over the last week as the market firmed up.
Uptrends this year have been short, indefinite and difficult to play for profits, as this column noted a week ago.
That still could remain the case, but at least this current market rally has picked up and offered more breakouts by highly rated stocks.

Under Armour (UA) jumped past an 80.90 buy point in big trade on Monday, powered by a strong earnings report. The sports apparel retailer is now 6% past 80.90, meaning it's outside of a proper buy zone, but watch to see if it pulls back in range.
The stock had already broken out Sept. 14 but fell more than 8% from the 73.46 buy point before finding support at the 50-day line.
Polaris Industries (PII) motored above a 61.60 entry from a cup-shaped base on Wednesday, and it remained in a buying range as of Thursday's close.
The maker of all-terrain vehicles and snowmobiles topped an earlier buy point at 57.21 in soft trade, then staged a rebound off its 10-week moving average.
Panera Bread (PNRA) gapped up above a 133.53 trigger on Wednesday, as it also got a lift from an upbeat earnings report.
The restaurant and bakery chain closed just 1.5% above 133.53 on Thursday, so it's still in range.
Triumph Group (TGI), an aerospace parts maker, stands 6% past a 54.92 buy point it cleared Monday.
As with Under Armour, watch to see if it pulls back in range.
Red Hat (RHT) is another stock that's extended after a breakout this week. But the software maker's move so far hasn't drawn the huge volume that you prefer to see.
Some leaders that broke out last week are holding up well. Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) and Tractor Supply (TSCO) fall in this category.

But a few Weekly Review stocks have flashed sell signals by slicing their 10-week lines this week. IBD's market outlook improved to "confirmed uptrend" during the past week.
That means growth investors ought to consider dipping their toes in the water, so to speak.
Several leading stocks have started to show encouraging action as the market's latest rally attempt unfolds.
Even so, approach the new uptrend with caution. Thoroughly study a stock's fundamentals and its chart pattern. Keep in mind IBD's 7% to 8% sell rule.
The week's encouraging action included a few breakouts.
Dollar Tree (DLTR) cleared a 79.45 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern during the week. But one area of concern is volume hasn't been strong for the discount retailer as it hits new highs.
Nuance Communications (NUAN) has topped a 22.50 cup buy point.
The voice-recognition software maker now stands 6% beyond that entry, in other words extended beyond a proper buy zone.
Note that the company's EPS and sales quarterly gains aren't quite at the 25% or more level often displayed by big winners.
Red Hat (RHT) and Ross Stores (ROST) also have staged breakouts.

Other leaders have rebounded off their 10-week moving averages, establishing secondary buying ranges. Among the IBD 50 stocks executing 10-week rebounds are Celgene (CELG), Cerner (CERN), Hansen Natural (HANS) and Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS).
This week's IBD 50 also features some stocks working on early-stage bases, such as Intuitive Surgical (ISRG), Tractor Supply (TSCO) and SolarWinds (SWI).
Such structures are less prone to failure than late-stage patterns. Watch to see if these stocks can move above their bases with strong volume.
But late-stage bases can still work out. Longtime leaders Herbalife (HLF) and Lululemon Athletica (LULU) are shaping late-stage structures and are worth watching.
For the week, IBD 50 stocks advanced 5.7% on average, underperforming the major indexes. The Nasdaq tacked on 7.6%, the NYSE 6.1% and the S&P 500 6%.

Apple (AAPL) was one of the week's biggest winners, gaining 14% as it bounced back from a failed breakout. Stocks struggled to find a consistent direction in afternoon trade Wednesday. The Nasdaq fell 0.4%, while the S&P 500 edged up less than 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 0.5%. The day's best performer was the defensive-oriented Dow Jones Utility Average, which rose 1.1%. Volume was running 5% higher on the Nasdaq and 6% lower on the NYSE.…

Investor optimism has lifted stock market rankings of several real estate industry groups, even as housing's rocking-horse recovery tilts between good and discouraging news. This week the Census Bureau said building products led retail sales up in March with 14% year-over-year growth, as building permits edged up. But housing starts slid, homebuilder industry confidence sagged for a first time in…

Stocks bounced back Tuesday, helped in part by a late rally stemming from a report from the U.K.'s Guardian that France and Germany have agreed to increase the size of Europe's bailout fund. Earlier, the market digested a round of mixed earnings and economic reports. Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the…
The sharp sell-offs at the start of the past week helped turn IBD's market outlook a shade more negative, switching it to "uptrend under pressure."
But the market behaved better as it closed out the week, lifting off weekly lows established Tuesday.
For the week, IBD 50 stocks actually managed to gain a little ground on average, edging up 0.2%.
The main indexes all fell for the week. The NYSE lost 3.2%, the S&P 500 2.5% and the Nasdaq 1.9%.
Quite a few IBD 50 stocks now stand beyond proper buying ranges following breakouts. In other words, they're extended more than 5% beyond their ideal entry points.
That leaves IBD-style investors with less to look at while shopping.
On the plus side, that's an encouraging sign of the overall market's health. You want to see highly rated stocks advancing to new highs and then holding up under pressure.
The extended leaders include Intuitive Surgical (ISRG), Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) and SolarWinds (SWI).

Still, some leaders have stayed in potential buying ranges after breaking out. Take a look at MasterCard (MA) and Tractor Supply (TSCO). Plus there's Ulta Salon (ULTA), which triggered a buy signal with heavy volume Nov. 4 from a late-stage base.
Other IBD 50 issues continue to work on bases. That group includes Accretive Health (AH) and Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD). Each is etching a first-stage pattern after resetting its base count.

During the week, leaders generally didn't fall apart. Herbalife (HLF) tumbled Tuesday and set off IBD's 8% sell rule for investors who bought at its recent 60.10 handle entry. But the stock then staged a solid rebound off its 10-week moving average.
Meanwhile, Hansen Natural (HANS) was the week's best performer among IBD 50 stocks, after being one of the laggards in the week ended Oct. 28.
Late on Nov. 3, the energy drinks maker reported third-quarter earnings per share that missed the Street's forecasts by a penny.

But revenue beat expectations, and several analysts hiked their price targets. That helped the stock lift off its 50-day line Friday and hit a new all-time high. The NYSE lost 3.2%, the S&P 500 2.5% and the Nasdaq 1.9%.Quite a few IBD 50 stocks now stand beyond proper buying ranges following breakouts. In other words, they're extended more than 5% beyond their ideal entry points.That leaves IBD-style investors with less to look at while shopping.On the plus side, that's an encouraging sign of the overall market's health. You want to see highly rated stocks advancing to new highs and then holding up under pressure.The extended leaders include Intuitive Surgical (ISRG), Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) and SolarWinds (SWI).Still, some leaders have stayed in potential buying ranges after breaking out. Take a look at MasterCard (MA) and Tractor Supply (TSCO). Plus there's Ulta Salon (ULTA), which triggered a buy signal with heavy volume Nov. 4 from a late-stage base. Other IBD 50 issues continue to work on bases. That group includes Accretive Health (AH) and Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD). Each is etching a first-stage pattern after resetting its base count.During the week, leaders generally didn't fall apart. Herbalife (HLF) tumbled Tuesday and set off IBD's 8% sell rule for investors who bought at its recent 60.10 handle entry. But the stock then staged a solid rebound off its 10-week moving average.Meanwhile, Hansen Natural (HANS) was the week's best performer among IBD 50 stocks, after being one of the laggards in the week ended Oct. 28.Late on Nov. 3, the energy drinks maker reported third-quarter earnings per share that missed the Street's forecasts by a penny.But revenue beat expectations, and several analysts hiked their price targets. That helped the stock lift off its 50-day line Friday and hit a new all-time high. In a really bearish climate, stocks are often shown no mercy after an earnings miss.
The major indexes rallied at day's end, allowing the Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 to finish in positive territory Tuesday.
The major indexes rallied at day's end, allowing the Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 to finish in positive territory Tuesday.

The Nasdaq added 0.1%, while the S&P 500 edged up a fraction. The NYSE shed 0.2%. Volume rose across the board, according to preliminary data.

After hours, MIPS Technologies (MIPS) was down sharply after posting quarterly sales that fell short of expectations. The chip designer reported EPS of 14 cents, 2 cents above views. Sales grew 44% to $21.9 million, missing forecasts for $22.1 million. MIPS, which gained 2% in the regular session, had been finding support at its 50-day moving average after trying to clear a loose consolidation.

Also in late trading, Altera (ALTR) reported Q4 EPS of 72 cents, a penny above views. Revenue came in at $555 million, above estimates. The chip designer was down modestly in late trading after losing 1% in the regular session. Altera, which boasts an IBD Composite Rating of 99, has been finding support at its 10-week moving average.
Tuesday's top-performing groups were Commercial Services-Staffing, Auto/Truck-Tires & Miscellaneous and Transportation-Equipment Manufacturing. Energy stocks were some of the weakest.
Among tech leaders, Apple (AAPL) tacked on 1% in above-average turnover. The stock appears to be bouncing off its 10-week line. It stands 2% off an all-time high hit earlier this month.

The companies slated to post quarterly results Wednesday include Netflix (NFLX), Starbucks (SBUX) and Tractor Supply (TSCO). The key economic reports expected Wednesday include new-home sales and an announcement from the Fed's policymaking arm. That group is expected to keep the fed funds target rate unchanged.

While many IBD 50 stocks have cleared buy points the past few weeks, big winners have been few.
Those that are sporting respectable gains have one common denominator: They all broke out in heavy volume.

Volume is your best gauge of demand and is a crucial characteristic of a breakout. Trading should be at least 40% above average when a stock clears a buy point. Remember, you want to see a wave of buyers hit the stock, not just a trickle.

It's hard to tell the final volume tally until after the close, but you estimate it by comparing the stock's volume at any point during the session with its average. Better yet, you can get a computer-generated estimate of final volume by getting a quote at Investors.com.
Hansen Natural (HANS) is up 12% since clearing an 82.10 entry in a cup-with-handle base Aug. 23. Turnover jumped to more than twice its average on the breakout.
Deep-discount retailer Dollar General (DG) gapped above a handle in a double-bottom base Aug. 30. It broke out in nearly triple its average volume and is up 11%.
Rival Dollar Tree (DLTR) is up about 7% after clearing a 70.64 buy point in nearly twice its average trade Aug. 29.
Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS) blew past a 41.10 square-box buy point in almost double its normal turnover Aug. 30 . It's now up 9%.

MasterCard (MA) initially cleared a 340.52 square-box trigger Sept. 8, but volume was lackluster. It again cleared the 340.52 buy point Thursday as trade jumped 50% above average — a much more convincing level of trading.
Higher turnover on a weekly chart also can tell you there's demand for a stock at a breakout.

Some IBD 50 stocks are still basing. Farm gear retailer Tractor Supply (TSCO) scored its first gain in above-average volume in more than two months. It has a 73.19 buy point. Its Relative Strength line is at a new high.
Chip designer Avago Technologies (AVGO) also rallied in heavy volume last week. It's forming a base with a 39.55 buy point.
The IBD 50 stocks lagged the market as a whole. Thirty-five components rose. The average weekly gain for the entire list was 2.2%.

With the market in its second correction this summer, managers of the country's leading funds have eased off buying.
The S&P 500 fell 2% in July, while the Nasdaq was off 0.62%. National debt concerns and disappointing economic data have put a dent into investors' confidence.

At this time, it's a good idea to park your money in cash and build a watch list of stocks with solid ratings. It's important to wait for the market to follow through on a rally attempt before you buy again.
Leisure stocks, travel-booking firm Priceline.com (PCLN) and online movie rental firm Netflix (NFLX) were popular buys among the best-performing funds.
Top managers also added retailers Tractor Supply Co. (TSCO), Dollar Tree (DLTR), Sally Beauty Holdings (SBH) and GNC Holdings (GNC).
New Buys:New buys of top performing stock funds
IBD spotted six top-performing funds buying Priceline.com, investing an estimated $5.9 million. The $7.7 billion Fidelity OTC Portfolio added shares in its latest reporting period.
Latest Sells:Top performing stock funds' latest sells
The Norwalk, Conn.-based firm provides airline ticket, hotel accommodations, car rentals and vacation packages through its website, priceline.com. The site lets you name your own price.
Priceline's group of companies consists of booking.com, agoda.com, priceline.com and traveljigsaw.com.
The stock is carving out the handle of a cup-with-handle pattern in a third-stage base. After Tuesday's pullback, it's 6% below its buy point of 552.25.
The firm clocked solid double-digit earnings growth in the past 10 quarters on solid revenue growth.
Sell Side

The nation's best-performing funds have been selling Finance-REIT stocks such as Essex Property Trust (ESS), Tanger Factory Outlet (SKT), Prologis (PLD) and American Campus Communities (ACC), as of their latest reporting periods.

Top funds have been pulling out of apparel makers PVH (PVH), Polo Ralph Lauren (RL) and VF (VFC). Retail restaurants Starbucks (SBUX), McDonald's (MCD), Darden Restaurants (DRI) and Bravo Brio Restaurant Group (BBRG) have also been sold.
Three top funds have been net sellers of Forest Laboratories (FRX). The $78 billion Fidelity Contrafund Fund unloaded shares in its latest reporting period.
The drug company is the maker of antidepressant Lexapro and Alzheimer's drug Namenda.
The stock had a strong rally from March to June, reaching a 52-week high of 40.52 on June 22. Since then, it's pulled back 11%. It's trading below its 10-week moving average line.

Market leaders advanced for a second straight week in 2011 as investors began digesting early results for the fourth quarter.Earnings season will heat up quickly despite a holiday-shortened week. Apple (AAPL), Google (GOOG), F5 Networks (FFIV) and IBM (IBM) all report results.This is one reason why buying breakouts can be tricky in January. An earnings beat or a buoyant outlook can send a stock surging past a buy point or padding its gains. An earnings miss or dismal outlook can send a stock crashing back into a base or below it.Techs continued to grab a leading role in the 4 1/2-month uptrend. VMware (VMW) added 2% last week. It's just barely above the 5% buying range after sneaking past a 92.05 buy point in a cup with a high handle.The base began to form when the virtualization and cloud software firm fell 2.5% for the week ended Oct. 1. That decline triggered a slide that lasted three more weeks, all in heavy volume.In the first of those three weeks down, VMware fell 7% and volume doubled from its weekly average. But the stock also closed within the upper 60% of its weekly range. Institutions likely stepped in and bought shares to support the stock. The losses were also small in the next two weeks.Illumina (ILMN) rallied for a second straight week and marked new highs. The genetics analyzer broke out past a 66.69 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern formed in the final weeks of December. It is 3.5% past that level.Not all leaders had a sunny week. Brazilian beer and beverage maker AmBev (ABV), No. 31 in the prior week's IBD 50, sliced through its 10-week line in heavy trade, falling 7% and back into a flat base.JPMorgan Chase (JPM) had solid Q4 results, though its stock has been locked in a sideways range going back to the fall of 2009. Its dull EPS and RS Ratings put the Dow component well below the caliber of IBD 50 firms.While financials make up a 16.2% weighting within the S&P 500, the only financial firm in the IBD 50 is EZCorp (EZPW), which rose 1.07 to a new high of 29.63 Friday. Volume more than doubled vs. the daily average as the stock thrust above a 28.85 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.IBD 50 stocks forming bases include Ebix (EBIX) and Semtech (SMTC). Rovi (ROVI) and Tractor Supply (TSCO) got support at their 10-week lines.For the week, stocks in the IBD 50 on average gained 2.6%, after a 1.4% advance the prior week. The Nasdaq rose 1.9% and the NYSE composite 2.4%.

Stock futures were off their best levels, but still signaled a modestly higher open as investors digested President Obama's State of the Union speech and more corporate earnings.Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 5 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures rallied 4 points and Dow futures gained 7 points.In corporate news, Rockwell Automation (ROK) bolted 8% in the pre-market after crushing views and raising its profit outlook. The maker of automation controls and power systems delivered fiscal Q1 earnings of $1.04 a share, up 93% from a year before and 16 cents above views. Sales grew 29% to $1.37 billion vs. views of $1.31 billion.Rockwell lifted its full-year profit guidance to a range of $4.30 to $4.60 a share, or above views of $4.08. Revenue is guided at $5.5 billion to $5.7 billion vs. views of $5.49 billion.Juniper Networks (JNPR) rose 2% in pre-market trade despite giving a soft outlook. After Tuesday's close, the network gear maker topped views with a 29% increase in Q4 earnings and a 26% rise in sales. But the firm pegged Q1 EPS at 30 cents to 33 cents vs. views of 34 cents. Its revenue guidance was also a tad below views.MIPS Technologies (MIPS) tumbled 9% in pre-open trading after reporting disappointing sales late Tuesday. The chip designer's fiscal Q2 revenue came in at $21.9 million, or below analysts' estimates of $22.3 million.Due to report after the close are Citrix Systems(CTXS), Lam Research(LRCX), Motorola Mobility (MMI), Netflix (NFLX),  Qualcomm (QCOM), Starbucks (SBUX) and Tractor Supply (TSCO).Data on December new home sales will be out at 10 a.m. EST. Economists expect sales of 300,000 units, up from 290,000 in November.The Fed will announce its decision on interest rates at around 2:15 p.m. EST. Although no change is expected, the central bank's assessment of the economy will be key.Elsewhere, gold and silver were mildly higher. Crude slipped ahead of inventory data at 10:30 a.m. EST.

The NYSE composite slumped 1%, the S&P 500 0.8%, Nasdaq 0.7% and Dow 0.5%. Volume jumped across the board, giving all four of the major indexes a distribution day. Five to six distribution days over a few weeks can derail a rally.
A distribution day involves a sizable loss in a major index in rising volume. It points to institutional selling.
A number of leaders sold off in heavy volume Tuesday.
China New Borun (BORN) reversed opening gains and dived 10% in heavy trading. The reversal erased nearly all of Monday's work. The stock is still trading above its 10-week moving average.

The alcohol producer announced that two of its board members resigned. China New Borun reports earnings on Nov. 16. Analysts see profit rising 17% to 35 cents a share. China New Borun had previously delivered four straight quarters of triple-digit growth.

Zhongpin (HOGS) gapped down and tumbled 7% in nearly triple its average volume. The Chinese pork producer reported Q3 earnings and sales below views and got hit with a downgrade. Zhongpin now sits 16% off its record high, reached Thursday.

Perrigo (PRGO) reversed lower, dropping 7% and slicing its 50-day moving average. But the stock trimmed losses after nearly hitting its 200-day line. The maker of generic drugs fell in sympathy with Teva Pharmaceuticals (TEVA).
A court blocked Teva from selling a generic version of the brain cancer treatment Temodar, which is made by Merck (MRK). Teva lost a fraction.

Silver Wheaton (SLW) reversed from a new high and shed 7%. Volume swelled to nearly 35 million shares — the busiest in years. Silver prices reversed from a 30-year high. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange is raising margins on silver future contracts.
Ebix (EBIX) turned a 7% gain into a 4% loss. Shares turned tail despite the software provider beating views with a 72% jump in Q3 earnings and a 43% rise in sales.

On the upside, Priceline (PCLN) gapped up and gained 8% in nearly triple its average volume. But the stock closed near session lows. Late Monday, the online travel services provider smashed expectations with a 54% rise in Q3 earnings and a 37% rise in sales. The stock has gained 39% since clearing a 302.08 buy point from a rare short-stroke pattern on Aug. 17.
After the close, 51job (JOBS) fell 3% despite delivering Q3 results above views.
Top-rated stocks reporting earnings Wednesday include Advance Auto Parts (AAP), Home Inns & Hotels Management (HMIN), Macy's (M) and Maidenform Brands (MFB).

The reversal erased nearly all of Monday's work. The stock is still trading above its 10-week moving average.The alcohol producer announced that two of its board members resigned. China New Borun reports earnings on Nov. 16. Analysts see profit rising 17% to 35 cents a share. China New Borun had previously delivered four straight quarters of triple-digit growth.Zhongpin (HOGS) gapped down and tumbled 7% in nearly triple its average volume. The Chinese pork producer reported Q3 earnings and sales below views and got hit with a downgrade. Zhongpin now sits 16% off its record high, reached Thursday.Perrigo (PRGO) reversed lower, dropping 7% and slicing its 50-day moving average. But the stock trimmed losses after nearly hitting its 200-day line. The maker of generic drugs fell in sympathy with Teva Pharmaceuticals (TEVA).A court blocked Teva from selling a generic version of the brain cancer treatment Temodar, which is made by Merck (MRK). Teva lost a fraction.Silver Wheaton (SLW) reversed from a new high and shed 7%. Volume swelled to nearly 35 million shares — the busiest in years. Silver prices reversed from a 30-year high. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange is raising margins on silver future contracts.Ebix (EBIX) turned a 7% gain into a 4% loss. Shares turned tail despite the software provider beating views with a 72% jump in Q3 earnings and a 43% rise in sales.On the upside, Priceline (PCLN) gapped up and gained 8% in nearly triple its average volume. But the stock closed near session lows. Late Monday, the online travel services provider smashed expectations with a 54% rise in Q3 earnings and a 37% rise in sales. The stock has gained 39% since clearing a 302.08 buy point from a rare short-stroke pattern on Aug. 17.After the close, 51job (JOBS) fell 3% despite delivering Q3 results above views.Top-rated stocks reporting earnings Wednesday include Advance Auto Parts (AAP), Home Inns & Hotels Management (HMIN), Macy's (M) and Maidenform Brands (MFB).

Stocks packed on additional gains Friday to finish with the biggest weekly pop in the Nasdaq in more than two years. The S&P 500 and the NYSE composite each rose 1.7%, while the…
Major stock indexes closed Friday mixed as the Nasdaq suffered its third straight loss despite mostly positive earnings reports over the whole week from the tech sector.
Major stock indexes closed Friday mixed as the Nasdaq suffered its third straight loss despite mostly positive earnings reports over the whole week from the tech sector.
Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video!
The NYSE composite stopped a two-day skid, but squandered a 0.9% intraday gain to finish up 0.4%. The S&P 500 rose 0.2%.

The Nasdaq, which sank 2.2% over Wednesday and Thursday's sessions, slipped an additional 0.6% after rallying 0.7% in the first 30 minutes of the session. Volume rose on the NYSE and fell from Thursday's heavy levels on the Nasdaq.

Mega-caps played catch-up again as the Dow advanced 0.7% for the week and its eighth straight weekly gain. The Dow is up 2.5% since Jan. 1, tops among the major indexes. The small-cap S&P 600, in contrast, is down 1.3% for the year.

A number of IBD 50 stocks struggled Friday after taking big hits earlier in the week. This was especially the case for companies working to enhance the speed and efficiency of Internet networks. F5 Networks (FFIV) finished the week down 24%, Acme Packet (APKT) 12% and Riverbed Technology (RVBD) 8%. All three remained above their 50-day or 200-day moving averages.
VMware (VMW), the leader in server virtualization, held onto most of Friday's gains as it rose 1.5% and held above 90, formerly a level of resistance.

Polycom (PLCM) pulled back from its highs, yet still finished with a 15% gain. Volume cruised more than six times its 50-day average to its highest level since July of last year. The stock busted out of a seven-month consolidation in October and has rallied 32% past a 34.24 buy point. An investor might have been able to find an earlier entry point by drawing a trend line across the highs from the base's left side.

The videoconferencing gear firm posted strong Q4 earnings and sales growth, up 48% and 27%, respectively, as after-tax margin of 12.7% hit its highest level since Q4 2008. EPS growth has accelerated over the past three quarters (7% to 17% to 23% to 48%), a typical characteristic of great stocks.

GE (GE) continued the Dow's unlikely charge as the U.S. market's top index so far in 2011. The diversified giant gapped up 7% in heavy volume and extended its gain from a breakout from a long cup with handle at a 17.59 buy point. The stock also pierced resistance near 20 seen in April of last year and will likely see its weak 39 Composite Rating improve significantly next week.
GE posted 29% growth in Q4 earnings to 36 cents a share, marking a third straight quarter of double-digit gains, as revenue edged up 1%, the first year-over-year increase in nine quarters.
On the downside, Caterpillar (CAT) sank 1% and fell further below a 94.99 three-weeks-tight pattern. The company, No. 18 in the latest edition of IBD Big Cap 20, will announce Q4 results on Jan. 27.

IBD's Energy-Solar industry group led the week's gains, up 2.9%. Select medical and retail groups also had a strong weekly showing, while Internet and computer networking, fiber optics, hospitals, coal, chip and fertilizers fell the most for the week.
A slew of leading companies will post quarterly results next week, including VMware, sensor maker Sensata (ST), Netflix (NFLX) and farm hobbyist retailer Tractor Supply (TSCO).

Tractor Supply broke out of a base in 2002, but its real move didn't kick off until mid-2003.

The long post-bubble decline of 2000-02 caused a lot of damage, and not just among technology names. A look at the top stocks from October 2002 shows a slew of defensive issues: banks, HMOs and soap makers. It would have been easy to miss a potential winner just because it was a member of IBD's Your Weekly Review.

Tractor Supply (TSCO) was already falling when the tech bubble burst in March 2000. The ensuing chaos seemed to add some oomph to the stock's decline. It bottomed at 1.63 a share (adjusting for splits) in November 2000.
From there, Tractor Supply built a long and steady uptrend, braving some nasty market head winds along the way.
What made Tractor Supply so hot to begin with? Sales growth had ticked up preceding its breakout for two straight quarters, from 8% to 19% to 47%.
Quarterly profit hadn't yet kicked in, which would have caused some investors to wait for a future base. But annual EPS was slated to rise 34% in 2002 and 33% in '03.

Tractor Supply's compelling story: more than 300 stores serving hobbyist ranchers and farmers who enjoy the rural life. The average customer was 44 years old, with an income 15% above the national average.
When a market follow-through appeared Oct. 15, what would you have seen in Tractor Supply? A great business niche and a stock that had established a torrid prior uptrend.
But the handle was loose 1. From top to bottom, it showed a 22% range. You really don't want to see much more than a 12% swing.
So the base was not identifiable as a clear cup with handle. You could have treated it as a rebound from the 10-week moving average, and that would have worked for a while.
In mid-October, volume exploded to almost five times its norm. The stock gapped up and surged 19%, closing near the day's high 2.
The stock gained more than 40% until it started a new correction.
Look at what proved to be the near-term peak, the Nov. 29 week 3.
Volume suddenly got squelched and stayed that way for weeks 4. The stock fell below its buy point and the 10-week moving average in the ensuing weeks.
But that decline was just Tractor Supply's setting-up process.
The stock carved a cup from that Nov. 29 peak to a trough in the March 7, 2003, week at 29.38 5.
As Tractor Supply moved up the right side of its base, it left in its wake a correction that ran 35%  quite acceptable.
The pattern was smoother than the earlier one.
Tractor Supply built a high handle from May 9 through May 30 6.

This handle ran 17% deep  still a bit more than the ideal. But most of the drop came in one week in which the stock reversed to erase most of its losses, closing in the same familiar neighborhood as other weeks in the handle. What's more, it made for three straight weeks of narrow price closes  a positive sign.
Tractor Supply broke out June 2 past its 46.31 buy point 7.
By this time, the stock market had made a follow-through that confirmed a new uptrend, one that would last much longer than what followed the October 2002 follow-through.

The stock nearly doubled over the next five months and offered several follow-on buy areas along the way.Tractor Supply broke out of a base in 2002, but its real move didn't kick off until mid-2003.The long post-bubble decline of 2000-02 caused a lot of damage, and not just among technology names. Rural Americans have long known Tractor Supply Co. (TSCO) as a place to find rugged work clothes for men. Now, with its customer profile changing, the farm and ranch supply chain is doing the same for women.

In September, Tractor Supply launched an expanded apparel and footwear section for women. It boasts a full line of work clothes — from premium Carhartt-branded jackets to Wrangler tops and jeans — and an array of footwear under high-end labels such as Ariat.

With 320 stores in 28 states, Tractor Supply serves mostly part-time farmers and ranchers. Only 10% of customers are full-time farmers. Until recently, two-thirds of them were men. Today, 50% are women.
"I expect we will continue to become a more important resource of basic clothes and maintenance products for women," said Chief Executive Joe Scarlett.
Scarlett hopes a combination of print, direct-mail and TV advertising will drive more women into the stores. He also intends to tailor women's clothes to regional needs and styling preferences.

But Tractor Supply isn't going after the trendy set. The firm is sticking to basic, utility-type fare, in part because fashionable clothes proved a flop in a recent 18-month test offering in 12 stores.
That styling strategy should lessen the company's fashion risk and help it better meet the demands of its customers, says analyst Eric Marshall of First Dallas Securities Inc.

The expanded apparel department, rolled out in 280 stores, also boasts a wider selection of work wear for men. That includes more Ariat leather footwear, a new line of hats under the Resistol label and more offerings under the Wrangler and Carhartt labels.
Enhancing the chain's clothing selection is part of Scarlett's plan to turn Tractor Supply into a one-stop shop for rural lifestyles, watchers say.
Also, by confining its offerings to a narrow niche — high-end work clothes — it's keeping with his ongoing merchandising strategy.

"We tell our buyers to stay out of the headlights of the big-box retailers, because we don't want to go eyeball to eyeball with people who have more purchasing power and bigger stores than we do," Scarlett said.
So he goes out of his way to distinguish Tractor Supply's products from those sold at the mass merchants and home superstores.

"They stay away from the mass commodity items... and stick with specialty type, farm-related products," said Marshall. "They're staying with mainly high-end, work-related clothes like Carhartt jackets, which you can't find at Wal-Mart (Stores Inc.)."
That's not all Tractor Supply does differently than Wal-Mart. It also carries a wider array of products such as feed, containment fencing, pitchforks and harvest equipment.

"It's done a great job merchandising products and finding niches in their retail category where they can sell a lot of products outside the radar screen of home improvement centers and mass merchants," said analyst David Campbell of Davenport & Co.
In the tool category, it offers more metalworking supplies than the home centers, which typically focus more on woodworking, he says.
Tractor Supply has come back strong from a lackluster 2000, when year-over-year earnings fell 4% due mostly to drought conditions in many areas where it operates
It also faced tough comparisons from 1999, when sales surged as people rushed to its stores for items like generators in anticipation of Y2K problems.

Things are better now. In the third quarter, the company's earnings more than doubled from a year ago to 27 cents a share. Sales grew 14% to $199.4 million. Sales at stores open at least a year, or same-store sales, rose 6.8%.
Analysts polled by First Call expect full-year earnings to rise 25% to $2.34 a share, then gain 12% to $2.62 in 2002.

More normal weather conditions this year in Texas — even accounting for the recent storms — and other key markets have boosted same-store sales growth, Marshall says. People are spending more time baling hay and handling other chores, which helps drive traffic.
The company's new merchandising programs have also given it a lift. It's doing a better job adjusting its product mix so it doesn't overlap with nearby home-improvement chains, Campbell says.
And through better inventory management, it's carrying 10% less inventories per store. At the same time, Tractor Supply is staying in stock with about 97% of its top 400 items.
Meanwhile, the company is weathering the weak economy well.
"Their business is highly driven by maintenance products like fencing materials and equine products, and people take care of their pets and do repairs regardless of the economy," said Marshall.
Still, Scarlett remains cautious.

"Looking ahead to the balance of the year, we remain concerned about the current outlook and are factoring this into our projections for same-store sales gains of 2% to 3% for the fourth quarter," he said in a recent statement.Rural Americans have long known Tractor Supply Co. 5:15 p.m. Update: Major stock averages bounced back from big losses to end mixed Wednesday.

The Dow and Nasdaq edged up 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. Meanwhile, weighed down by metals and financials, the NYSE composite fell 0.5%. It closed above its 200-day moving average after piercing the line intraday. The S&P 500 lost 0.2%.
Volume climbed sharply on the Nasdaq and NYSE. Decliners beat advancers by about 2-to-1 on both exchanges
Retail stocks jumped ahead of Thursday's June same-store sales data.
Family Dollar Stores (FDO) gapped up and surged nearly 13% after it beat views with a 35% jump in fiscal Q3 earnings. The stock regained its 50-day moving average.
Group mates Dollar Tree (DLTR) and Big Lots (BIG) climbed 8% and 3%, respectively.
Tractor Supply (TSCO) gapped up and surged 11% to a 10-month high. The operator of farm and ranch stores raised its full-year profit outlook to a range of $2.78 to $2.92 a share vs. views of $2.64.
Overall, retailers were strong across the board.
On the downside, Pegasystems (PEGA) tumbled 10% and sliced its 50-day moving average in about twice its average trade. The stock had been above the line since gapping up May 5.
Synaptics (SYNA) trimmed an 8% loss to 3%. But the stock closed below its 50-day line for the first time in four months.
On the economic calendar, jobless claims and wholesale inventories will be out Thursday. Earnings from 3Com (COMS), Chattem (CHTT), Infosys (INFY) and Posco (PKX) will also be out Thursday.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Battle To Mixed Close
BY VINCENT MAO
Late-session buyers helped stocks to a mixed finish Wednesday.
The Dow and Nasdaq rose 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. But the NYSE composite lost 0.5% and the S&P 500 slipped 0.2%.
Volume surged on both exchanges.
Retailers were among the session's best performers. Metals and financials were among the worst performers.
3:15 p.m. Update: Comeback Wanes In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Rebound efforts faded in late trade Wednesday, sending some indexes back near session lows.
The NYSE composite was down 1.5%, the S&P 500 1%. The Dow and the Nasdaq lost 0.7% each.
Turnover continued to track much higher on both exchanges.

American Dairy (ADY) tumbled 11% to its lowest levels in about five weeks. The stock is trading in a high, tight flag with a 44.10 buy point. Despite its name, American Dairy is a Chinese producer of milk and soybean powder and dairy products.
ArcSight (ARST) trimmed a 9% loss to just 2%. But the stock is still on pace to finish lower for the sixth straight session.
Valeant Pharmaceuticals International (VRX) slid 2%, falling further below a 24.47 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern.
On the bright side, retailers were having a nice day.
Buckle (BKE) rallied 5% after Sidoti raised shares to buy from neutral. Ross Stores (ROST) and Best Buy (BBY) rose 3% and 2%, respectively.
Elsewhere, Alcoa (AA) slipped 1% ahead of its earnings report after the close. Analysts are expecting a loss of 38 cents a share on sales of $3.93 billion.
2:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Recoup Chunk Of Losses
BY VINCENT MAO
Strong results from a 10-year note auction helped stocks improve in afternoon trading Wednesday.
The NYSE composite lost 1.1%, up from -1.6% at its session low. The S&P 500 fell 0.6%, the Nasdaq 0.4% and the Dow 0.2%.
Volume was running vastly higher across the board.
Websense (WBSN) gapped down, dived 15% and sliced its 200-day moving average. Late Tuesday, the maker of Web-filtering tools guided Q2 sales below views.

Pegasystems (PEGA) tumbled 10% and sliced its 50-day moving average. It was one of the biggest percentage loser in the IBD 100. Earlier Wednesday, Dougherty & Company started coverage of the business software maker with a neutral rating.

Synovis Life Technologies (SYNO) gapped down and shed 7% in huge trade. But the stock trimmed losses after nearing its 50-day moving average. After Tuesday's close, the medical gear maker said it would buy nearly all assets of privately held Pegasus Biologics for $12.1 million.
Oil recouped some losses after falling as low as $60.28 a barrel. The August contract lost $1.87 to $61.05.
1:15 p.m. Update: Losses Build In Afternoon Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Major stock indexes fell to new session lows in early afternoon trading Wednesday.
Hurt by commodity and bank stocks, the NYSE composite dropped 1.6% and pierced its 200-day moving average. The S&P 500 lost 1.2%, the Nasdaq 1% and the Dow 0.8%.
Turnover was again tracking sharply higher across the board, and the pace had picked up.

Exchange operators continued to slide following Monday's news that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission may set limits on speculation in energy futures. The CFTC will hold hearings this month. IntercontinentalExchange (ICE) gapped down and dumped 11% to a two-month low.
CME Group (CME) dropped 7% and neared its 200-day moving average.
Changyou.com (CYOU) erased early gains and lost 5% in fast trade. The stock is about 3% above potential support at its 50-day moving average.
Likewise, group mates Shanda Interactive Entertainment (SNDA) and Perfect World (PWRD) also reversed lower. They lost 5% and 3% respectively. Shanda breached its 50-day line.

On the upside, Dollar Tree (DLTR) gapped up, rallied 6% and regained its 50-day moving average. The discount retailer jumped in sympathy with Family Dollar Stores (FDO), which earlier delivered fiscal Q3 earnings above views.
Elsewhere, crude oil dropped $2.47 to $60.46 a barrel after an Energy Information Administration report showed that distillate and gasoline supplies increased more than expected.
12:15 p.m. Update: Market Turns Lower At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
Stocks turned early gains into losses at midday Wednesday as the market continued to show weakness.
The Nasdaq and S&P 500 both sank 0.7%, while the Dow industrials shed 0.4%. The NYSE composite was off 0.9%.
Volume remained higher across the board. It jumped 18% on the NYSE and 23% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.

Marvel Entertainment (MVL) was barely higher after rising 1% in nearly twice its normal trade. The multimedia entertainment company has found institutional support, garnering an A- grade for its Accumulation/Distribution Rating.
Amazon.com (AMZN) climbed 2% in above-average volume but was barely holding on to gains. The online retail giant is 17% off its 52-week high.

On the downside, Synaptics (SYNA) tumbled 7% in more than three times its typical turnover. The maker of touchpads for digital music players and other devices sliced through its 50-day moving average. It is one of the clearest sell signals among the market's leaders.

Fuqi International (FUQI) slid 12% in triple its usual trade. The China-based jewelry maker has been one of the most volatile stocks of the past few months but also one of the most successful, staging a big uptrend.
11:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Retain Slight Gains

5:15 p.m. Update: Major stock averages bounced back from big losses to end mixed Wednesday.The Dow and Nasdaq edged up 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. Meanwhile, weighed down by metals and financials, the NYSE composite fell 0.5%. It closed above its 200-day moving average after piercing the line intraday. The S&P 500 lost 0.2%.Volume climbed sharply on the Nasdaq and NYSE. Decliners beat advancers by about 2-to-1 on both exchangesRetail stocks jumped ahead of Thursday's June same-store sales data.Family Dollar Stores (FDO) gapped up and surged nearly 13% after it beat views with a 35% jump in fiscal Q3 earnings. The stock regained its 50-day moving average.Group mates Dollar Tree (DLTR) and Big Lots (BIG) climbed 8% and 3%, respectively.Tractor Supply (TSCO) gapped up and surged 11% to a 10-month high. The operator of farm and ranch stores raised its full-year profit outlook to a range of $2.78 to $2.92 a share vs. views of $2.64.Overall, retailers were strong across the board.On the downside, Pegasystems (PEGA) tumbled 10% and sliced its 50-day moving average in about twice its average trade. The stock had been above the line since gapping up May 5.Synaptics (SYNA) trimmed an 8% loss to 3%. But the stock closed below its 50-day line for the first time in four months.On the economic calendar, jobless claims and wholesale inventories will be out Thursday. Earnings from 3Com (COMS), Chattem (CHTT), Infosys (INFY) and Posco (PKX) will also be out Thursday.4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Battle To Mixed CloseBY VINCENT MAOLate-session buyers helped stocks to a mixed finish Wednesday.The Dow and Nasdaq rose 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. China's show of confidence in Europe sent stocks sharply higher Thursday. China reassured investors that it wasn't selling its European debt holdings. Equities shrugged off disappointing economic data.
Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?
Click here to watch the latest Market Wrap video!

The NYSE composite jumped 3.9%, its biggest gain since a 4.9% surge on May 10. The Nasdaq rallied 3.7%, regaining its 200-day moving average. The S&P 500 and Dow climbed 3.3% and 2.8%, respectively. Both closed just below their 200-day lines. Volume fell markedly across the board, mitigating the day's gains.

NetApp (NTAP) gapped above its 50-day moving average and rocketed 18% on more than four-times average volume. Late Wednesday, the data-storage firm delivered fiscal Q4 results above views and gave an upbeat outlook for the current quarter.
Group mate Xyratex (XRTX) bolted 16% and neared its 10-week moving average, which lies above.

VeriFone Systems (PAY) gapped up, surged 16% and regained its 10-week line. Late Wednesday, the payment processor delivered fiscal Q2 results above views and raised its full-year profit outlook. Thursday morning, Wedbush raised shares to neutral from underperform.

STR Holdings (STRI) rallied 12% on double its average volume. The stock regained its 10-week line. STR makes encapsulants used in making solar modules. Analysts see a 371% surge in its second-quarter earnings.
In after-hours news, J. Crew Group (JCG) jumped 7% after reporting Q1 results above views. The apparel retailer also guided full-year profit ahead of analysts' estimates.

OmniVision Technologies (OVTI) delivered fiscal Q4 earnings and sales ahead of analysts' estimates. And it guided current quarter profit and revenue above views. Shares rallied 8% in extended trading.
But Blue Coat Systems (BCSI) tumbled 17% on a disappointing fiscal Q1 sales outlook.
Reports on personal income, personal spending, Chicago PMI and the Michigan sentiment index will be out Friday.
U.S. Stocks Hold Big Gains Into The Close
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks stormed out of the gate and never looked back Thursday. All major indexes closed just ticks off session highs and most rose for the first time in four sessions.
The NYSE composite bolted 3.9%, the Nasdaq 3.7%, the S&P 500 3.3% and the Dow 2.8%. Volume fell sharply across the board, dampening the day's gains.
Nearly all 197 industry groups tracked by IBD finished higher. Data storage, steel and energy groups were the session's best performers.
U.S. Stocks Extend Gains In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks marched to new session highs and were on pace to snap a three-session losing streak.
The NYSE composite bolted 3.4%, Nasdaq 3.3%, S&P 500 2.8% and Dow 2.3%. Volume was again tracking lower on both exchanges. But trade was picking up on the Nasdaq.

Avago Technologies (AVGO) rallied 6% and regained its 50-day moving average. Late Wednesday, the Singaporean chipmaker reported fiscal Q2 earnings of 47 cents a share vs. views of 43 cents. It lost a penny a share in the year-ago period. Analysts see its full-year profit surging 176%.

SXC Health Solutions (SXCI) climbed 5% to a new all-time high. The company provides pharmacy benefit management services and IT services. SXC's earnings growth decelerated in recent quarters, but sales growth accelerated.

Blue Coat Systems (BCSI) gained 5% ahead of its fiscal Q4 results after the close. Analysts see the application delivery firm's earnings bolting 111% to 40 cents a share. Sales are slated to climb 17% to $132.7 million.

J. Crew Group (JCG) rose 3% in fast trade. It, too, reports quarterly results after the close. The preppy apparel retailer is expected to deliver earnings of 57 cents a share, up 78% from a year ago. Sales are seen rising 14% to $394.2 million.
OmniVision Technologies (OVTI) and Diamond Foods (DMND) will also report quarter results after the close.
U.S. Stocks Touch New Intraday Highs
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks eased after briefly touching new session highs.
The NYSE composite climbed 3%, the Nasdaq 2.9%, the S&P 500 2.4% and the Dow 2.1%. Turnover continued to track lower across the board.
Gold fell $1.88 to $1,211.52 an ounce. Crude pulled back, but was still up $2.63 to $74.14 an ounce.

SanDisk (SNDK) rallied 6% to its best level since October 2007. The stock is on the rise for the fifth straight session. Analysts see the flash-memory products maker's earnings surging 102% this year.
Other chip issues also were strong Thursday. NetLogic Microsystems (NETL) and Cree (CREE) climbed 5% each. The Philadelphia semiconductor index jumped 4.4%.
Retailers were also among Thursday's top performers.
Rue21 (RUE) climbed 8% after reporting Q1 earnings that more than doubled late Wednesday.

Tiffany (TIF) trimmed an earlier 9% gain to 5%. The stock backed off after nearly hitting its 50-day moving average. Before the open, the luxury goods retailer delivered Q1 earnings and sales above views, and raised its full-year profit outlook.

On the downside, education stocks fell. In a Dow Jones report, hedge fund manager Steve Eisman said that he believes earnings from school operators could fall sharply if the government implements new regulations.
Grand Canyon Education (LOPE) and DeVry (DV) fell 4% each.
U.S. Stocks Hold Big Gains In Early Afternoon Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks hovered near session highs in early afternoon trading Thursday.
The NYSE surged 3%, Nasdaq 2.9%, S&P 500 2.2% and Dow 2%. Volume continued to track lower across the board. Advancers trounced decliners by 14-to-1 on the NYSE and more than 5-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Crude oil rallied $2.78 to $74.29 a barrel. Gold turned lower, falling $2 to $1,211.40 an ounce.

NetApp (NTAP) gapped above its 50-day moving average and bolted 17% to a three-year high. Late Wednesday, the data storage firm beat views with a 61% increase in fiscal Q4 earnings and a 33% gain in sales. And it guided Q1 results ahead above analysts' estimates.

VeriFone Holdings (PAY) gapped up, surged 16% and regained its 50-day line. Late Wednesday, the payment processor delivered fiscal Q2 results above views and raised its full-year profit outlook. Thursday morning, Wedbush raised shares to neutral from underperform. Its Composite Rating, however, is only 80.

Hi-Tech Pharmacal (HITK) gapped above its 200-day line, surging 12% in heavy trading. The stock also regained its 50-day line. Standard & Poors announced late Wednesday that the drugmaker will replace Tractor Supply (TSCO) in the small-cap S&P 600.
U.S. Stocks Surge In Mild Trade At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes hit fresh session highs at midday Thursday, though the rally came in curiously quiet trading.
The Nasdaq zoomed 2.8%, the S&P 500 2.5%, the Dow 2.2% and the NYSE composite 3.1%. Volume fell 19% on the NYSE and 6% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Wednesday.
Beaten-down energy and commodities stocks, including coal and solar power companies and steel producers, rank among the session's top-performing groups.
Meanwhile, chip stocks are up sharply, with the Philadelphia semiconductor index surging 3.8%.

Spreadtrum Communications (SPRD) jumped 7% in heavy volume. The chipmaker's stock has been surging since gapping up 16% on May 18 following a bullish earnings report. Spreadtrum has rocketed 54% in the month of May.
Other chipmakers on the rise include SanDisk (SNDK) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS), up 5% each, and Avago Technologies (AVGO), up 4%.
U.S. Stocks Soar To Session Highs

China's show of confidence in Europe sent stocks sharply higher Thursday. China reassured investors that it wasn't selling its European debt holdings. Equities shrugged off disappointing economic data.Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?

Spreadtrum has rocketed 54% in the month of May.Other chipmakers on the rise include SanDisk (SNDK) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS), up 5% each, and Avago Technologies (AVGO), up 4%.U.S. Stocks Soar To Session Highs
Stocks stumbled Wednesday, sending most indexes down for the first time in four sessions.

The NYSE composite fell 0.8%, the Dow 0.7%, the S&P 500 0.6%. The Nasdaq took a milder 0.2% loss. Chips issues were one bright spot: The Philadelphia semiconductor index rose 0.4%. And Apple (APPL) rose for the fourth straight session.
Volume jumped across the board, handing all the major indexes a distribution day.

Micrus Endovascular (MEND) fell 5% in heavy trading. It fell further below its 50-day moving average after breaching that line Tuesday. The stock may be working on a new base, but it is lacking accumulation.

Parexel (PRXL) gapped down and fell 4% in more than twice its average trade. Wells Fargo cut the clinical research firm to market perform from outperform partly due to valuation. The stock snapped a five-session win streak.

Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) fell 3% in nearly double average volume. The stock slipped further below its 50-day moving average. Intuitive Surgical's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has weakened to D- from B+ in early March. Intuitive Surgical reports first-quarter earnings April 15. Views are for $1.68 a share, up 133% from a year ago.
Netflix (NFLX) fell 4% in nearly twice its average trade. Barclays downgraded the provider of online movie rentals to equalweight from overweight, citing valuation concerns after a huge run-up.

On the upside, Big Lots (BIG) rose 3% in more than four times its normal trade. The discount retail chain's stock hit its highest point in nearly 12 years. Big Lots rallied in sympathy with Family Dollar Stores (FDO), which reported better-than-expected earnings.
After the close, Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) rallied 4% after delivering Q4 earnings and sales above views. The retailer also guided Q1 EPS above views.
No noteworthy earnings announcements are due Thursday. Jobless claims data are due out before the opening bell.
Late Selling Drives Stocks Lower
BY VINCENT MAO
A late round of selling sent stocks firmly lower Wednesday. But most indexes finished off the worst levels of the session.
The NYSE composite dropped 0.8%, Dow 0.7%, S&P 500 fell 0.6% and Nasdaq 0.2%.
Volume surged on both exchanges.

Gold producers were the session's top group after the yellow metal hit a new high for the year. Retail-related groups also fared well. Many of the nation's retailers will report March same-store sales Thursday. Steel makers and homebuilders were two of Wednesday's hardest-hit groups.
U.S. Stocks Weaken In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks weakened in late trading Wednesday. Most indexes were back near session lows.
The Dow and NYSE composite shed 0.6% each, while the S&P 500 fell 0.4%. The Nasdaq turned lower, falling 0.2%. Volume was again tracking sharply higher across the board.

Speaking in Dallas, Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke said that the economy is starting to grow again, but still has hurdles in the way. "Fortunately, today the financial crisis looks to be mostly behind us, and the economy seems to have stabilized and is beginning to grow again. But we are far from being out of the woods. Many Americans are still grappling with unemployment or foreclosure, or both."

Allscripts-Misys Healthcare Solutions (MDRX) was off its session peak but still up 1% ahead of its earnings report after the close. The provider of health care technology services is expected to earn 16 cents a share on sales of $175.5 million.

Retailer Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) reversed earlier losses and rose less than 1%. It too reports after the close. Analysts see the firm earning 73 cents a share, up 33% from a year ago. Sales are slated to rise 10% to about $2.1 billion.
On the downside, Dollar General (DG) erased early gains and slipped 2% in fast trade. It retraced a good chunk of Tuesday's move.
Stocks Turn Mixed After Treasury Auction
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks turned mixed in early afternoon trading after results from a strong note auction.
Thanks to gains in Apple (AAPL), Baidu (BIDU) and Qualcomm (QCOM), the Nasdaq edged up 0.2%. Chips also helped. The Philadelphia semiconductor index climbed 0.9%.
Meanwhile, the Dow and NYSE composite fell 0.3% each, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.2%.
Turnover continued to track sharply higher across the board.
The government sold $21 billion in 10-year notes with a yield of 3.9%. The bid-to-cover ratio, a gauge of demand, was a robust 3.72, according to Bloomberg.
Gold settled at $1,153 an ounce, up $17 on the session. Crude oil fell 31 cents to $86.53 a barrel.
Altisource Portfolio Solutions (ASPS) erased earlier losses and added 4% to Tuesday's 9% gain. The stock regained its 50-day moving average. Altisource is building up the right side of a new base.

NetApp (NTAP) reversed opening losses and rose 2% to a near three-year high, putting the stock 5% past a 33.79 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. Earlier Wednesday, the data storage firm said it bought software maker Bycast for an undisclosed amount.
U.S. Stocks Hold Lower; Nasdaq Faring Better
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks weakened in early afternoon trading Wednesday. But the Nasdaq showed some relative strength.
The tech-heavy index slipped a mild 0.1%, thanks to support from Apple (AAPL) and Baidu (BIDU).
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite and the Dow fell 0.4% each. The S&P 500 lost 0.3%. Volume was sharply higher on both major exchanges.
The dollar was higher against the euro, but weaker against the yen. Gold jumped $15.20 to $1,151.20 an ounce.
Gold-mining stocks also rallied. Randgold Resources (GOLD) climbed 4% in fast trade, while Newmont Mining (NEM) gained 3% in average volume. Both have mediocre Relative Strength Ratings.
A round of restaurant stocks bucked market weakness.

BJ's Restaurants (BJRI) climbed 4% and neared its March peak. The stock cleared a 23.01 buy point from a cup base March 9, but did so in soft volume. It may be forming a base-on-base pattern. Despite tough times last year, the pizza and brewery chain grew earnings by 20%. Analysts see a 19% EPS rise this year.

Cheesecake Factory (CAKE) rose 2% to a 32-month high. The stock has shaped two three-weeks-tight patterns in recent weeks. Cheesecake Factory reports earnings April 22. Views are for 25 cents a share, up 47% from a year ago.
Cracker Barrel Old Country Store (CBRL) added 2% to a fresh three-year high. Stifel Nicolaus started coverage of the restaurant and gift shop operator with a buy rating.

Elsewhere, Tractor Supply (TSCO) gapped up and surged 8% in heavy trading. The gardening and farming equipment retailer raised its guidance for the first quarter and full-year profit. For Q1, it expects earnings between 22 cents and 24 cents a share vs. views of a penny a share. For all of 2010, the company now sees profit in range of $3.48 to $3.60 a share vs. views of $3.39. The stock was up as much as 10% earlier.

On the downside, Parexel (PRXL) gapped down and dropped 5% on a downgrade. Wells Fargo cut the clinical research firm to market perform from outperform partly due to valuation. The stock is on pace to snap a five-session win streak.
U.S. Stocks Pare Losses; Volume Remains Heavy
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes pared earlier losses at midday Wednesday, as investors continued to grapple with the psychological barrier of the Dow near 11,000.

The Dow fell 0.3%, the S&P 500 0.2%, the Nasdaq less than 0.1% and the NYSE composite 0.4%. Volume swelled across the board. It rose 13% on the NYSE and 26% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.

Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) shed 2% in twice its normal trade. The surgical equipment maker's stock sliced through its 50-day moving average and is at risk of closing below that support level for the first time since July 2009.
Aixtron (AIXG) fell 2% in rapid volume. The German chipmaker's stock has staged a gigantic run-up, surging nearly 10-fold since March of last year.

On the upside, Blue Coat Systems (BCSI) advanced 2% in nearly double its average turnover. The maker of proxy appliances that secure and accelerate delivery of business applications over the Internet owns a 95 Earnings Per Share Rating and a 98 Composite Rating.
U.S. Stocks Extend Losses

Stocks stumbled Wednesday, sending most indexes down for the first time in four sessions.The NYSE composite fell 0.8%, the Dow 0.7%, the S&P 500 0.6%. The Nasdaq took a milder 0.2% loss. Chips issues were one bright spot: The Philadelphia semiconductor index rose 0.4%. And Apple (APPL) rose for the fourth straight session.Volume jumped across the board, handing all the major indexes a distribution day.Micrus Endovascular (MEND) fell 5% in heavy trading. It fell further below its 50-day moving average after breaching that line Tuesday. The stock may be working on a new base, but it is lacking accumulation.Parexel (PRXL) gapped down and fell 4% in more than twice its average trade. Wells Fargo cut the clinical research firm to market perform from outperform partly due to valuation. The stock snapped a five-session win streak.Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) fell 3% in nearly double average volume. The stock slipped further below its 50-day moving average. Intuitive Surgical's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has weakened to D- from B+ in early March. Intuitive Surgical reports first-quarter earnings April 15. Views are for $1.68 a share, up 133% from a year ago.Netflix (NFLX) fell 4% in nearly twice its average trade. Barclays downgraded the provider of online movie rentals to equalweight from overweight, citing valuation concerns after a huge run-up.On the upside, Big Lots (BIG) rose 3% in more than four times its normal trade. The discount retail chain's stock hit its highest point in nearly 12 years. Big Lots rallied in sympathy with Family Dollar Stores (FDO), which reported better-than-expected earnings.After the close, Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) rallied 4% after delivering Q4 earnings and sales above views. The retailer also guided Q1 EPS above views.No noteworthy earnings announcements are due Thursday. Jobless claims data are due out before the opening bell.Late Selling Drives Stocks LowerBY VINCENT MAOA late round of selling sent stocks firmly lower Wednesday. But most indexes finished off the worst levels of the session.The NYSE composite dropped 0.8%, Dow 0.7%, S&P 500 fell 0.6% and Nasdaq 0.2%.Volume surged on both exchanges.Gold producers were the session's top group after the yellow metal hit a new high for the year. Retail-related groups also fared well. Many of the nation's retailers will report March same-store sales Thursday. Steel makers and homebuilders were two of Wednesday's hardest-hit groups.U.S. Stocks Weaken In Late TradeBY VINCENT MAOStocks weakened in late trading Wednesday. Most indexes were back near session lows.The Dow and NYSE composite shed 0.6% each, while the S&P 500 fell 0.4%. The Nasdaq turned lower, falling 0.2%. Volume was again tracking sharply higher across the board.Speaking in Dallas, Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke said that the economy is starting to grow again, but still has hurdles in the way. "Fortunately, today the financial crisis looks to be mostly behind us, and the economy seems to have stabilized and is beginning to grow again. But we are far from being out of the woods. Many Americans are still grappling with unemployment or foreclosure, or both."Allscripts-Misys Healthcare Solutions (MDRX) was off its session peak but still up 1% ahead of its earnings report after the close. The provider of health care technology services is expected to earn 16 cents a share on sales of $175.5 million.Retailer Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) reversed earlier losses and rose less than 1%. It too reports after the close. Analysts see the firm earning 73 cents a share, up 33% from a year ago. Sales are slated to rise 10% to about $2.1 billion.On the downside, Dollar General (DG) erased early gains and slipped 2% in fast trade. It retraced a good chunk of Tuesday's move.Stocks Turn Mixed After Treasury AuctionBY VINCENT MAOStocks turned mixed in early afternoon trading after results from a strong note auction.Thanks to gains in Apple (AAPL), Baidu (BIDU) and Qualcomm (QCOM), the Nasdaq edged up 0.2%. Chips also helped. The Philadelphia semiconductor index climbed 0.9%.Meanwhile, the Dow and NYSE composite fell 0.3% each, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.2%.Turnover continued to track sharply higher across the board.The government sold $21 billion in 10-year notes with a yield of 3.9%. The bid-to-cover ratio, a gauge of demand, was a robust 3.72, according to Bloomberg.Gold settled at $1,153 an ounce, up $17 on the session. Crude oil fell 31 cents to $86.53 a barrel.Altisource Portfolio Solutions (ASPS) erased earlier losses and added 4% to Tuesday's 9% gain. The stock regained its 50-day moving average. Altisource is building up the right side of a new base.NetApp (NTAP) reversed opening losses and rose 2% to a near three-year high, putting the stock 5% past a 33.79 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. Earlier Wednesday, the data storage firm said it bought software maker Bycast for an undisclosed amount.U.S. Stocks Hold Lower; Nasdaq Faring BetterBY VINCENT MAOStocks weakened in early afternoon trading Wednesday.
