5:15 p.m. Update: The week wound down to an unremarkable finish, with indexes giving up early gains to end mixed in heavy options-expiration trading.

The Nasdaq ended 0.8% higher and the S&P 500 edged up 0.3%. The NYSE composite was a fraction into the red. The Dow, slipping 0.3% on a quadruple-witching boost from options expirations, logged its third distribution day since the Dec. 2 follow-through.
Still, three of the four major indexes gained ground for the week. The NYSE composite added 1.3% and the Nasdaq 1.5%. The S&P 500 edged 0.9% higher, while the Dow slipped 0.6%.
For the NYSE, Nasdaq and S&P 500 it was the first two-week advance since September. The Dow hasn't managed a two-week gain since May.
In addition, all the major indexes eased in late trading, losing the week's battle to hold above their 50-day moving averages.

No significant economic news is scheduled for release Monday. But Tuesday's releases will include new and existing home sales, GDP data and the University of Michigan's revised Consumer Sentiment index numbers for December.
Drugstore chain Walgreen (WAG) and software maker Red Hat (RHT) are scheduled to report earnings Monday.
4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Close Mixed After Volatile Session
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
A volatile session ended with mixed results Friday.
The Dow fell 0.4%, weighed down mostly by oil components Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX), as crude continued sliding.
The NYSE composite edged down a fraction, while the S&P 500 rose 0.2% and the Nasdaq 0.8%, according to early figures.
Volume rose amid options expiration-related trading. The market heads into one of its quietest weeks, shortened by the Christmas holiday.
Automakers and auto-supplier stocks rose after the White House agreed to provide emergency loans to the Big Three.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Hold Gains, But Settle To Lower End of Ranges
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
A back-and-forth session held to positive territory, as decliners led advancing issues by healthy margins. But the day's heavy-volume trading bypassed most leading stocks.
The Nasdaq composite held top honors, up 1.3%. The S&P 500 kept 0.9% in the black, while the Dow and NYSE composite clung to 0.4% gains.

Research in Motion (RIMM) and Oracle (ORCL) continued to be heavy upside players on the Nasdaq. Energy and international plays lagged on the NYSE. Small caps continued riding ahead of the mainstream, driving the S&P 600 up better than 2%.
Volume continued to settle toward more normal ranges, but remained 78% higher on the NYSE and up 23% on the Nasdaq.

Oil prices split in late trading. The expiring January contract shed $2.35 to settle at $33.87. The February contract climbed rose 69 cents to $42.36, leaving the front month contract down 8% for the week.

Aaron Rents (RNT) climbed 5%, breaking above a 26.68 buy point on a 13-week, cup-with-handle base. The rent-to-own chain announced Tuesday it would acquire Missouri-based Rosey Rentals, a franchisee operating 35 Aaron's stores in six states in the Southeast with annual revenue of about $45 million.

Quality Systems (QSII) cut losses for a 4% run, but volume was just a shade above average. The maker of health care practice and records management software has jumped 16% so far this week as it works to build the right side of a base.

On the downside, Italian oil & gas heavyweight Eni Spa  (E) slipped 7% as oil prices sculpted out multiyear lows. Eni has been in a general uptrend since early October and is holding its own above support at its 10-week moving average.
2:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Rebound In Afternoon Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
The major stock indexes bounced back in afternoon trading Friday but remained off session highs.
The Nasdaq climbed 1.5%, the S&P 500 1.1%, while the Dow and NYSE composite rose 0.6% each.
Volume continued to track sharply higher, but the pace had slowed.
PetMed Express (PETS) rallied 6% and regained its 50-day moving average. The pet pharmacy operator may be forming a base.
Research In Motion (RIMM) rallied 9% in heavy trading. Despite hovering near two-year lows, the stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has improved to B from a worst-possible E in October.

On the downside, AeroVironment (AVAV) extended losses to 10% and is off more than 8% from its buy point. The unmanned aircraft systems maker cleared a 36.32 buy point from a base-on-base pattern Thursday.

Tractor Supply (TSCO) dropped 4% and sliced is 10-week and 40-week moving averages. The stock also triggered the 8% sell rule. It passed a 42.85 buy point from a double-bottom base Wednesday. William Blair & Co. warned that deflation may hurt the farming equipment retailer.
Crude oil dropped $1.90 to $34.32 a barrel. Energy stocks were mixed.
1:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Tinker With Mixed Territory; Small Caps Outperform
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTTIndexes threw in the towel after an early surge spurred by news of a federal bailout for U.S. automakers.
The NYSE composite slipped briefly into the red, then managed a fractional gain. The Dow flattened. The S&P 500 held a 0.5% advance and the Nasdaq composite showed a 0.9% rise.

Financial issues dragged on the Nasdaq, with the exchange's financial index down 1.3%. Computer, telecom and insurance sectors still held better-than-1% gains. On the NYSE, the International 100 index lagged with a 1% decline, and technology stocks tracked close behind. Small caps ran well ahead of the curve, with the S&P 600 up 2%.
Volume eased from its early highs, but remained at extraordinary levels  particularly on the NYSE  because of options expiration trading.
Crude oil prices ground lower, down more than $1 after dipping to midsession lows below $34 a barrel. Gold held the bulk of its early losses, remaining down more than $22 to below $838 an ounce.
Flowers Foods (FLO) cooked up a 4% gain as it tried to notch its first weekly gain in December. Shares are still well below their 50- and 200-day moving averages in a consolidation begun in August.

Onyx Pharmaceuticals  (ONXX) swung 5% higher in above-average volume. The biotech drug maker is in its fourth straight week of gains, has topped resistance at its 10-week line and appears ready to take a run at the 40-week level.

On the downside, advanced ceramic components maker Ceradyne (CRDN) gapped down and surrendered 20% after a downgrade from buy to hold from Stanford Research. The big-volume tumble punched the stock back below support at its 50-day line. It has been trying to build a floor to a consolidation begun in August.
12:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Retreat Near Session's Halftime
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks pulled back sharply near the halftime of Friday's session. Most major indexes slipped back under their respective 50-day moving averages after regaining them earlier.
The Nasdaq climbed 1.4%, down from an intraday high of 2.6%. The S&P 500 rose 1%, Dow 0.6% and NYSE composite 0.4%.
Volume was again tracking vastly higher across the board due to quadruple expiration and the quarterly rebalancing of S&P indexes.
Tower Group (TWGP) tacked on 9% in heavy trading, its fourth straight advance. The insurance firm is nearing a potential 27.63 buy point from a cup base.
Gentiva Health Services (GTIV) gapped up and gained 3% in brisk trade. After a failed breakout earlier this month, the home health care firm is forming a new handle with a buy point at 28.36.

On the downside, Supertex (SUPX) gapped down and dropped 7% after cutting its sales outlook. The chipmaker now expects revenue in the range of $17 million to $18 million, down from a prior forecast of $21.3 million to $22.3 million. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Atmel (ATML), Atheros Communications (ATHR), MEMC Electronic Materials (WFR), Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) and Xilinx (XLNX) have all slashed their earnings and/or sales guidances.
AeroVironment (AVAV) lost 4% in active trading, slipping below a 36.32 buy point cleared Thursday.
11:15 a.m. Update: Indexes Drive To Solid Gains With Options Expiration Support
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Indexes swept higher in broad-based gains, with advancing issues leading by better than 4-to-1 on the NYSE and by a 3-to-1 margin on the Nasdaq.
The Nasdaq composite scored a 2.5% rise, with Oracle (ORCL), Research In Motion (RIMM) and Comcast (CMCSA) driving the Nasdaq 100.
The S&P 500 flashed a 2% advance, the Dow climbed 1.8% and the NYSE composite rode 1.5% higher.
On the NYSE, energy, financials and health care pulled ahead of other sectors.
NYSE volume erupted in quadruple witching action, up nearly 250%. Nasdaq volume soared 67% above Thursday's below-average volume.

Commodities traded generally mixed as crude futures hovered, holding near a 4-1/2 year low just below $36 a barrel. The dollar strengthened vs. the euro. Gold slumped more than $25 to below $836 an ounce.

S&P 400 component Highwood Properties (HIW) phoned in an 8% jump on more than double its average trading volume. The Southeast/Midwest commercial property REIT sports a best possible 99 EPS Rating from IBD. It appears set to end its second week above its 10-week moving average as it climbs up from a three-month consolidation.

California Water Services (CWT) launched into a 4% gain in heavy trade. The move began what would be a fourth straight day of gains for the multistate public and commercial water utility. Shares are up 14% so far this week, clearing new highs for the first time since 2006 and 8% above a 42.60 buy point on a rebound from the stock's 10-week moving average.

On the downside, heavy construction firm Fluor (FLR) slipped 7% in busy trading. The company, which has strong ties to refining and energy industry construction, has suffered from the fall in oil prices. Shares are down 6% so far for the week, hurting the stock's effort to build a right side to a six-month consolidation.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Pare Gains After Higher Open
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks charged out of the gate Friday after automakers received their long-awaited bailout, but the major indexes have already shaved a chunk of gains.
The Nasdaq climbed 1.3%, thanks to gains in a number of high-profile tech issues and chip stocks. The Dow rose 0.6% and the S&P 500 0.5%. The NYSE composite was mostly unchanged.
Volume was tracking vastly higher due to quadruple expiration of stock options, stock index options, stock index futures and single stock futures.
Provident Bankshares (PBKS) gapped up and skyrocketed 58% on news that it will be acquired by M & T Bank for $401 million in stock.

Research In Motion (RIMM) rose 5% in fast trade following a round of mixed analysts' actions. Cowen & Co. cut the BlackBerry maker to underperform from neutral, while Raymond James and UBS both cut the stock's price target. TD Bank Financial raised shares to Action List Buy from Buy.
On the downside, AECOM Technology (ACM) fell 3% as it slipped for a second session. That left the government contractor 5% past a 27.30 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern.
January crude pared losses, but was still down 53 cents to $35.69 a barrel.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Poised For Higher Start As Automakers Get Bailed Out
BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures signaled a higher open Friday after the While House announced help for U.S. automakers.
Nasdaq futures rose 12 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures rallied 9 points and Dow futures gained 112 points.
General Motors (GM) and Chrysler will split $13.4 billion in loans to help them stave off bankruptcy. They'll split another $4 billion in February and must show "financial viability" by March.
GM shares rose 7% in the pre-market. Ford (F), which has said it doesn't need bailout money, rose 5%.

Standard & Poor's Ratings Services cut ratings on a slew of major U.S. and European banks, citing rising risks amid the worsening recession. The list of downgraded firms includes Bank of America (BAC), Barclays (BCS), Citigroup (C), Credit Suisse Group (CS), Deutsche Bank (DB), Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Morgan Stanley (MS), Royal Bank of Scotland Group (RBS), UBS (UBS) and Wells Fargo (WFC).
S&P also lowered HSBC's (HBC) outlook to negative. The U.K. bank fell 3% in the pre-market.

On the upside, Oracle (ORCL) gained nearly 4% in the pre-open on its bright fiscal Q3 outlook. Amid a weak tech spending environment, the database software maker sees current quarter sales growing 8% to 11% vs. views of 8%. Earnings are pegged at 34 cents to 36 cents a share vs. views of 34 cents.

Intrepid Potash (IPI) cut its Q4 sales outlook, while fellow fertilizer maker Potash Corp. Of Saskatchewan (POT) cut its full-year profit guidance. Intrepid fell 14% in the pre-market, while Potash Corp. shed 3%.
Elsewhere, Panasonic offered to buy rival Sanyo for $9 billion.

Crude oil rebounded slightly after touching its lowest level in nearly five years. The expiring January contract fell $1.42 to $34.08 a barrel. Earlier, it hit $33.44, the lowest since February 2004.5:15 p.m. Update: The week wound down to an unremarkable finish, with indexes giving up early gains to end mixed in heavy options-expiration trading.The Nasdaq ended 0.8% higher and the S&P 500 edged up 0.3%. After a failed breakout earlier this month, the home health care firm is forming a new handle with a buy point at 28.36.On the downside, Supertex (SUPX) gapped down and dropped 7% after cutting its sales outlook. The chipmaker now expects revenue in the range of $17 million to $18 million, down from a prior forecast of $21.3 million to $22.3 million. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Atmel (ATML), Atheros Communications (ATHR), MEMC Electronic Materials (WFR), Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) and Xilinx (XLNX) have all slashed their earnings and/or sales guidances.AeroVironment (AVAV) lost 4% in active trading, slipping below a 36.32 buy point cleared Thursday.11:15 a.m. Update: Indexes Drive To Solid Gains With Options Expiration Support BY ALAN R. ELLIOTTIndexes swept higher in broad-based gains, with advancing issues leading by better than 4-to-1 on the NYSE and by a 3-to-1 margin on the Nasdaq.The Nasdaq composite scored a 2.5% rise, with Oracle (ORCL), Research In Motion (RIMM) and Comcast (CMCSA) driving the Nasdaq 100.The S&P 500 flashed a 2% advance, the Dow climbed 1.8% and the NYSE composite rode 1.5% higher.On the NYSE, energy, financials and health care pulled ahead of other sectors.NYSE volume erupted in quadruple witching action, up nearly 250%. Nasdaq volume soared 67% above Thursday's below-average volume.Commodities traded generally mixed as crude futures hovered, holding near a 4-1/2 year low just below $36 a barrel. The dollar strengthened vs. the euro. Gold slumped more than $25 to below $836 an ounce.S&P 400 component Highwood Properties (HIW) phoned in an 8% jump on more than double its average trading volume. The Southeast/Midwest commercial property REIT sports a best possible 99 EPS Rating from IBD. It appears set to end its second week above its 10-week moving average as it climbs up from a three-month consolidation.California Water Services (CWT) launched into a 4% gain in heavy trade. The move began what would be a fourth straight day of gains for the multistate public and commercial water utility. Shares are up 14% so far this week, clearing new highs for the first time since 2006 and 8% above a 42.60 buy point on a rebound from the stock's 10-week moving average.On the downside, heavy construction firm Fluor (FLR) slipped 7% in busy trading. The company, which has strong ties to refining and energy industry construction, has suffered from the fall in oil prices. Shares are down 6% so far for the week, hurting the stock's effort to build a right side to a six-month consolidation.10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Pare Gains After Higher OpenBY VINCENT MAOStocks charged out of the gate Friday after automakers received their long-awaited bailout, but the major indexes have already shaved a chunk of gains.The Nasdaq climbed 1.3%, thanks to gains in a number of high-profile tech issues and chip stocks. The Dow rose 0.6% and the S&P 500 0.5%. The NYSE composite was mostly unchanged.Volume was tracking vastly higher due to quadruple expiration of stock options, stock index options, stock index futures and single stock futures.Provident Bankshares (PBKS) gapped up and skyrocketed 58% on news that it will be acquired by M & T Bank for $401 million in stock.Research In Motion (RIMM) rose 5% in fast trade following a round of mixed analysts' actions. Cowen & Co. cut the BlackBerry maker to underperform from neutral, while Raymond James and UBS both cut the stock's price target. TD Bank Financial raised shares to Action List Buy from Buy.On the downside, AECOM Technology (ACM) fell 3% as it slipped for a second session. That left the government contractor 5% past a 27.30 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern.January crude pared losses, but was still down 53 cents to $35.69 a barrel.9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Poised For Higher Start As Automakers Get Bailed OutBY VINCENT MAOStock futures signaled a higher open Friday after the While House announced help for U.S. automakers.Nasdaq futures rose 12 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures rallied 9 points and Dow futures gained 112 points.General Motors (GM) and Chrysler will split $13.4 billion in loans to help them stave off bankruptcy. They'll split another $4 billion in February and must show "financial viability" by March.GM shares rose 7% in the pre-market. Ford (F), which has said it doesn't need bailout money, rose 5%.Standard & Poor's Ratings Services cut ratings on a slew of major U.S. and European banks, citing rising risks amid the worsening recession. The list of downgraded firms includes Bank of America (BAC), Barclays (BCS), Citigroup (C), Credit Suisse Group (CS), Deutsche Bank (DB), Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Morgan Stanley (MS), Royal Bank of Scotland Group (RBS), UBS (UBS) and Wells Fargo (WFC).S&P also lowered HSBC's (HBC) outlook to negative. The U.K. bank fell 3% in the pre-market.On the upside, Oracle (ORCL) gained nearly 4% in the pre-open on its bright fiscal Q3 outlook. Amid a weak tech spending environment, the database software maker sees current quarter sales growing 8% to 11% vs. views of 8%. Earnings are pegged at 34 cents to 36 cents a share vs. views of 34 cents.Intrepid Potash (IPI) cut its Q4 sales outlook, while fellow fertilizer maker Potash Corp. Of Saskatchewan (POT) cut its full-year profit guidance. Intrepid fell 14% in the pre-market, while Potash Corp. shed 3%.Elsewhere, Panasonic offered to buy rival Sanyo for $9 billion.Crude oil rebounded slightly after touching its lowest level in nearly five years. The expiring January contract fell $1.42 to $34.08 a barrel. Earlier, it hit $33.44, the lowest since February 2004.
Often a fund name change signals a new investment style, but that's not the case with Oppenheimer Discovery Mid Cap Growth .

The biggest switch to the $456 million fund since its June 28 name change from Small- & Mid-Cap Growth is its benchmark. It now measures its performance against the Russell Midcap Growth Index instead of the small-to-midcap-focused Russell 2500 Growth Index.

The fund's moves realigned its name and benchmark with what the fund basically had been doing anyway. Its midcap weightings were 77%, 74% and 79% as of July 31, 2011; June 30, 2012; and June 30, 2013. It was 78% as of Sept. 30.
Its small-cap weightings were 6.40%, 3.88%, 7.84% and 6.90% as of those same dates.
Run by Ronald Zibelli, Jr. since June 2007, the fund has generally downshifted on large caps, with weightings of 15.78%, 12.36% and 11.45% in the three most recent of those periods.
So, in a way, the fund name has changed to reflect the reality of the fund's focus.

The fund's investment objective did not change, Zibelli says. The new name and benchmark more closely reflect its focus on mid caps. The fund still seeks high-quality companies with leading market positions and sustainable competitive advantages, generating above-average growth.
Among its holdings, CoStar Group (CSGP) is a midcap that has helped fund performance this year, rising 98%.
Serving Real Estate Industry
The provider of information services to the commercial real estate industry was the fund's fifth largest holding as of Oct. 31.
With Q2 financial results that beat analysts' consensus estimates and its own guidance, the stock was the third best contributor to Q2 fund performance.
Earnings per share grew 47%, 56% and 51% the past three quarters.
Midcap Tractor Supply (TSCO), the fund's top holding as of Oct. 31, is up 62% this year.
EPS growth has accelerated for two quarters. The rural hardware chain thrives on a loyal clientele, curried by customer service.
Lumber Liquidators (LL) has benefited from the housing rebound. Shares are up 115% this year. The stock is finding support at its 10-week moving average. EPS growth has slowed for two quarters.
A Few Large Caps
The fund's large-cap weighting has slipped, but big stocks still aid the fund. No. 4 holding Actavis (ACT) is up 87% this year.
EPS growth has accelerated for three quarters. And growth is poised to pick up as its buyout of Warner Chilcott is now complete.
Another large stock, Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), is up 26% this year. It's pulled back 6% from its Oct. 30 high and is testing support at its 10-week moving average.
EPS grew 55% and 38% the past two quarters. The drugmaker's focus on rare diseases had led to strong growth.
Large-cap LinkedIn (LNKD), up 93% this year, is consolidating recent gains 16% off its recent high.
Earnings growth has steadily slowed from 267% in Q4 2012 and is projected to grow 9% in the current period.

Mobile revenue and headhunter services are showing good growth, although EPS growth has decelerated the past two quarters.Often a fund name change signals a new investment style, but that's not the case with Oppenheimer Discovery Mid Cap Growth .The biggest switch to the $456 million fund since its June 28 name change from Small- & Mid-Cap Growth is its benchmark. Stocks rose sharply Tuesday, triggering a bullish shift in the market's outlook. The Nasdaq rallied 1%. The S&P 500 climbed 1.1% and closed back above the 50-day moving average after spending 12 days below it. Volume rose, marking the second time in the past four sessions in which the broad indexes make solid gains in higher trading. Translation: Institutional investors…

The pace of new highs picked up Thursday, but at the same time some leading stocks are becoming extended from proper buy ranges. Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) climbed 2.12 to 88.76, closing 7% above the 82.61 buy point of a cup with handle. Green Mountain's 5% buy range extended to 86.74. K12 Inc. (LRN) also became extended after gapping…

Leading stocks were higher after Tuesday's open as the general market rebounded in rising volume. The Nasdaq popped 1.6%, with Broadcom (BRCM) and Logitech (LOGI)leading the Nasdaq 100. The NYSE composite and the S&P 500 each added 1%. Volume was higher compared with the same time Monday. In stocks, Acme Packet (APKT) jumped 5% in heavy trade. The maker of…
The major indexes delivered a mixed performance Wednesday, as the Nasdaq composite ended near its session low.

Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video!
The Nasdaq lost 0.4%, while the S&P 500 edged down less than 0.1%. The NYSE composite tacked on 0.3%. Volume increased on the Nasdaq, but decreased on the NYSE, according to early data.

After hours, Intel (INTC) and eBay (EBAY) were both trading lower even as each tech giant reported Q2 EPS and sales that topped expectations. Intel has been consolidating and finished the regular session about 4% off its 52-week high. It gets an IBD Composite Rating of 79, not close to the best-possible rating of 99. EBay, which has a 96 Composite Rating, also has been consolidating and ended 6% off its recent high.

Also in late trading, F5 Networks (FFIV) dropped as the networking gear maker's June fiscal Q2 profit topped estimates, but its fiscal Q4 targets were only in line with expectations. The stock has been trading near its 10-week and 40-week moving averages, ending the regular session 23% off its high. It sports a 95 Composite Rating.

Tractor Supply (TSCO) slid in extended trading as the specialty retailer's Q2 revenue missed forecasts, though EPS beat views. The company also hiked its 2011 EPS target. Tractor Supply, which has a 98 Composite Rating, is extended after topping a 65.10 buy point from a flat base.

During Wednesday's regular session, stocks appeared to lose ground after euro zone officials cautioned that failure to reach a debt deal could lead to economic damage "in all corners of Europe and beyond." A key EU meeting is planned for Thursday.
On Thursday, quarterly earnings reports are expected from Edwards Lifesciences (EW), EZCorp (EZPW), TravelZoo (TZOO), BJ's Restaurants (BJRI), Informatica (INFA) and Acme Packet (APKT).

Thursday's economic reports will include new readings for the Conference Board's index of leading indicators, the Federal Housing Finance Agency's House Price Index and the Philly Fed's general business conditions index.

The major indexes charged to session highs at midday Tuesday, as volume remained higher across the board. The Nasdaq composite was up 1.9%, the NYSE composite 1.5% and the S&P 500 1.3%. Turnover was up sharply from Monday's levels on both major exchanges. Some top-rated stocks appeared to be staging breakouts. Holly (HOC) gained 4% in fast trade, clearing an…

Stocks ended a ho-hum session with a finish near session highs Monday. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq led the way, rising 0.6% each. The Dow added 0.3%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in about 15-20% lower than Friday.
Despite recent signs of distribution in the major averages, all three indexes continue to hold stubbornly near highs as first-quarter earnings season approaches.

In the stock market today, General Electric (GE) announced plans to buy oilfield pump maker Lufkin Industries (LUFK) for $3.3 billion. The deal values Lufkin at $88.50 per share, a premium of 38% above Friday's close. Shares of Lufkin surged 38% in big volume. GE added 0.8% in heavy volume. GE's presence in the oil and gas industry continues to grow. The segment is now the third-largest by revenue behind GE's power/water and aviation units.

GE's acquisition fueled a big move in IBD's Oil & Gas-Machinery/Equipment group. It rose 4.2%. FMC Technologies (FTI) added 2% in light volume; Dril-Quip (DRQ) rose 2% in average volume and Cameron International (CAM) picked up nearly 2% in light volume.

Other gainers Monday included Dunkin' Brands (DNKN). It extended gains after last week's breakout from a second-stage base, rising 1% in above-average volume, but still has its all-time high to contend with at 40. Dunkin's chart is bullish and growth prospects are pretty good as the company continues to expand, but earnings and sales growth has decelerated for two quarters in a row.

Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) recovered after last week's 6% loss, rallying 3% in soft trade. The stock hasn't looked back after a big breakout in November over 33.25. It continues to hold above its 10-week moving average around 51.

United Rentals (URI) outperformed Monday, rising 3% in light turnover. It's been consolidating gains for just over six weeks. While trading has been somewhat erratic in recent weeks, it's only corrected about 15% off its recent high. That means tits current structure still qualifies as a flat base.

Finally, Tractor Supply (TSCO) extended gains after Friday's low-volume breakout, rising 2.5% in heavy volume. Its weekly chart might look like a late-stage breakout, but Tractor Supply reset its base count in August 2011 so it's not as late stage as it looks.Stocks ended a ho-hum session with a finish near session highs Monday. Although most IBD 50 stocks find themselves below 52-week highs, few are forming sound bases. Many stocks in today's list are still trending downward or haven't corrected enough that chart readers should view their price declines as proper bases. Others are extended from their most recent buy points and not offering good buying areas. The medical sector provides two of…

Stocks were near session lows midday Friday after another jump in oil prices offset upbeat jobs data.The NYSE composite and S&P 500 lost 0.6%, while the Nasdaq fell 0.3%. Volume was tracking lower across the board.Crude gained $1.71 to $103.62 a barrel, lifted by unrest in Libya. Earlier it topped $104.Madison Square Garden (MSG) gapped down and fell 8% after delivering disappointing results. Before the open, the company posted Q4 profit of 42 cents a share, up 35% from a year ago, but a penny below expectations. Sales rose 5% to $432.7 million, also below views.On the upside, Aruba Networks (ARUN) climbed 4% to a record high in fast trade. The stock recently regained its 10-week moving average following a failed breakout. Aruba makes products that help workers link mobile devices securely into computer networks. Earnings have surged by triple digits in the past seven quarters. Sales grew 10% to 51% over the same period.Tractor Supply (TSCO) rose 2% to an all-time high in heavy trading. The stock found support at its 50-day moving average a week ago. Tractor Supply operates farming equipment stores. Analysts see its full-year earnings rising 16%. Estimates have been raised numerous times in recent months.

The major indexes fell to new lows in early afternoon action. Disappointing earnings from Goldman Sachs (GS) continued to weigh on financials, while  Cree's (CREE) weak quarterly report remained a drag on semiconductor-related stocks.The Nasdaq composite was off 1.1%, while the NYSE composite and S&P 500 shed 0.8%. The Dow displayed the most resilience, trading just 0.1% lower. Volume was tracking mildly higher on the Nasdaq but lower on the NYSE.On the upside, farming equipment retailer Tractor Supply (TSCO) rose 1% in above-average trade. The stock appears to be rebounding off its 10-week moving average. It remains 4% off a high hit on Jan. 3. Tractor Supply boasts a respectable IBD Composite Rating of 88. Areas of concern include a lackluster ranking for its industry group: 112th out of 197. But the 16-member Retail/Wholesale-Building Products industry group also features another stock, Titan Machinery (TITN), that has a Relative Price Strength Rating of 80 or higher.Grupo Financiero Galicia (GGAL) rose 4% in big volume. The Argentine bank holding company has lately been featured on IBD's International Leaders page. It has climbed back above its 10-week line as it works on a possible new base since posting a high of 17.10 on Dec. 7. Grupo Financiero Galicia's EPS rose 127% in its latest quarter as revenue jumped 25%. But the foreign banks industry group has slipped to a ranking of 170th, down from 62nd six weeks ago.Meanwhile, China MediaExpress Holdings (CCME) added 3% in strong turnover. The provider of digital advertising for buses in China is nearing a possible buy point of 22.40 from a cup base. The correction in this base was 36%, just a little deeper than the 35% or less that you would prefer to see. Like Grupo Financiero Galicia, the stock has lately been featured on IBD's International Leaders page. It sports a best-possible Composite Rating of 99. Funds owning shares have ballooned in recent quarters to 40 funds holding 6.3 million shares as of the September quarter, or 26% of the total float.
Helped by a surge by economic news and chipmakers Tuesday, stocks logged solid gains — although volume couldn't keep up.
The Nasdaq moved up 0.7%, the S&P 500 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.2%. Volume fell 9% on the Nasdaq and 13% on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.
The Philadelphia semiconductor index shot up 2.2%.
SanDisk (SNDK) jumped 6% after Pacific Crest brokerage put an outperform rating on the chipmaker, with a target price of 47, a 40% premium over the current price.

Among IBD 50 stocks, Titan Machinery (TITN) climbed 6%, making its way back toward its 10-week moving average. The stock has closed below support at the 10-week line in light trade twice since May 16.
Web.com Group (WWWW) added 3% in weak trade. The website publishing software maker is in the fifth week of a possible flat base.
Farm goods retailer Tractor Supply (TSCO) climbed more than 2% in average trade, recouping some of Monday's 5% loss. The stock remains well below its 50-day line.
A stock that's finding support at its 50-day line is integrated circuit designer Cirrus (CRUS), which climbed 4%, putting it 3% below a 28.35 buy point in a square-box base.
On the downside, Starbucks (SBUX) dropped 3% after the coffee retailer announced Monday that it would buy Bay Bread, which owns French pastry maker La Boulange bakery.

While the Nasdaq pared some losses, stocks still traded firmly in the red in late-afternoon action Wednesday. A raft of discouraging headlines continues to weigh on sentiment.

The S&P 500 lost 1.3%, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.2%. The Nasdaq shed 1%, after trading as much as 1.6% lower. Volume was tracking down slightly from Wednesday's levels on both main exchanges.
Cirrus Logic (CRUS) slid 3% in big trade, giving up some of its gains from Wednesday's 7% pop. The chip designer is also holding above a 28.35 buy point that it cleared Wednesday.
Facebook (FB) also lost ground, slipping 2%. The stock, which began trading on the Nasdaq on May 18, has touched a new low Wednesday. The social network is about 25% below its offering price of 38.

Tractor Supply (TSCO) continued its recent sell-off, falling 3% in heavy volume and hitting a two-month low. The retailer had been consolidating above its 50-day moving average, but it's tumbled below that level this week.

Teavana (TEA) dropped 17% in heavy volume, as the specialty tea retailer reported first-quarter revenue that missed forecasts, even as revenue grew 27% to $44 million. Earnings per share rose 11% to 10 cents, matching estimates but slowing from gains of 33% and 100% in the preceding quarters. The July IPO has dropped to an all-time low.

Research In Motion (RIMM), the former stock market leader turned basket case, tumbled 7% in huge volume after the company on Tuesday predicted an operating loss for the current quarter. Wall Street had been expecting a profit. The BlackBerry smartphone maker's IBD Composite Rating is a weak 15, not far from the worst-possible grade of 1.

On the upside, Fresh Market (TFM) soared 13% in huge turnover, as the upscale grocer reported first-quarter profit rose 33% to 40 cents a share, 4 cents over views. Revenue grew 23% to $325 million, also above forecasts. The company hiked its full-year profit target. The stock cleared a 55.07 buy point from a somewhat odd-shaped square-box pattern out of the gate Thursday and is currently holding above that level.

In economic news, the National Association of Realtors reported a worse-than-expected 5.5% decrease in pending home sales for April. The consensus view was for a 0.5% gain. Even the lowball estimate for a 2% drop proved far too bullish.

Reuters reported that yields on 10-year Spanish bonds moved closer to 7%, the level at which other nations in the eurozone were forced to seek a bailout. Italian 10-year yields topped 6% for the first time since a January bond sale.

The latest poll from Greece showed a leftist party has taken the lead over the pro-bailout forces ahead of a national parliamentary election next month. China's official news agency Xinhua reported government officials were backpedaling on a large-scale stimulus.While the Nasdaq pared some losses, stocks still traded firmly in the red in late-afternoon action Wednesday. A raft of discouraging headlines continues to weigh on sentiment.The S&P 500 lost 1.3%, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.2%. The Nasdaq shed 1%, after trading as much as 1.6% lower. Volume was tracking down slightly from Wednesday's levels on both main exchanges.Cirrus Logic (CRUS) slid 3% in big trade, giving up some of its gains from Wednesday's 7% pop. The chip designer is also holding above a 28.35 buy point that it cleared Wednesday.Facebook (FB) also lost ground, slipping 2%. The stock, which began trading on the Nasdaq on May 18, has touched a new low Wednesday. The social network is about 25% below its offering price of 38.Tractor Supply (TSCO) continued its recent sell-off, falling 3% in heavy volume and hitting a two-month low. The retailer had been consolidating above its 50-day moving average, but it's tumbled below that level this week.Teavana (TEA) dropped 17% in heavy volume, as the specialty tea retailer reported first-quarter revenue that missed forecasts, even as revenue grew 27% to $44 million. Having reaped healthy profit on strong sales in the spring planting season, seeds and herbicide maker Monsanto (MON) raised its profit guidance again. Shares climbed 2.6% 76.70 in afternoon trading Wednesday, rising above their 50-day moving average a day after advancing above their 200-day line. But other farm-related stocks retreated along with the overall market. Monsanto guided per-share profit for…
Stocks rumbled higher Tuesday as volume picked up.
The Nasdaq tacked on 1.2% after being up as much as 1.6%. The S&P 500 and the NYSE composite each rose 1.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average added 1%. The small-cap S&P 600 led with a 1.4% gain.
Economic news was a mixed bag Tuesday.

On the negative side, ratings agency Egan-Jones downgraded Spain's credit rating. A regional manufacturing report from the Dallas Fed was disappointing, and the Conference Board's consumer confidence fell to 64.9 in May, below the Street's estimate of 69.7.
The upbeat news included polls showing support for the austerity plan in Greece, and signs that the big banks in China are accelerating lending.
News, though, often has already been priced in by the market. The market correction continues despite Tuesday's gains.
Blue chips advanced with 28 of 30 stocks in the Dow rising. Volume, though, was restrained for most.
The IBD 50 did better. Seven of every eight stocks rose, some in strong volume.

Cirrus Logic (CRUS) broke out of a square-box base in 75% faster trade. The chip designer rose past a 28.35 buy point. Market watchers said the move was tied to speculation that Cirrus would benefit if Apple (AAPL) proceeds with a television project. Cirrus already provides chips for iPads, iPhones and iMacs.
Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) retook its 50-day moving average as it jumped 4%. Volume was 40% above average.
Online marketplace eBay (EBAY) surged 3% in a third faster action.
On the downside, Tractor Supply (TSCO) skidded 7% in volume that was 368% above average. The stock closed under its 50-day line, which it only recently retook.

On Wednesday, the National Association of Realtors will release pending home sales for April. Stocks continued to eke out small gains late Tuesday afternoon following Monday's sharp rise, as home prices and consumer confidence dipped.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.3%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were fractionally higher.
Trade was also mixed, up about 7% on the Nasdaq and down a few clicks on the NYSE vs. action at the same time Monday.
The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index fell 0.6 point in March to 70.2, roughly in line with analysts' forecasts. The index had gained in four of the five months through February.

Meanwhile, the Case-Shiller 20-city home-price index fell 3.8% in January, in line with views. Prices had fallen 4.1% in December. Sixteen of 19 cities saw home prices fall for the month (Charlotte, N.C., was not included in the January data). Miami, Phoenix and Washington saw price gains.
Yet homebuilder stocks fared well, led by Lennar (LEN), which soared 4% after reporting that orders jumped 33% in the first quarter. Lennar holds a superior 95 Relative Price Strength Rating.

Meanwhile, Chinese online search engine Baidu (BIDU) was up more than 1%, heading for its fifth straight gain. The stock is 7% past a 142.59 cup-with-handle buy point. It's still 7% below a 165.96 all-time high.

Among IBD 50 stocks, Apple (AAPL) continued its strong run, climbing more than 1% to another record high. It's extended 44% beyond a 427.85 buy point. The stock has an Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A and an up/down volume ratio of 2.1, indicating strong demand for the shares.
Farm supply retailer Tractor Supply (TSCO) also rose 1% to another new high following Monday's 6% gain. The stock is now extended past a 82.60 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.

On the downside, motion control and sensing chipmaker InvenSense (INVN) lost 4% in heavy volume. It's extended beyond a buying range following a strong bounce off its 50-day line. InvenSense has a 98 IBD Composite Rating, putting it at the top of its industry group.

Dollar General (DG) lost 2% in more than double its average daily volume. The discount retailer is still extended after rebounding off its 50-day line. It's gained as much as 13% since breaking out of a flat base at 42.20 in late January.

The stock has a 98 Composite Rating and a 97 Earnings Per Share Rating, putting it at the top of the Retail-Discount & Variety group. Dollar General's earnings growth has accelerated for three straight quarters, rising a healthy 38% in the latest period. But profit growth is seen slowing to 23% in the current quarter.
Elsewhere, France-based oil producer Total (TOT) slumped 7% to its 200-day line following a gas leak beneath one of its North Sea production rigs.
Walgreen (WAG) settled to a 1% gain after gapping up 3% in initial trade. The stock is having trouble trying to climb above its falling 200-day moving average line.

The drugstore chain reported fourth-quarter revenue of 78 cents per share, down 5% vs. a year ago but a penny above analyst consensus views. Revenue edged up 1% to a better-than-expected $18.65 billion. Prescription sales, which were 61% of revenue, slipped 1.7%. The company reported 700,000 new enrollees in its Prescription Savings Plan and said cost reduction efforts would be weighted toward the second half of the year. Walgreen shares gained more than 2% Monday. But its RS Rating is a 15.Stocks continued to eke out small gains late Tuesday afternoon following Monday's sharp rise, as home prices and consumer confidence dipped.The Nasdaq climbed 0.3%. While much of the U.S. and global economy face chronic challenges, domestic agriculture remains a bright spot. Net farm income is forecast to climb 28% for 2011, according to the Department of Agriculture, topping the $100 billion mark for the first time. That puts farm and ranch store retail chain Tractor Supply Co. (TSCO) in a sweet spot. The building,…
A few stocks in the Top 10 showed notable action Wednesday.

Robotics surgery company Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) continues to keep basically all of its gains after clearing a 402.45 buy point in a cup-with-handle base Oct. 19. Strong quarterly results ignited the action. Earnings rose 43% vs. the Street's estimate for 29% growth. Revenue jumped 30%, the best in five quarters.
Volume was 217% above average on the breakout. Thanks to the undercut of the previous base, the base count is first-stage. Intuitive is now a4.5% above the buy point.
The medical sector could use some improvement — No. 16 of 33 sectors, as of Tuesday's IBD — but Intuitive's Medical-Systems/Equipment industry group was No. 6 of 197 industry groups in Tuesday's IBD.
Intuitive's base itself showed net accumulation before the breakout, which is a good sign.
Intuitive's profile looks strong. But to gain steam, the general market is going to have to step up.

Meanwhile, Hansen Natural (HANS) showed more ugly action Wednesday. It fell further under its 50-day moving average in strong volume, after diving 8% on Tuesday. The trip to the 50-day area was its third since breaking out in strong volume on Aug. 23, the follow-through day. From that breakout, Hansen advanced as much as 15% before turning south and eventually triggering the 8% sell rule.

Also notable Wednesday: Herbalife (HLF) tried to clear a possible handle buy point at 58.10 but drew weak turnover and finished under that level. And Dollar Tree (DLTR) has dropped back near its recent three-weeks-tight buy point.

On the IBD 50, farm store chain Tractor Supply (TSCO) broke out Oct. 20. The stock motored past a 70.20 buy point in a first-stage, cup-with-handle base. Volume was up 312%. It too received a spark from quarterly earnings. EPS jumped 45%, topping the Street's views easily. On Wednesday, the stock tested that buy point but found support.
Another breakout came in a delayed fashion.
Biogen Idec (BIIB) cleared a 102.11 potential buy point on Oct. 14, but volume was only average. A week later, the biotech surged more than 6% in double volume.

However, the handle is low in the base. The major indexes advanced and closed near their highs for the session Thursday, shaking off a surprise jump in applications for unemployment benefits.

The Nasdaq composite tacked on 0.6%, while the NYSE composite and S&P 500 both gained 0.2%. Volume was down across the board from Wednesday's levels, according to preliminary data.

After the bell, Amazon.com (AMZN) fell sharply in the wake of its Q4 earnings report. The e-commerce giant posted EPS of 91 cents, beating views by 3 cents. But revenue came in at $12.95 billion, below forecasts for $12.98 billion. Amazon sees Q1 sales of $9.1 billion to $9.9 billion, the midpoint above estimates. In the regular session, the stock gained 5% in hurried trade.
Thursday's top-performing groups were Leisure-Movies & Related, which was powered by Netflix's (NFLX) 15% surge, and Building-Hand Tools, lifted by Stanley Black & Decker's (SWK) 8.5% pop.
Netflix and Tractor Supply (TSCO), both top-rated stocks, were among the day's big winners. Stanley Black & Decker has earned some lackluster IBD ratings.
Netflix cleared a 209.34 buy point from a later-stage base in big turnover. It finished just 1% past that level.
Meanwhile, Tractor Supply has staged a rebound off its 10-week moving average. The stock, which jumped 9% on Thursday, is now well extended from a proper buy range.
The economic data expected Friday include reports on GDP and consumer sentiment. In addition, coal producer Alliance Resource Partners (ARLP) is slated to release its quarterly earnings.

The Nasdaq composite tacked on 0.6%, while the NYSE composite and S&P 500 both gained 0.2%. Volume was down across the board from Wednesday's levels, according to preliminary data.

After the bell, Amazon.com (AMZN) fell sharply in the wake of its Q4 earnings report. The e-commerce giant posted EPS of 91 cents, beating views by 3 cents. But revenue came in at $12.95 billion, below forecasts for $12.98 billion. Amazon sees Q1 sales of $9.1 billion to $9.9 billion, the midpoint above estimates. In the regular session, the stock gained 5% in hurried trade.
Thursday's top-performing groups were Leisure-Movies & Related, which was powered by Netflix's (NFLX) 15% surge, and Building-Hand Tools, lifted by Stanley Black & Decker's (SWK) 8.5% pop.
Netflix and Tractor Supply (TSCO), both top-rated stocks, were among the day's big winners. Stanley Black & Decker has earned some lackluster IBD ratings.
Netflix cleared a 209.34 buy point from a later-stage base in big turnover. It finished just 1% past that level.
Meanwhile, Tractor Supply has staged a rebound off its 10-week moving average. The stock, which jumped 9% on Thursday, is now well extended from a proper buy range.

The economic data expected Friday include reports on GDP and consumer sentiment. In addition, coal producer Alliance Resource Partners (ARLP) is slated to release its quarterly earnings.The Nasdaq composite tacked on 0.6%, while the NYSE composite and S&P 500 both gained 0.2%. Stocks futures took a turn for the worse and pointed to a mixed open following a round of disappointing economic data. Nasdaq 100 futures rose 6 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures slipped 1 point and Dow futures rose 2 points.On the economic front, last week's initial jobless claims climbed by 52,000 to a much higher-than-expected 454,000. Economists had expected 410,000 claim. Bad weather and a backlog in the processing of claims were reasons for the spikeMeanwhile, orders for durable goods unexpectedly tumbled 2.5% in December vs. expectations for a 1.5% gain. Excluding transportation, orders rose 0.5%, a tad below estimates.Data on December pending home sales will be released at 10 a.m. EST. Economists expect a 0.5% decline.In corporate news, Netflix (NFLX) bolted 13% in pre-open trading after it reported stellar earnings and a rosy outlook late Wednesday. Thursday morning, Morgan Keegan upgraded Netflix shares to market perform from underperform. Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and ThinkEquity also upgraded the stock.Chip equipment maker Teradyne (TER) surged 11% in pre-market trading after it smashed views late Wednesday. The company said its Q4 earnings more than doubled from the previous year to 37 cents a share, beating views by 12 cents. That also marked its second straight quarter of triple-digit growth. Sales climbed 22% to $322.17 million, also above expectations. Looking ahead, Teradyne expects Q1 profit in a range of 33 cents to 39 cents a share, well ahead of views for 19 cents.Fellow chip gear makers KLA-Tencor (KLAC) and Varian Semiconductor Equipment Associates (VSEA) are due to report after the close.Late Wednesday, Tractor Supply (TSCO) topped views with a 29% gain in Q4 earnings and a 20% gain in sales. The farming equipment retailer guided full-year profit between $2.54 and $2.62 a share vs. views of $2.52 a share. Revenue is pegged at $4 billion to $4.07 billion vs. estimates of $3.95 billion. Shares were indicated higher.Companies due to report earnings after the close include  Amazon.com (AMZN), Ariba (ARBA), Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR), Microsemi (MSCC), Microsoft (MSFT), Riverbed Technology (RVBD) and SanDisk (SNDK).

Fastenal's  (FAST) first quarter earnings per share rose 26% to 34 cents a share, but that missed forecasts by a penny as higher fuel costs offset other good news. The highly rated industrial supplies distributor's revenue climbed 20% to $768.9 million, just barely above forecasts. Sales at stores open at least two years rose 16.8% in March vs. a…

Fastenal (FAST) retreated Tuesday after William Blair downgraded the nuts, bolts and tool seller to market perform from outperform, citing valuation concerns and recent insider selling. Shares, which have been climbing for months and are trading near all-time highs, closed down 2.3% Tuesday at 53.37. "Although Fastenal should continue to generate strong earnings growth, we believe high expectations are already…
Stocks were struggling to eke out gains early Tuesday afternoon following Monday's sharp gains, as home prices and consumer confidence dipped.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.2%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were little changed.
Trade was also mixed, up about 8% on the Nasdaq and down a few clicks on the NYSE vs. action at the same time Monday.
The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index fell 0.6 point in March to 70.2, roughly in line with analysts' forecasts. The index had gained in four of the five months through February.

Meanwhile, the Case-Shiller 20-city home-price index fell 3.8% in January, in line with views. Prices had fallen 4.1% in December. Sixteen of 19 cities saw home prices fall for the month (Charlotte, N.C., was not included in the January data). Miami, Phoenix and Washington saw price gains.
Yet homebuilder stocks fared well, led by Lennar (LEN), which soared 5% after reporting that orders jumped 33% in the first quarter.

Meanwhile, Chinese online search engine Baidu (BIDU) was up 1% in heavy volume, heading for its fifth straight gain. The stock is 7% past a 142.59 cup-with-handle buy point. It's still 8% below a 165.96 all-time high above 600.

Among IBD 50 stocks, farm supply retailer Tractor Supply (TSCO) rose 1% to another new high following Monday's 6% gain. The stock is now extended past a 82.60 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.

Apple (AAPL) also continued its strong run, climbing 1% to another record high. It's extended 43% beyond a 427.85 buy point. The stock has an Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A and an up/down volume ratio of 2.1, indicating strong demand for the shares.

On the downside, motion control and sensing chipmaker InvenSense (INVN) lost 4% in heavy volume. It's extended beyond a buying range following a strong bounce off its 50-day line. InvenSense has a 98 IBD Composite Rating, putting it at the top of its industry group.
Dollar General (DG) lost 2%, also in strong volume. The discount retailer is also extended after rebounding off its 50-day line.
Elsewhere, France-based oil producer Total (TOT) slumped 6% to its 200-day line after a gas leak beneath one of its North Sea production rigs forced further evacuations.
Walgreen (WAG) settled to a 1% gain after gapping up 3% in initial trade. The stock is having trouble trying to climb above its falling 200-day moving average line.

The drugstore chain reported fourth-quarter revenue of 78 cents per share, down 5% vs. a year ago but a penny above analyst consensus views. Revenue edged up 1% to a better-than-expected $18.65 billion. Prescription sales, which were 61% of revenue, slipped 1.7%. The company reported 700,000 new enrollees in its Prescription Savings Plan and said cost reduction efforts would be weighted toward the second half of the year. Walgreen shares gained more than 2% Monday. But its RS Rating is a 15.Stocks were struggling to eke out gains early Tuesday afternoon following Monday's sharp gains, as home prices and consumer confidence dipped.The Nasdaq climbed 0.2%. The Retail/Wholesale Building Products group has been living in the market's penthouse.

It has been driven by names like Fastenal (FAST). The maker of supplies ranging from fasteners to nuts, bolts and studs is up 47% since Sept. 30, though extended from its most recent buy point. Fourth-quarter earnings per share and sales beat estimates, with growth accelerating.
The number of mutual funds owning a piece of Fastenal grew to 812 as of Dec. 31 from 788 at the end of the third quarter.
The $77 billion Fidelity Contrafund began a stake as of its latest disclosure.
The category is currently No. 10 among IBD's 197 industry groups. It's been in the top 20 for 13 weeks, often in the top 10.
And it's done this despite a still-shaky housing market.

Some of its performance is due to relative strength in nonresidential construction, says Michael Jaffe, analyst for S&P Capital IQ. Part of the group's mojo stems from recent modest gains in residential housing.

"Even slight increases in existing home sales have apparently triggered more renovations," Jaffe said. "That's reflected in increased sales of everything from paint to kitchen cabinets and bathroom faucets and hardware."
Existing-home sales rose to 4.61 million in December. That was up 3.6% from 4.45 million a year earlier, according to the National Association of Realtors.
Nuts 'N' Bolts
Fastenal is a beneficiary. It had record sales and earnings last year.
In January, despite tough comps with 2011, sales rose 21% from the year earlier period.
W.W. Grainger (GWW) is up 35% since the end of Q3. It set an all-time high of 204.62 on Jan. 24.
The distributor of tools, lighting, plumbing and other maintenance products' Q4 EPS growth beat analysts' consensus estimates. Its 2012 EPS target is somewhat light.
Another leader in this space is MSC Industrial (MSM). The MRO supplies distributor is up 38% since the third quarter.
Return on equity has grown two years in a row. But EPS growth has slowed for three quarters in a row.
The stock is just shy of its all-time high.
The group has even benefited from foreclosures, says S&P analyst Michael Souers. Those lead to low-cost fix-ups. Paint maker Sherwin Williams (SHW) is up 33% since the third quarter.
Jaffe sees no near-term slowdown in the sector's improving fundamentals.
"This industry was so beaten down for five years, that even with their recent gains many of these companies are still trading way below their historical highs," he said.

Jaffe also likes some of the group's kissing cousins. He has a strong buy recommendation on Manitowoc (MTW). The manufacturer of lifting equipment has an IBD Composite Rating of 85. Its SMR Rating is a modest D.
Souers cautions that at least one group leader's strength has little to do with commercial or residential construction.

Tractor Supply (TSCO) sells livestock feed and other farm products. "You can like that name without liking building products," he said.The Retail/Wholesale Building Products group has been living in the market's penthouse.It has been driven by names like Fastenal (FAST). Stocks were again mixed near Wednesday's halftime following a round of mixed earnings reports and surges in housing starts and building permits. The S&P 500 rose 0.3% and the Nasdaq gained 0.2%. But the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.1% due to losses in IBM (IBM) and Intel (INTC). Turnover was tracking higher on the Nasdaq and lower on the…

Stocks tumbled out of the gate Monday in reaction to S&P's downgrade of the nation's credit rating. The Nasdaq was down 3.4%. The S&P 500 slid 3.2% and remained at a session low, and the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 2.6%. Volume was tracking higher across the board, especially on the Nasdaq. Decliners swamped advancers by more than 10-to-1 on…
Stocks held near session highs Thursday afternoon amid reports of a possible delay of military action in Syria and better-than-expected data on economic growth.

The Nasdaq jumped 1.1% and regained the 3600 level. Bellwethers Apple (AAPL), Google (GOOG) and Priceline.com (PCLN) helped the Nasdaq outperform. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.6% and 0.5% respectively. Volume was mixed in the stock market today. Nasdaq trade was running a touch higher, but NYSE trade was tracking lower.

3D Systems (DDD) rallied 6% in hefty trade, putting it back above a 51.55 early buy point from a late-stage consolidation. On Monday, Citigroup started coverage of 3D Systems and rival Stratasys (SSYS) with buy ratings. Stratasys shares climbed 4%.

Tractor Supply (TSCO) rose 3% to a record high in fast trade. The stock cleared a 124.55 buy point from a flat base. Tractor Supply announced a 2-for-1 stock split, its fourth such split since 2002. The farming and ranch equipment retailer has delivered accelerating profit growth in recent quarters.

The Fresh Market (TFM) was off its session low, but still down 10% in heavy trading. Shares of the high-end grocer gapped down Thursday in reaction to late Wednesday's disappointing Q2 sales The stock appeared to be finding support near its 200-day moving average.

The stock market today leaned toward a positive open, with Europe's markets trading higher and drug makers dominating most of the early action.
Dow futures were up 74 points. S&P 500 futures were 7.5 points higher and Nasdaq 100 futures were ahead 20.5 points. All were on the uptick.

In stocks, Onyx Pharmaceuticals (ONXX) rocketed higher after confirming it had rejected a $120 per share takeover bid from Amgen (AMGN). Onyx's board said the offer undervalued the company. A Monday analyst report from Lazard Capital estimated the deal could occur in the $130 to $140 per share range.
Amgen shares rose a fraction.
Qihoo 360 Technologies (QIHU) traded up 8% ahead of the opening bell. Qihoo ended Friday in a strong-volume rebound from 10-week support.
Drug makers were once again leading the IBD 50 list in premarket trade. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) and Biogen Idec (BIIB) were each ahead 2%.

Biogen rebounded 8% last week, after a three-week pullback, to end not quite even with its 10-week moving average. Regeneron rebounded 4%, but remained below its 10-week level and deeper in a seven-week consolidation.
On the downside, Tractor Supply (TSCO) dropped 3% prior to the open. The stock ended Friday just below a new high and 1% above a 116.06 buy point in a flat base.

Overseas, Europe's markets scratched out modest gains at midday. In China, the Shanghai Composite posted a modest gain. Hong Kong's exchange was closed for a one-day holiday. In Japan, the Nikkei 225 jumped 1.3%, adding to last week's 3.4% advance.
The euro rose faster than the dollar, the dollar gained vs. the yen. Oil chugged ahead 1% to hover near the $97-per-barrel mark. Gold firmed to $1,238 an ounce.

The Purchasing Managers Index is due out just before 9 a.m. ET. Dealers didn't ramp up inventory in early 2013 as they typically do, signaling weaker spring and summer sales for Caterpillar. The world's largest heavy equipment maker lowered its full-year outlook after first-quarter earnings and sales fell more than expected, largely on falling demand for mining equipment. But Caterpillar (CAT) said the U.S. housing market remains a bright spot. And it…
Stocks were again mostly flat and struggling for direction near Tuesday's halftime.
The Dow Jones industrial and the S&P 500 were each up a fraction, while the Nasdaq lost a fraction. Nasdaq volume was tracking lower in the stock market today. NYSE trade was running higher.

Natural Grocers by Vitamin Cottage (NGVC) ramped up an additional 4% after an 8% gain Monday. The stock hit a six-month high. The July IPO blew past a 23.38 buy point from a cup-with-handle base within a larger pattern Monday. It's now 5% past that entry. But Natural Grocers is a thin stock.
The organic grocer's earnings surged by triple digits in three of the past four quarters. Analysts see profit rising 63% to 49 cents this year.

Air Lease (AL) cruised up nearly 5% at the open, but has since turned flat. The stock has pulled back to support at its 50-day line recently. Air Lease broke out from a long saucer pattern in February. It's still 6% past a 26.57 buy point.

Tractor Supply (TSCO) reversed from a brand-new high and fell 2%. The stock erased all of Monday's work, but remains about 1% past 105.47 buy point from a flat base. Tractor Supply broke out Friday, but big volume didn't come in until Monday. The Brentwood, Tenn.-based firm runs a chain of farm and ranch stores. Its earnings have nearly quadrupled since falling in 2008.

Meritage Homes (MTH) gave up small opening gains and lost 2%. The stock fell back to its 50-day moving average, which has provided support in recent sessions. Stocks pulled higher in solid trade as the morning's second wave of economic data was encouraging, and more details of the euro zone's Greek debt rescue plans materialized.The NYSE composite led with a 1.4% gain. The S&P 500 rose 1.2%, and the Nasdaq 0.9%. Volume rose modestly on the NYSE and was sharply higher on the Nasdaq compared with the same time yesterday.Manufacturing in the mid-Atlantic region picked up in July, hoisting the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's manufacturing index 3.2%, vs. a 7.7% decline in June.The Consumer Board's leading indicators index gained 0.3% for June, above May's downwardly revised 0.2% number and in line with expectations.The Federal Housing Finance Administration's Housing price index rose 0.4% for May, down from April's 0.8% increase.Wednesday's top performing sector, financials, got an early boost from Morgan Stanley  (MS), which jumped 5% in early trading. The bank holding company reported a loss of 38 cent a share, better than the 64 cent loss analysts expected. Revenue was up 17% to $9.28 billion, above expectations for $8.04 billion.Leading stocks faced pressure for a second straight day, but several took healthy gains. One example, Catalyst Health Solutions (CHSI) popped 5% in a sympathy move following Express Scripts' (ESRX) announced $29.1 billion acquisition of Medco Health Services  (MHS). Catalyst is near a 66.07 buy point in a 10-week cup without handle.On the downside, Tractor Supply (TSCO) plowed a 7% rut. The company topped second-quarter earnings estimates but revenue came up just a shade short of expectations, and the company offered full-year revenue guidance near the low end of expectations.Tractor Supply has given up most gains since breaking out of a flat base past a 65.10 buy point.F5 Networks (FFIV) dropped 8% in massive trading. The maker of optimization software for applications delivered over networks reported late Wednesday Q2 earnings that topped forecasts, but revenue fell just shy of views. The stock has been consolidating since January.

Stocks tried to rally in afternoon trade Monday as they cut some of the day's sharp losses.The Nasdaq was down 1.2%, the S&P 500 1.4% while the NYSE composite fell 1.5%. Small caps and midcaps were down more as the S&P 600 and the S&P 400 skidded 1.8%. Volume was up about 1% on the Nasdaq and down about 4% on the NYSE, suggesting that institutional investors were selling selectively but not pushing the panic button.Among top-rated stocks, losers moving in fast trade dominated winners moving in fast trade.Construction and mining equipment maker Caterpillar (CAT) dived 4% in heavy volume. The stock sliced through its 50-day line. Caterpillar's last five new highs made en route to a peak on April 4 were all made in below-average volume. Since then, it's corrected about 9% with three declines coming in above-average volume. That picture points to distribution.In most cases, though, the chart action of top-rated stocks didn't look especially dangerous.Mining equipment maker Joy Global (JOYG) cut under its 50-day line as it shed 4%. But volume was below normal. The stock is 10% off its 52-week high.Silver Wheaton (SLW) dropped 3% in nearly double its average volume. But the stock was finding support at its 50-day moving average.Tractor Supply (TSCO) slid 3% in 39% heavier volume, but the farm store chain stock remains well above its 50-day line. Tractor Supply will report quarterly results Wednesday. The Street expects earnings to rise 23% and revenue 12% on a year-ago basis. The company has topped analysts' estimates for nine consecutive quarters.Other top-rated stocks — such as Priceline.com (PCLN), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Stericycle (SRCL) and somewhat thinly traded iRobot (IRBT) — fell in below-average volume. The stocks were not undercutting recent lows, which gave their action a sideways look.
As the market found its footing after a sharp two-week slide, a few issues within the IBD 50 showed some muscle.
The Nasdaq rebounded 3.8% last week while the NYSE composite gained 2.5%. Both indexes recouped more than half of their recent losses.

Since March 8, IBD's Big Picture has noted a correction taking place after rosy gains that began in September. This means most stocks — even the leaders — are coming quickly off their highs and forming new bases.
Yet a handful of names in the IBD 50 are acting like overachievers.
Software developers thrived during a week in which Oracle (ORCL) impressed investors with solid EPS and revenue growth in the February-ended quarter.

Informatica (INFA), which excels in the data storage management niche, was one of last week's star outperformers. It ran up 9% for the week and notched new highs as it cleared a 49.86 buy point in a five-week flat base.

Data management expert Open Text (OTEX) rallied 5% last week to end at the top of a fresh seven-week flat base in which the stock declined just 10%. Volume was thin, though. In January, the stock cleared a 47.86 buy point and gained 24%.
Some consumer-oriented names advanced sharply. Restaurant reservation system provider OpenTable (OPEN) cleared a relatively deep square box with a 96.07 buy point.

Tractor Supply (TSCO) edged to new highs in mild volume. Over the prior 11 weeks, the retailer formed an ascending-base-like pattern. But in the third pullback, the decline was just shy of 10%. Travelzoo (TZOO) zoomed past a 53.21 buy point in an unusual cup-without-handle base. Though V-shaped, the base also features a bullish reversal at the bottoming week.
Netflix (NFLX) continued work on a base that's forming on top of an eight-week cup. The late-stage base carries more risk than a first- or second-stage pattern.

Silver Wheaton (SLW) suffered a big two-week hiccup before last week's rebound. A cup with no handle gave investors a 42.44 buy point. But the stock whipsawed recent buyers and triggered the 8% rule forcing investors to exit the stock. Shares jumped 10% last week to land back above the recent 39.04 buy point.As the market found its footing after a sharp two-week slide, a few issues within the IBD 50 showed some muscle.The Nasdaq rebounded 3.8% last week while the NYSE composite gained 2.5%. The NYSE composite fell 0.5% and the S&P 500 0.2%. But the tech-heavy Nasdaq climbed 0.3%. The Philadelphia semiconductor index shot up 1.8%.

While tech stocks fared well, builders shined even brighter. That long-suffering group was lifted by stocks such as Toll Bros. (TOL), Meritage Homes (MTH) and Hovnanian Enterprises (HOV), each of which surged 5% or 6%.
Ancestry.com (ACOM), which broke out Wednesday with a 10% surge, added 2% on Thursday. Chip designer MIPS Technology (MIPS), which leapt 3% Wednesday, rose 4% Thursday.
The retail sector continued to show some weakness.
Tractor Supply (TSCO) fell 2% in almost three times its usual trade. But the stock had sunk as much as 5% before clawing back a good bit.

On the economic calendar, Friday morning (before the open) will see the release of the monthly nonfarm payrolls report, a figure that often sparks volatile trading. The consensus estimate is running at a rise of 140,000 jobs. Data on consumer credit will be released later in the day.

Stocks waltzed higher in mixed volume Thursday, despite some discouraging economic news. Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video! The Nasdaq rose 0.6%, while the S&P 500 and the NYSE composite each added 0.2%. Volume was about 15% lower on the NYSE but slightly higher on the Nasdaq. Trade…

Stocks hovered near session highs in early afternoon trading Tuesday. They had surged from the open as worries over Ireland's debt situation eased. Better-than-expected U.S. economic data also boosted sentiment.The Nasdaq rallied 2%, the NYSE composite 1.9%, the Dow 1.6%. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 gained 1.8% to just below the 1200 level. Volume was again tracking higher across the board, especially on the NYSE.Aruba Networks (ARUN) gapped up and surged 8% in fast trade. Late Thursday, the network software maker beat views with a 200% surge in fiscal Q1 earnings. That was its sixth straight quarter of triple-digit profit growth. Sales grew 44%, also above views.Citing increasing use of tablet computers and smart phones, Aruba pegged fiscal Q2 revenue between $86 million and $88 million vs. views for $84.7 million. The stock found support at its 50-day moving average Tuesday and Wednesday. Aruba cleared an 18.51 buy point from a square-box base Aug. 27.Salesforce.com (CRM) gapped above its 50-day line and gained 5% ahead of its Q3 results after the close. Analysts see the cloud-computing firm's earnings jumping 94% to 31 cents a share. Sales are slated to rise 24% to $410.5 million. The stock is in a cup-with-handle base.Spreadtrum (SPRD) turned fractionally higher after finding support near its 50-day moving average. The stock was down nearly 11% early despite the Chinese chip designer's report of triple-digit Q3 gains in earnings and sales. Spreadtrum cleared a four-week consolidation in late October. The pattern corrected just over 19%, too much for a square-box base, which corrects 10% to 15%.On the downside, Humana (HUM) trimmed an earlier 6% loss to 3% after finding support near its 50-day moving average. Citing "near-term challenges", the health insurer guided full-year 2011 earnings between $5.35 and $5.55 a share vs. views for $6.03 a share.
Distributors Fastenal (FAST) and MSC Industrial Direct (MSM) reported quarterly earnings early Wednesday that reflected weaker industrial activity in the first half of the year.

Construction supplies distributor Fastenal said second-quarter revenue grew 5% to $847.6 million, missing Wall Street's $857.1 million target. Sales at stores open more than two years grew about 3.6% in the quarter.
After reporting double-digit sales gains 10 straight quarters, Fastenal's overall sales growth has dipped to the single-digit level for the last four quarters.
Earnings per share rose 8% to 41 cents, meeting analyst estimates.
MSC Industrial's fiscal Q3 EPS fell 4.5% to $1.05, beating consensus of 11 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for 97 cents.
Revenue hiked 4% to $636.9 million, just above estimates for $635.2 million.
Fastenal shares fell 1.6% in morning trading on the stock market today. MSC Industrial was down about 0.3%.
Elsewhere in the Retail/Wholesale Building Products group, sales leader W.W. Grainger (GWW), which distributes tools, plumbing supplies and other maintenance products, slid 0.5%.

Elsewhere in the group, which is ranked a respectable 62 on IBD's list of 197 industries, flooring store chain Lumber Liquidators (LL) skidded 2.7% and Tractor Supply (TSCO), which operates about 1,200 farming equipment stores nationally, rose 1.2%.
No. 1 home and business supplies retail chain Home Depot (HD) fell 0.8% and archrival Lowe's (LOW) was down about 1%.
Amazon.com (AMZN), which has ramped up online sales of fasteners and other components for industries and homebuilders in recent years, edged down 0.2%.

Fastenal noted it's had several major slowdowns the past couple of years, including a slump after Superstorm Sandy devastated the East Coast at the end of October, and another this spring amid softness in manufacturing and housing.
"The construction piece in 2013 was also hampered by poor weather during the winter and spring time frame throughout many areas in North America," the company said in a statement.
During Q2 Fastenal opened 33 stores, bringing its total to 2,677 at the end of June.

MSC Industrial CEO Erik Gershwind, commenting on the economic outlook in a statement, said "We continue to fuel share gains in our targeted markets despite a sluggish manufacturing sector, particularly in metalworking-related end markets."

The company expects fiscal Q4 EPS of 87 cents to 91 cents, well below analyst consensus for $1.01 per share.Distributors Fastenal (FAST) and MSC Industrial Direct (MSM) reported quarterly earnings early Wednesday that reflected weaker industrial activity in the first half of the year.Construction supplies distributor Fastenal said second-quarter revenue grew 5% to $847.6 million, missing Wall Street's $857.1 million target. Stocks jumped in powerful trade Tuesday in spite of disappointing home price and consumer confidence data. The Nasdaq led with a 1.1% advance. The Dow pushed up 1% and the S&P 500 showed a 0.6% gain. Volume was more than 20% higher on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq compared with the same time Friday. Caterpillar (CAT) led the Dow…

The American consumer is back and willing to spend. With China slowing and Europe still in turmoil, the IBD 50 list of top-notch stocks is filled with retailers and other consumer-related companies. This week, five IBD 50 retailers — all U.S.-focused — report earnings results. (Also check out the IBD 50's 6 tech and biotech earnings this week.) Tuesday, April…
Stocks gave up early gains, wavered and finally closed modestly lower Wednesday amid more earnings reports, upbeat housing data and Fed speak.
The S&P 500 and Nasdaq each fell 0.3%. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.2%. NYSE volume fell from Tuesday's level, but Nasdaq trade rose, according to early data.

After the close, Akamai Technologies (AKAM) gained 5% after reporting Q3 earnings and sales above expectations. Cheesecake Factory (CAKE) was also higher in extended trading despite reporting mixed results. Earnings matched views, but sales missed.

Earlier Wednesday, big caps Boeing (BA) and AT&T (T) delivered quarterly earnings that beat expectations. New-home sales jumped to a 2-1/2-year high in September. And the Federal Reserve kept interest rates steady and sees the economy growing moderately.

Tractor Supply (TSCO) was essentially unchanged after it reported better-than-expected earnings and sales that matched estimates. The company also lifted its full-year profit outlook, but that was shy of expectations.

Nationstar Mortgage (NSM) fell as much as 21% intraday, but pared its loss to 10% and closed above its 50-day line. The mortgage servicer lost out on an auction for a unit of the bankrupt Residential Capital. Ocwen Financial (OCN) and Walter Investment Management Corp. won with a $3 billion bid. Wednesday marked Nationstar's busiest volume since its March 8 debut.

Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) tumbled 4% in massive trade despite easily beating Wall Street's Q3 profit expectations on strong sales of its lone drug, Soliris, which is used to treat rare blood diseases. The firm reported earnings of 60 cents a share, up 62% from a year ago. Sales jumped 44% to $294.1 million. Views were for 47 cents on revenue of $293.2 million. Alexion also raised its full-year outlook Wednesday.
The stock fell for the fifth straight session Wednesday and breached its 200-day line. It slumped more than 8% below its most recent buy point at 110.06 earlier this week.

Lumber Liquidators (LL) gapped up and bolted 11% gain in more than four times average trade. Before the open, the flooring retailer delivered Q3 earnings that leapt 77% to 46 cents a share, trouncing analysts' consensus estimate of 34 cents. Revenue also bounded past forecasts with a 19% gain. The company lifted full-year sales and earnings guidance. Lumber Liquidators gapped above a 54.10 buy point from a five-week flat base.

PolyOne (POL) gapped up and rallied 9% after a mixed Q3 earnings report. The maker of plastics, resins and additives reported a profit of 33 cents a share, up 27% from a year earlier. It beat views by 2 cents. Revenue edged up about 1% to $740.2 million vs. views of $793.14 million.
The company also said it had agreed to pay $246 million to acquire peer Spartech (SEH). PolyOne expects the deal to close in the first quarter. Spartech shares jolted 60% higher on the news.
The stock opened above a 17.63 buy point from a five-week flat base.

Amazon.com (AMZN), Apple (AAPL), Biogen Idec (BIIB), Celgene (CELG), NetSuite (N), SolarWinds (SWI) and Under Armour (UA) are among some notable companies reporting earnings Thursday.
