Stocks remained near intraday lows Wednesday afternoon as a fresh drop in oil prices fanned concerns about global economic growth.
The Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.8%, the S&P 500 0.7% and the Nasdaq 0.6%. Volume on the NYSE and the Nasdaq was running well below Tuesday's levels in the stock market today.

Oil prices sank 5%, dragging down energy stocks, as the Organization for Petroleum Exporting Countries pared its 2015 oil demand forecast to the lowest level since 2012. Exxon Mobil (XOM) and and Chevron (CVX) each lost 3%.

Yum Brands (YUM), the owner of Taco Bell, Pizza Hut and KFC, dropped 5% and sliced through its 50-day and 200-day moving averages in heavy volume after lowering its profit outlook for the year on weaker-than-expected sales in China.

Fellow fast-food retailerBurger King Worldwide (BKW) fared better, reversing higher and rising more than 2% after RBC Capital Markets upgraded the stock to outperform from sector perform. RBC raised its price target on the stock to 38 from 30 on expectations that Burger King's takeover of Canadian coffee and doughnut chain Tim Hortons will yield cost savings.

Burger King rebounded off support at its 50-day line and was trying to retake a 33.44 buy point of a cup-with-handle base. Volume was heavy, but the latest base was a late-stage structure, which makes it riskier than those that form earlier in a stock's run.

Meanwhile, warehouse club operator Costco (COST) slipped 1% despite reporting better-than-expected quarterly profit. If applying for certain retail jobs at Tractor Supply (TSCO), you'd better come with plenty of equine know-how and a green thumb.
It pays to know the meaning of words like tack (leather products for horses) or hard keepers (horses that lose weight easily).
Hiring people with special skills in horses or farming has become a staple and revenue booster at Tractor Supply, the biggest rural retailer in the U.S., with 976 stores in 44 states.

Many players talk about knowing customers. But analysts say one sure way to reach them involves hiring the right employee who understands a client's concerns. Companies that recruit staff with specific know-how can enhance profitability. At the same time, experts say identifying the right job candidate can be tricky.
Tractor Supply, whose revenue rose to $3.2 billion in 2009 and is on track to hit $3.5 billion in 2010, believes that specialized workers are a competitive edge.
Staffers are recruited with expertise in four areas: farming, ranching, horses and welding. Why welding? If they know welding, odds are that they've mastered nearly everything else in home repair.
Hiring Horse Sense

James Wright, CEO of Brentwood, Tenn.-based Tractor Supply, says creating a reservoir of staff knowledge helps retain both customers and employees. "Only with longevity of staff can we build deep category expertise," he said.

Since many customers own horses, staffers with four-legged expertise can offer advice on horse training, nutrition and care, and speak the "horse language," Wright says. The staffers, called team members at Tractor Supply, build rapport, develop close ties with customers and close a sale, which leads to return customers.

In addition to technical smarts, Tractor Supply also seeks staffers with an upbeat attitude. "We seek someone with a bounce in their step, who's gregarious, positive and not grumpy," Wright said. Indeed, when customers enter a store, staffers greet them with an upbeat hello and a smile.

Wright describes the company's recruiting philosophy as "hiring hard and managing easy." Hence, hiring includes tough job descriptions and extensive interviewing. But once on board, staffers receive incentives for boosting sales and recognition for outstanding performance.

Employee turnover used to be a problem. But over the last 10 years, the upbeat employee retention approach has cut turnover in the retail staff from 100% to 35% annually. On the store manager side, it's fallen from 43% to 15%.

A stable staff helps to fuel store expansions. The company plans to open 75 to 80 stores in 2011, an 8% jump from the prior year. Robert W. Baird & Co. senior retail analyst Peter Benedict calls the plans "a measured pace of growth" rather than expanding too quickly.

Benedict praised Tractor Supply's customer service. "They are staffed with people who live that lifestyle," he said. If a customer has a broken riding mower or needs to mend a damaged fence, staffers offer problem-solving suggestions on how to repair or replace it.

"They've identified their core customer and know how to serve them," Benedict said. He describes the primary customer as someone who owns property with large animals, which could be a farmer, a rancher or a banker who lives on rural property with horses.

Benedict says everyone knows about Wal-Mart but Tractor Supply often falls under the radar screen. Rural clientele know it, but consumers won't find Tractor Supply in most malls or strip centers where the vast majority of customers shop. Yet, Benedict says, the company is executing its business model flawlessly.

Following in Tractor Supply's footsteps isn't easy. Dan Erling, author of "Match: A Systematic, Sane Process for Hiring the Right Person Every Time," says many companies go awry when hiring staff with specific know-how. Matching the applicant to the corporate culture is difficult, and most hiring depends 75% on personality and 25% on technical skills.
"It's hard work to hire the right person, and most organizations don't have the energy or resources to make this happen," Erling said.
Shorter Learning Curve

When done deftly, choosing the right employee can boost profitability. Staffers that possess this expertise can "walk through the door, bring their knowledge to the table, get going faster and require less of a learning curve," Erling said.

To prove expertise, Erling says one manufacturing company gave its applicants a simulated test on a computer that revealed whether a person possessed the necessary skills. In hiring, companies can also ask behavioral questions to ensure that applicants fit the job.
Many companies don't make recruiting the right applicant a priority. "Everyone has a marketing plan, but few organizations have a hiring plan," Erling said.

When Stephen Meadows was hired as chief accounting officer in 2006 by RockTenn (RKT), a $3 billion paper company based in Norcross, Ga., his mandate was to modernize the accounting system. Hence, he sought to hire IT and accounting staffers who had cutting-edge knowledge of systems.
Besides technical skills, Meadows sought employees who were adaptive "and could change how technology was used in the organization."
To determine who was qualified, he asked applicants to cite examples of how they sharply altered the accounting systems in their former job.

"The more talented the people you hire, the more efficiently you can do the job," Meadows said.If applying for certain retail jobs at Tractor Supply (TSCO), you'd better come with plenty of equine know-how and a green thumb.It pays to know the meaning of words like tack (leather products for horses) or hard keepers (horses that lose weight easily).Hiring people with special skills in horses or farming has become a staple and revenue booster at Tractor Supply, the biggest rural retailer in the U.S., with 976 stores in 44 states.Many players talk about knowing customers. But analysts say one sure way to reach them involves hiring the right employee who understands a client's concerns. Companies that recruit staff with specific know-how can enhance profitability. At the same time, experts say identifying the right job candidate can be tricky.Tractor Supply, whose revenue rose to $3.2 billion in 2009 and is on track to hit $3.5 billion in 2010, believes that specialized workers are a competitive edge.Staffers are recruited with expertise in four areas: farming, ranching, horses and welding. Why welding? If they know welding, odds are that they've mastered nearly everything else in home repair.Hiring Horse SenseJames Wright, CEO of Brentwood, Tenn.-based Tractor Supply, says creating a reservoir of staff knowledge helps retain both customers and employees. "Only with longevity of staff can we build deep category expertise," he said.Since many customers own horses, staffers with four-legged expertise can offer advice on horse training, nutrition and care, and speak the "horse language," Wright says. The staffers, called team members at Tractor Supply, build rapport, develop close ties with customers and close a sale, which leads to return customers.In addition to technical smarts, Tractor Supply also seeks staffers with an upbeat attitude. "We seek someone with a bounce in their step, who's gregarious, positive and not grumpy," Wright said. Indeed, when customers enter a store, staffers greet them with an upbeat hello and a smile.Wright describes the company's recruiting philosophy as "hiring hard and managing easy." Hence, hiring includes tough job descriptions and extensive interviewing. But once on board, staffers receive incentives for boosting sales and recognition for outstanding performance.Employee turnover used to be a problem. But over the last 10 years, the upbeat employee retention approach has cut turnover in the retail staff from 100% to 35% annually. On the store manager side, it's fallen from 43% to 15%.A stable staff helps to fuel store expansions. The company plans to open 75 to 80 stores in 2011, an 8% jump from the prior year. Robert W. Baird & Co. senior retail analyst Peter Benedict calls the plans "a measured pace of growth" rather than expanding too quickly.Benedict praised Tractor Supply's customer service. "They are staffed with people who live that lifestyle," he said. If a customer has a broken riding mower or needs to mend a damaged fence, staffers offer problem-solving suggestions on how to repair or replace it."They've identified their core customer and know how to serve them," Benedict said. He describes the primary customer as someone who owns property with large animals, which could be a farmer, a rancher or a banker who lives on rural property with horses.Benedict says everyone knows about Wal-Mart but Tractor Supply often falls under the radar screen. Rural clientele know it, but consumers won't find Tractor Supply in most malls or strip centers where the vast majority of customers shop. Yet, Benedict says, the company is executing its business model flawlessly.Following in Tractor Supply's footsteps isn't easy. Dan Erling, author of "Match: A Systematic, Sane Process for Hiring the Right Person Every Time," says many companies go awry when hiring staff with specific know-how. Matching the applicant to the corporate culture is difficult, and most hiring depends 75% on personality and 25% on technical skills."It's hard work to hire the right person, and most organizations don't have the energy or resources to make this happen," Erling said.Shorter Learning CurveWhen done deftly, choosing the right employee can boost profitability. Staffers that possess this expertise can "walk through the door, bring their knowledge to the table, get going faster and require less of a learning curve," Erling said.To prove expertise, Erling says one manufacturing company gave its applicants a simulated test on a computer that revealed whether a person possessed the necessary skills. In hiring, companies can also ask behavioral questions to ensure that applicants fit the job.Many companies don't make recruiting the right applicant a priority. "Everyone has a marketing plan, but few organizations have a hiring plan," Erling said.When Stephen Meadows was hired as chief accounting officer in 2006 by RockTenn (RKT), a $3 billion paper company based in Norcross, Ga., his mandate was to modernize the accounting system. Hence, he sought to hire IT and accounting staffers who had cutting-edge knowledge of systems.Besides technical skills, Meadows sought employees who were adaptive "and could change how technology was used in the organization."To determine who was qualified, he asked applicants to cite examples of how they sharply altered the accounting systems in their former job."The more talented the people you hire, the more efficiently you can do the job," Meadows said.

It's often hard to figure out when to sell a stock.Ideally, you've bought a name that will become a tremendous stock market winner, like Apple (AAPL), Baidu (BIDU) or Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG).But realistically, you can't expect every stock in your portfolio to perform like a champ. While a few might, others will only provide a solid gain, rather than a remarkable one. And others will head south, offsetting your winners.Given this range of outcomes, IBD advises locking in your profits for at least some of your winners when the gains reach 20% to 25%.It can be a good idea to prepare in advance for this sale. When you buy a stock priced at, say, 100 a share, you can make a note to yourself to sell at 120 or 125.One reason to sell after a 20% or 25% gain is to avoid sitting through the stock's next consolidation. Time and time again, leading stocks catch their breath after advances of 20% or 25%.If you have plenty of conviction in a name, then you'll want to sit tight through that period of price consolidation, which IBD calls a base. But you probably won't be completely enamored with every stock, so you'll want to declare victory with some names and move on.Often, this will help you steer clear of a round trip with a stock. That means achieving a sizable profit, but then seeing it evaporate as the stock comes back to your buy point.At the same time, selling for a gain of 20% or 25% doesn't prevent you from buying the stock back. You could let it shape a new base, then establish a position again on the breakout from the new base.Earlier this year, Tractor Supply (TSCO) offered an opportunity to take a profit at 25%.The farming equipment retailer cleared a 75.58 buy point from a flat base in early January 1, not long after the Dec. 20 follow-through day that signaled a new market uptrend.You could have established a position at that level, then made a note to sell at about 94.48 — when your profit hit 25%. With this goal in mind, you would have sold in early April 2.This would have saved you from taking a round trip that was completed in July 3.
Stocks held moderate gains at midafternoon Monday, trading slightly below their session highs.
The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 both rose 0.5%, while the Nasdaq gained 0.3%. Volume was tracking up a little from Friday's levels for both main exchanges.

Among S&P 100 names, Abbott LabsTICKER jumped 3% in big volume, helped by its positive study results for a hepatitis C drug. The stock has touched a new high and is extended beyond a proper buying range. It has an IBD Composite Rating of 84 out of a best-possible 99, weighed down a bit by its meager sales growth. Abbott reports its quarterly results Thursday.

American Tower (AMT) surged 4% in huge turnover, clearing a 73.30 entry from a low handle. The operator of cell towers sports an 80 Composite Rating, hurt by its decline in quarterly EPS last quarter. The company is expected to announce Q3 profit of 38 cents a share, rebounding from a loss of four cents a share a year ago. The Q3 report is due Oct. 31 before the market opens.

Citigroup (C) gained 4% in fast trade, after third-quarter earnings slipped less than expected. The banking giant cleared a 35.35 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. It has earned a mediocre Composite Rating of 50.

Among leading stocks, Polaris Industries (PII) advanced 2% in strong volume. The maker of ATVs, snowmobiles and motorcycles is extended above a 78.04 buy point after a breakout last month. Polaris is No. 28 in the latest IBD 50 lineup.

On the downside, Tractor Supply (TSCO) lost 1% in big turnover, but it has pared its loss for the session and regained its 50-day moving average. The specialty retailer is No. 33 in the latest IBD 50 lineup.

In economic news Monday, retail sales climbed 1.1% in September, above the 0.7% growth projected by analysts. The slowdown in New York region manufacturing eased in October, putting the N.Y. Could home improvement retailers spruce up and electronics stores power down in light of the latest industry sales data?

Retail trade figures out this week from the Census Bureau run positive for the likes of Home Depot (HD) and Lowe's Companies (LOW) but not so for Best Buy (BBY) and RadioShack (RSH), says RBC Capital Markets analyst Scot Ciccarelli, in a research note Friday. He adds that falling gas prices could benefit auto parts sellers, encouraging more summer driving. IBD 50 stock O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) is in that industry.
Sales at building material and garden equipment & supply dealers rose 5.3% year over year in May, the Census Bureau estimated Wednesday in a retail trade report.

"In light of the softness in (comparable sales) during the month of April for Home Depot and Lowe's and the negative pre-announcement from Scotts Miracle-Gro (SMG) on Wednesday, we took the retail sales data ... as a positive datapoint for home improvement retail," Ciccarelli said in his note.

IBD's Retail/Wholesale-Building Products industry group is now ranked 77 out of 197 groups tracked, fallen from 53 a week ago. It's highest-rated stocks are flooring seller Lumber Liquidators Holdings (LL), Tractor Supply (TSCO), Beacon Roofing Supply (BECN) and Home Depot.
Lowe's rose 1% while Beacon and Tractor Supply both gained 1.3% Friday.

The outlook for electronics retailers isn't rosy and IBD's Retail-Consumer Electronics industry group is ranked near the bottom at No. 188. Electronics retailers have been struggling as their sales are drawn away by online superstore Amazon (AMZN).
The Census Bureau reported this week that retail sales at electronics and appliance stores fell an estimated 0.1% year over year in May.

"The decline in sales, while modest, represents a deceleration from the previous 2 months," Ciccarelli said in his research note. "The continued softness in retail sales at electronics and appliance stores is a negative for both Best Buy and RadioShack."
Best Buy stock moved up 1.1% Friday as RadioShack slipped 0.5%.
Gas prices, meanwhile, are on the decline after a price spike earlier this year. They've fallen 10% from a March peak, making consumers more likely to rack up driving miles over the summer.
Ciccarelli notes that at the end of March a gallon of gasoline cost $3.93 on average, but now it's down to $3.53.
He sees auto parts retailers benefiting due to more wear and tear on cars meaning more need for parts.
IBD's Retail/Wholesale-Auto Parts industry group is ranked No. 67. In it highly rated stocks include LKQ Corp. (LKQ) and the IBD 50's O'Reilly Automotive, which edged up 0.7% Friday.

Pharmacy benefits management firm Express Scripts (ESRX) said its $29 billion acquisition of rival Medco Health Solutions delivered savings faster than expected, helping drive better-than-expected Q2 results.
And the company said its impasse with drugstore chain Walgreen (WAG) — which it settled last month — didn't hurt it much.
That news helped boost Express Scripts shares more than 9% for the week, and helped elevate it to the elite IBD 50 list at No. 29.
It was one of nine firms promoted to the list published in Monday's Investor's Business Daily.
The consulting and IT market research firm Gartner (IT) joined at No. 38. For-profit university Grand Canyon Education (LOPE) joined at No. 41.
Danish drugmaker Novo Nordisk (NVO) is No. 43. Fertilizer maker Agrium (AGU) moved to No. 44. Business intelligence firm IHS (IHS) moved to No. 45.
Network testing equipment maker IXIA (XXIA) is No. 46. Disk drive maker Seagate Technology (STX) moved to No. 47. And fertilizer maker Rentech Nitrogen Partners (RNF) moved to No. 48.
Nine others fell off to make room.
One of them was Monster Beverage (MNST), the energy drink maker that disclosed late Thursday it was being investigated by a state attorney general about its ingredients, advertising and other issues.
The online travel agency Priceline.com (PCLN) also slipped off. Its shares tumbled 15% for the week, after it gave weak guidance on economic head winds from Europe and currency effects.

The others off the list were cosmetics retailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA), farm supplier Tractor Supply (TSCO), bakery-cafe chain Panera Bread (PNRA), freight hauler Union Pacific (UNP), discount flier Spirit Airlines (SAVE), oil mover and storer Plains All American Pipeline (PAA) and network security firm Fortinet (FTNT).Pharmacy benefits management firm Express Scripts (ESRX) said its $29 billion acquisition of rival Medco Health Solutions delivered savings faster than expected, helping drive better-than-expected Q2 results.And the company said its impasse with drugstore chain Walgreen (WAG) — which it settled last month — didn't hurt it much.That news helped boost Express Scripts shares more than 9% for the week, and helped elevate it to the elite IBD 50 list at No. 29.It was one of nine firms promoted to the list published in Monday's Investor's Business Daily.The consulting and IT market research firm Gartner (IT) joined at No. 38. Wells Fargo Advantage Emerging Growth Fund is among the top performing U.S. stock funds since 2010's market bottom in August.

The $872 million portfolio's outperformance stems in large part from a solid 2010. Its 31.78% gain more than doubled the broad market's 15.06% and beat the 26.98% score posted by its small-cap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar.
Its 4.95% gain in 2011 topped its peers' -3.55% average and the S&P 500's 2.11% gain.
The fund has done that by aiming for small caps with a multiyear growth cycle in front of them.
Co-lead managers Thomas Ognar, age 41, and Joseph Eberhardy, 44, along with 51-year-old manager Bruce Olson discussed their strategy with IBD from their offices in Menomonee Falls, Wis.

IBD: Many investors are looking for companies with the resources to weather a stormy market and with little European exposure. That leads them to large U.S. multinationals. As small-cap investors, how are you coping?
Olson: To be effective and analyze companies and try to model their growth going forward, we need to take account of market environments.

But we don't think of the world first from a macro perspective. We look for companies like LogMeIn (LOGM), which provides on-demand remote connectivity software. Once we identify it as a growth company with the characteristics we want, we ask how the macro environment can impact its growth. Is it factored into its stock price?
We look for stocks with a gap between what we think a company's value is given its growth prospects and where the stock price is.
When there's at least a 20% upside to where it should be valued in perhaps one year, that's a stock we want if it shows the other characteristics we want.
IBD: That underappreciation is one of three characteristics you seek, right?
Olson: Correct. We look for smaller, new, faster growing companies with three characteristics.
One is a robust growth, in the top 25% of cash flow and earnings in its industry.
It must be at least 10% annual revenue and earnings growth.
Second is growth that is sustainable. It can do that by creating a new market or taking market share. It can have a differentiated product or service that can continually grow at least 10% annually.
And third is that 20% upside.
IBD: But what about the danger of investing in small caps when many investors are tilting towards large caps?
Olson: Smaller caps can be more volatile. We just try to take advantage of that volatility. We look for those gaps between price and potential.
IBD: So have you been buying and adding to names you like as they pull back?

Olson: We do put money to work in volatile periods. One thing (shareholders) should realize is that U.S. corporations, if you look at their cash as a percentage of assets, is at an all-time high, going back 50 years. And corporations are using that cash.

It is being deployed in smaller companies like Brigham Exploration (BEXP) (being acquired by Statoil (STO), NetLogic Microsystems (NETL) (being acquired by Broadcom (BRCM) and SonoSite (SONO) (being acquired by Fujifilm Holdings). Big companies put that cash into faster growing assets, which a lot of times are stocks that we've invested in. So small caps can benefit from how large caps redeploy their cash through M&A activity.
IBD: Do you wear blinders to limit your vision just to small caps?
Ognar: We've found that doing research on mid and large caps helps us with small caps.

To be good investors in small caps like Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) or Hibbett Sports (HIBB) or Life Time Fitness (LTM), we have to research Nike (NKE), Under Armour (UA) and Wal-Mart (WMT). And we can own either in our multicap fund ($7.2 billion Wells Fargo Advantage Growth .

IBD: I know you are bottom-up investors and do not invest based on sectors. Yet sector weights show where you expect to find leaders. Tech is still your largest sector. Through the 12 months ended Sept. 30 your weighting declined 11 percentage points to 24%. Mostly price action, or mostly sells?
Olson: Both. When we take out assets, it's to deploy them into better ideas.
IBD: Your weightings increased by about 5% in health care and 4% in industrials.
Eberhardy: We look at the world bottom-up. When we see that valuation gap widen in names we like, we redeploy our cash.
IBD: Akorn (AKRX) is a health name that you added to as of your latest disclosure. Sales have accelerated for two quarters. What's your thesis?

Eberhardy: They focus on ophthalmology and hospital injectables, primarily generics. The main thesis is that this is an underappreciated name. The market has missed the fact that they have 27 abbreviated new product applications. That's a big pipeline. It shows what's before the FDA and has a chance to be approved.
Those address about a $3 billion branded market. The company also plans to go into the private label ophthalmology market.

And there's an underappreciated shortage of generic injectable drugs, due to manufacturing delays at some larger players like Hospira (HSP). So we believe Akorn is a 25% to 30% annual top line grower. It should have expanding margins, so it should get in excess of that on the bottom line.
IBD: Zoll Medical (ZOLL) is another health name you added to. Return on equity jumped to 9.3% in 2011 from 6.4% the year before. What do you like here?
Eberhardy: They have one main product, the LifeVest. It's a wearable defibrillator, which a patient can use while waiting to get an implantable cardiac defibrillator.

There have been rule changes that the waiting period (during which a patient wears LifeVest while his doctor assesses his risk for sudden cardiac arrest and develops a treatment strategy) should be extended, and LifeVest is at the forefront of taking advantage of that.

IBD: You added to your stake in Chart Industries (GTLS), an industrial. Sales growth has accelerated for six quarters. Earnings per share have grown at a triple-digit pace for three quarters but are decelerating. Your thoughts?
Eberhardy: They're the leading manufacturer of equipment used in processing and storage of industrial gases and liquefied natural gas.
There's a secular movement toward more use of LNG. This company is at the forefront of providing infrastructure for that distribution.
Also, LNG is being used more as a fuel for transportation overseas.
And here in the U.S. there is a big difference between the cost of producing gas and what it can be sold for overseas.
IBD: Is Tractor Supply  (TSCO) doing well because it caters to people who ranch and farm more for fun than profit?
Ognar: They don't sell to farmers. Their end market is more like the rural enthusiast, who has 10 acres, farms a little, has a horse and enjoys the rural lifestyle.

They have an opportunity to double their store base. They're just starting to expand into the Western U.S. They've done a lot of productive things, from better merchandising, better inventory and distribution management — which are resulting in better sales experiences at stores — and (better) profitability and earnings.

This stock is hitting the limits of this fund's market cap. But this is a good example of what we can own in our multicap fund as well as this emerging growth fund.Wells Fargo Advantage Emerging Growth Fund is among the top performing U.S. stock funds since 2010's market bottom in August.The $872 million portfolio's outperformance stems in large part from a solid 2010. Yet sector weights show where you expect to find leaders. Tech is still your largest sector. Through the 12 months ended Sept. 30 your weighting declined 11 percentage points to 24%. Mostly price action, or mostly sells?Olson: Both. When we take out assets, it's to deploy them into better ideas.IBD: Your weightings increased by about 5% in health care and 4% in industrials.Eberhardy: We look at the world bottom-up. When we see that valuation gap widen in names we like, we redeploy our cash.IBD: Akorn (AKRX) is a health name that you added to as of your latest disclosure. Sales have accelerated for two quarters. What's your thesis?Eberhardy: They focus on ophthalmology and hospital injectables, primarily generics. The main thesis is that this is an underappreciated name. The market has missed the fact that they have 27 abbreviated new product applications. That's a big pipeline. It shows what's before the FDA and has a chance to be approved.Those address about a $3 billion branded market. The company also plans to go into the private label ophthalmology market.And there's an underappreciated shortage of generic injectable drugs, due to manufacturing delays at some larger players like Hospira (HSP). So we believe Akorn is a 25% to 30% annual top line grower. It should have expanding margins, so it should get in excess of that on the bottom line.IBD: Zoll Medical (ZOLL) is another health name you added to. Return on equity jumped to 9.3% in 2011 from 6.4% the year before. What do you like here?Eberhardy: They have one main product, the LifeVest. It's a wearable defibrillator, which a patient can use while waiting to get an implantable cardiac defibrillator.There have been rule changes that the waiting period (during which a patient wears LifeVest while his doctor assesses his risk for sudden cardiac arrest and develops a treatment strategy) should be extended, and LifeVest is at the forefront of taking advantage of that.IBD: You added to your stake in Chart Industries (GTLS), an industrial. Sales growth has accelerated for six quarters. Earnings per share have grown at a triple-digit pace for three quarters but are decelerating. Your thoughts?Eberhardy: They're the leading manufacturer of equipment used in processing and storage of industrial gases and liquefied natural gas.There's a secular movement toward more use of LNG. This company is at the forefront of providing infrastructure for that distribution.Also, LNG is being used more as a fuel for transportation overseas.And here in the U.S. there is a big difference between the cost of producing gas and what it can be sold for overseas.IBD: Is Tractor Supply  (TSCO) doing well because it caters to people who ranch and farm more for fun than profit?Ognar: They don't sell to farmers. Their end market is more like the rural enthusiast, who has 10 acres, farms a little, has a horse and enjoys the rural lifestyle.They have an opportunity to double their store base. They're just starting to expand into the Western U.S. They've done a lot of productive things, from better merchandising, better inventory and distribution management — which are resulting in better sales experiences at stores — and (better) profitability and earnings.This stock is hitting the limits of this fund's market cap. But this is a good example of what we can own in our multicap fund as well as this emerging growth fund.

August IPO Tile Shop Holdings (TTS) was among the top-rated stocks touching a new high Thursday, as the retail chain climbed as much as 5%. The stock closed in the bottom half of its trading range for the day, scoring a 1% gain. Volume came in strong, about 123% above average. Plymouth, Minn.-based Tile Shop is a specialty retailer that…
Investors will be watching Fastenal's (FAST) third-quarter results, due out Thursday before the market opens, for signs that the housing recovery and construction are on track.

The company operates about 2,700 wholesale construction supply stores selling fastening and maintenance products. Because it's at the front end of the housing supply chain and among the first to report, it's seen as a bellwether for the industry.
Analysts expect Fastenal to report that earnings per share rose 12% vs. the same quarter last year, to 37 cents. Revenue is forecast to climb 11% to $804.8 million.

Although the company has posted double-digit profit growth the last 10 quarters in a row and double-digit sales growth for nine periods, like its peers in the housing supplies group, it's seen growth ease in the last few quarters.
Over the last three quarters its EPS growth rate has been cut in half, falling from 36% to 26% to 19%. The Street will be looking for a return to accelerating growth.
Fastenal shares fell 0.4% to 42.59 in Wednesday morning trading.

Elsewhere in the Retail/Wholesale-Building Products group, ranked 104 on the list of 197 industries tracked by IBD, shares of rival W.W. Grainger (GWW) were off 0.8% to 209.23. Grainger is slated to announce Q3 results next Tuesday before the market opens.
No. 1 building materials and home repair retailer Home Depot (HD) dropped 0.7% to 60.52 and smaller rival Lowe's (LOW) was virtually unchanged at 31.15.
Tractor Supply (TSCO), which operates about 1,100 farm supply and implements stores, rose a few pennies to 98.91.
Online retailer Amazon.com (AMZN) has also established a beachhead in building supplies business, selling to businesses through its Amazon Webstore. Amazon shares eased a bit Wednesday morning.

Stocks of building suppliers as a group have backed off from their heady growth last year and earlier this year. The group's No. 104 ranking is down from 75 a month ago, and a lofty No. 7 rank six months ago.
Last quarter, Fastenal recorded a 19% hike in EPS to 38 cents a share, a penny over Wall Street's view. But sales came in a bit light, rising 15% to $804.9 million, vs. estimates of $807.7 million.

When Fastenal reported August sales figures on Sept. 6, it said sales at stores open at least two years rose 8.6% vs. the same month a year earlier, significantly lower than the 16.5% growth in August 2011.Investors will be watching Fastenal's (FAST) third-quarter results, due out Thursday before the market opens, for signs that the housing recovery and construction are on track.The company operates about 2,700 wholesale construction supply stores selling fastening and maintenance products. Stocks ticked higher in late trading Tuesday, sending the major averages to their best levels since May 31.

The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 1% each. The S&P 500 climbed 0.9%. Volume was mixed in the stock market today. NYSE trade was running a bit lower compared with the same time Monday. Nasdaq volume was tracking a hair higher.

United Rentals (URI) rallied 6%, erasing all of Monday's loss and then some. The stock is rebounding from a failed breakout in February. Last week, the stock found support near its 40-week moving average.

Cree (CREE) rallied 4% to its best levels since January 2011 in brisk trade. It cleared a 64.42 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern. The company's earnings went through a rough patch in 2011 and parts of 2012. But it has since delivered three straight quarters of earnings growth, thanks to demand for LED lighting.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) climbed 3% in strong volume, despite announcing a stock offering late Monday. After Monday's close, the Canadian drugmaker said that it hopes to raise about $1.75 billion through a share offering to help fund its $4.5 billion acquisition of Bausch & Lomb. Valeant is extended from a rebound off its 10-week line and a 76.66 buy point from a flat base.

Brookfield Residential Properties (BRP) rose 2% in seesaw trading. The stock had regained its 50-day moving average in light trade Monday. In late 2007, Gregory Sandfort, Tractor Supply's president and COO, saw customer buying patterns shifting. Clients of the farm and ranch equipment seller were moving away from buying large-ticket items. They wanted to mend equipment. If consumer buying was changing, Tractor Supply, with 1,135 retail stores in 45 states, needed to respond.

It was a smart call for Sandfort, who at the end of September was named Tractor Supply's (TSCO) CEO effective Jan. 1 next year when current CEO James Wright becomes executive chairman of the Brentwood, Tenn.-based chain's board.

As president, Sandfort helped managers focus on increasing the "consumable, usable and edible products" at company outlets to boost customer traffic. Management also came up with "CUE" as an acronym for their new strategy, and so far, it's working.

Adapting product lines to shifting customer spending patterns is now critical to a company's success. They also honed their strategy without hiring a costly research firm. Tractor Supply compiles its own research on what customers are buying.

Sensitivity on just how much clients are willing to spend is critical at the cash register. "We sell riding lawn mowers, parts and accessories, so anything that sells for above $350 is considered a big-ticket item," Sandfort told IBD.

Sandfort, a former chief merchandising officer at Michaels Stores, studies Tractor Supply's business in small chunks to see "what's selling in spring, what's not, what needs to change. Sequence and timing are critical," he said.

Sandfort described consumable items as things people use such as fertilizers and lubricants, usables as equipment that needs to be repaired and edibles as feed for pets and farm animals. He calls these CUE items necessary, not discretionary, and comparable to "milk, eggs and butter" in a supermarket.
Stressing these essentials also boosted return business. "These are items that customers buy on a regular basis that build frequency and traffic," Sandfort said.

Tractor Supply executives hold quarterly town hall meetings with about 15 store managers and district managers to track clients' buying habits. What new products are customers buying, and how can it change its merchandise to adjust?
It has also spiked sales by developing its own private labels in areas such as gardening and hardware. These sales now constitute 23% of revenue, though it doesn't use the Tractor Supply name.
Keeping Prices Low

For example, when customers started to buy a premium branded dog food that was costing $45 to $48 a package, Tractor Supply saw an opening for a new product. It developed its own premium canine food but sold it for $7 or $8 less, which has proven popular. It keeps its prices down because it doesn't have to pay for marketing, Sandfort says.

Most of its stores are located in rural areas, and 60% of those locales suffered droughts in 2012. Tractor Supply stocked more water storage tanks and hoses so customers could store and gain access to water, but cut back on buying lawn mowers. You don't need to cut your grass during a drought, Sandfort says.
Adapting product lines is paying off. In 2011, Tractor Supply had an 8.2% increase in same-store sales following a 7% rise in 2010.

Store sales are rising because Tractor Supply listens to its customers, says Joan Storms, a Los Angeles-based industry analyst with Wedbush Securities. "When customers come in, it's like talking to their neighbors. Tractor Supply hires horse specialists and metal repair specialists," she said. Its staff is trained to problem-solve and doesn't follow customers through the stores pushing products on them.
Eye Gentleman Farmers
The prototypical customer is a "gentleman farmer, who may be an executive in the city who owns a weekend retreat, and earns above the national income," Sandfort said.

Tractor Supply has a "franchise in this farm and tractor category that no one else covers," Storms said. While they face competition from PetSmart (PETM) and Petco for some types of feed, most of their rivals are local feed stores, which don't carry its breadth of merchandise. Those mom-and-pop stores have dwindled from 15,000 to about 10,000 in the last few years.
Tractor Supply opened 84 new stores in 2011 and plans to open 90 to 95 stores by the end of 2012. Over the next few years, it has long-term plans to expand to 2,100 stores.
"They're opening some smaller stores and filling out markets appropriately," Storm said.

When it opened its first store in Colorado in 2012, it started conducting research three years before the debut. Its research revealed that Coloradans prefer to buy feed made in the state and stocked the store with Coloradan-made seed.

Storms sees continued growth due to opening new stores, rising private-label sales and its CUE strategy. Ultimately, Tractor Supply thrives because it "sells unique products you won't find anywhere else," she said.In late 2007, Gregory Sandfort, Tractor Supply's president and COO, saw customer buying patterns shifting. Stocks bounced Monday after suffering their biggest weekly loss in more than four months last week. The S&P 500 rallied 0.8% for its biggest gain so far this month. The NYSE composite also rose 0.8%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq climbed 0.7% after erasing an intraday loss of 0.2%. It also snapped a six-day slide. All three major averages recouped all of…
Stocks held onto slim gains in light trade early Tuesday afternoon as services data for May topped expectations and Europe's markets improved on talks aimed at stabilizing Spain's banking system.
The Nasdaq and S&P 500 were each up 0.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average was a fraction higher. Volume was slightly lower compared with the same time Monday.

Financials led the Dow, with Bank Of America (BAC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) adding 3% apiece. On the Nasdaq 100, Akamai Technologies (AKAM) dropped more than 6% in huge volume after Netflix (NFLX) said it would stream more of its videos over its own content delivery network.

Meanwhile, construction supply chain Fastenal (FAST) dived 9%, plunging below its 200-day moving average, after reporting that its sales growth slowed in May. The announcement also dragged down shares of rival W.W. Grainger (GWW), which plunged 7% in huge volume. Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) lost 4%.
The Philadelphia semiconductor index jumped to a solid start on the heels of a 1% gain by Rubicon Technology (RBCN) and SanDisk's (SNDK) 5% jump.

The service sector of the economy expanded more than expected in May, pushing the Institute of Supply Management's service index to 53.7. That is up from 53.5 in April and better than forecasts for a slip to 53.1.

Among IBD 50 stocks, Titan Machinery (TITN) climbed 7%, making its way back toward its 10-week moving average. The online surplus inventory auctioneer has closed below support at the 10-week line in light trade twice since May 16.
Web.com Group (WWWW) popped more than 2% in weak trade. The website publishing software maker is in the fifth week of a possible flat base.

Also, farm goods retailer Tractor Supply (TSCO) climbed 2% in above-average trade, recouping some of Monday's 5% loss. Its base-building effort was marred by a recent drop that has taken the stock below its 50-day line.
On the downside, Starbucks (SBUX) dropped 4% in heavy volume after the coffee retailer announced Monday that it would buy Bay Bread, which owns French pastry maker La Boulange bakery.

Overseas, Europe's markets improved heading into late-afternoon trading, as a conference call of G-7 finance ministers seemed to steady worries over Spain's precarious finances. Spain's budget minister pleaded for support for the country's failing banks, claiming rising risk premiums had effectively blocked the country from access to capital markets.

The CAC-40 in Paris climbed 1.1%. Frankfurt's DAX narrowed its earlier losses and was down 0.2%. Some leading stocks showed signs of stress during the past week, as IBD's market outlook was downgraded to "uptrend under pressure." SolarWinds (SWI) has dropped in fast trade after breaking out past a 39.85 buy point from a square-box base on Monday. The tech stock fell as much as 6.8% below 39.85 on Thursday, coming close to triggering IBD's 7%…

Technology and consumer shares topped this week's list of Weekly Review amid data showing improvement in jobs, manufacturing and retail sales. Many are, however, extended past buy points.Data networking leader F5 Networks (F5) is 13% above a 117.40 buy point. Stocks that are more than 5% above their entry points are seen as risky because latecomers could be shaken out by a pullback.But F5 has also popped above a 130.37 entry in a three-weeks-tight pattern, giving a new chance to add a small amount of shares to an existing position. F5 is in the top-ranked Internet-Network Solutions group along with IBD Leaderboard stocks Rackspace Hosting (RAX) and SolarWinds (SWI).Rackspace, which operates cloud-computing centers, is 24% past a 45.56 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. Network management software developer SolarWinds is 14% past a 33.78 buy point.Two other software developers high on the list are Israel-based ClickSoftware (CKSW) and  Salesforce.com (CRM). Both are in the Computer Software-Enterprise group, which was ranked eighth out of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD as of Thursday. Both are also extended from buy points.Apple (AAPL) briefly touched the 600 mark Thursday before reversing lower. It's 27% past a 427.85 entry. Piper Jaffray says Apple might sell 1 million new iPads on the first day of sales Friday.Flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators (LL) and farm supply chain Tractor Supply (TSCO), both members of the highly rated Retail/Wholesale-Building Supply group, are also extended from their buy points.Apparel retailer Buckle (BKE), auto retailer America's Car-Mart (CRMT) and athletic footwear retailer Foot Locker (FL) also stood out. None are in buying range, however.Biotech names were well-represented, and some are even near buy points. Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) is 2% above an 87.73 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern.

Stocks remained near session lows, but were on pace to end October with their biggest gains in more than two decades.The S&P 500 dropped 1.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.4%. Both were headed for their biggest monthly gains since January 1987 and August 1982 respectively, according to the Associated Press. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq shed 1.2%. Turnover continued to track sharply lower across the board.Ceva (CEVA) reversed earlier gains and fell 5% in heavy trading. The reversal eased all of Friday's move. The stock is forming a new base, but it would be a fourth-stage pattern.Banks also came under pressure. Morgan Stanley (MS) and Bank of America (BAC) dropped 5% and 4%, respectively.On the upside, Hansen Natural (HANS) extended rebound efforts. It rallied 4% in fast trade and cleared resistance at its 50-day moving average. The stock suffered some distribution last week. The distributor of Monster Energy drinks will report Q3 results after Thursday's close. Analysts see profit rising 24% to 89 cents a share. Sales are slated to grow 21% to $462.3 million.SolarWinds (SWI) eased from a new high, but was still up 2% in active trading. Solid Q3 results Thursday sent the stock past a 25.72 buy point from a first-stage double-bottom base. The 48% jump in earnings and the 31% gain in sales were its best results in several quarters.Recent breakouts Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) and Tractor Supply (TSCO) have also turned higher.

Stocks opened higher Monday, but quickly faded to a mixed performance. The Nasdaq held a fraction into positive territory. The S&P 500 slipped 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average edged 0.1% lower. Volume was down 12% on the Nasdaq and 31% lower on the NYSE compared with the same time Friday. Factory orders slipped 0.6% in April, missing expectations…

The stock market opened lower Wednesday as fears of contagion swept Europe and hopes for a China stimulus faded.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 tumbled 1.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average was down 1.1%. Volume was tracking lower compared with the same time Tuesday.The broad indexes deepened their losses after the National Association of Realtors reported a 5.5% plunge in pending home sales for April. That was well below even the most optimistic estimates. The SPDR S&P Homebuilders (XHB) ETF was down 2%.Relatively few leading stocks came under heavy fire in early trading. But the retail sector accounted for a large share of those.DSW (DSW) gapped down, shedding 3% in heavy volume. The stock remained above 57, a level of resistance it cleared a week ago. Rival Steven Madden (SHOO) also lost 3% in active trading.Tractor Supply (TSCO) continued its sell-off. Shares stumbled 3% to a two-month low as the retailer's base continued to show stress.Reuters reported that yields on 10-year Spanish bonds moved closer to 7%, the level at which other nations in the eurozone were forced to seek a bailout. Italian 10-year yields topped 6% for the first time since a January bond sale.The latest poll from Greece showed a leftist party has taken the lead over the pro-bailout conservatives ahead of a national parliamentary election next month.The FTSE 100 slid 1.7%, Germany's DAX 1.4% and France's CAC 40 1.7%. The Athens bourse plunged 3.8%.China's official news agency Xinhua reported government officials were backpedaling on a large-scale stimulus. Hong Kong's Hang Seng fell 1.9%, the Shanghai composite 0.2%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 fell 0.3%.

A correction is no time to buy.Most disciplined investors probably aren't having much trouble following that rule these days. The month of May hasn't served up many breakouts.The sluggishness is making it easy for investors to do what they should be doing: looking for stocks that could be forming bases.A few stocks in the Stock Spotlight screen appear to be working on bases. These stocks also have relative strength lines at or near new highs, which points to outperformance vs. the S&P 500.Network management software developer SolarWinds (SWI) gapped up 20% in huge volume to close at 45.38 on April 26. The stock has essentially moved sideways since the gap-up, while the S&P 500 dropped about 7%.On the weekly chart, SolarWinds looks like it is only in the third week of a consolidation. The daily chart shows it is working on the fourth week. So far, the pattern is less than 10% deep.The Internet-Network Solutions group is No. 14 of 197 groups, as of Wednesday's IBD.Retail farm and ranch chain Tractor Supply (TSCO) appears to be working on week four of a consolidation on the weekly chart. The daily chart shows it's in week five of the pattern.The stock is sketching a shallow pattern, and its RS line is at a high.The Retail-Wholesale Building Products group is No. 37.Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) is working on the ninth week of a possible base. Although there are four down weeks in above-average volume within the consolidation, the overall pattern shows two net weeks of accumulation — not counting this week.How is this possible? A weekly close high in the range is a sign of accumulation, not distribution.The Medical-Biomed Biotech group is No. 4 among 197 groups.

In Monday's column, IBD noted that the shaky action of certain individual stocks affirmed the market's shift into a correction.However, it should also be noted that not all stocks are following the same script.As Monday's selection of 16 stocks showed, several have fallen minimally since IBD's Market Pulse went from "uptrend under pressure" to "correction" after the May 4 trading session.The leaders that fall the least during a general decline are sending an important signal to alert chart readers. When the market returns to an uptrend, the chances are greater for these stocks to power out of new bases first and go on strong price runs.Consider Sourcefire (FIRE), which gapped up 13% on May 1 in the second-highest turnover so far this year. That big move catapulted the network security specialist 24% past a 46.39 short-stroke entry. In other words, the stock is still well extended from a proper buy point.Recent declines have been modest, both in price and volume.The company, incorporated in 2001 and making its stock-market debut in March 2007, has accelerating top- and bottom-line growth.SXC Solutions (SXCI) soared 22% in the week ended April 20, while the market was still in rally mode. The fast-growing pharmacy benefits manager has recently announced new acquisitions to further bolster its market presence.Despite a 2.5% decline Monday, the stock is still 9% above its fast-rising 10-week line.Tractor Supply (TSCO), featured in today's Income Investor column on Page B6, is easing in a gentle fashion after rising as much as 44% from a 70.20 cup-with-handle entry. The leader in IBD's Retail/Wholesale-Building Products sports 38% annualized EPS growth in the past three years.

The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were little changed. Trade was also mixed, up about 11% on the Nasdaq and down a few clicks on the NYSE vs. action at the same time Monday. The…

Dividend-paying companies tend to be more mature, less volatile firms. W.W. Grainger (GWW) fits the bill. But the company has also delivered respectable growth.Last month, the industrial supplies retailer reported full-year 2011 adjusted diluted earnings per share of $9.04, up 33%. That marked the fourth straight double-digit gain in the past five years.The stock has a five-year Earnings Stability Factor of 9, indicating a steady stream of profit.Sales grew 12% to nearly $8.1 billion. It has now delivered back-to-back double-digit increases in annual revenue.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit rising 16% to $10.51 this year. The estimate has been raised recently.W.W. Grainger is a member of the S&P Dividend Aristocrats index, which tracks the performance of blue chip companies that have increased their shareholder payouts for at least 25 years.The company has raised its dividend for 40 straight years. W.W. Grainger's dividend has nearly doubled since 2007. In its last dividend hike of almost a year ago, W.W. Grainger boosted its payout by 22% to a quarterly rate of 66 cents a share. It tends to announce dividend increases in late April.On an annualized basis, W.W. Grainger pays $2.64 a share. This works out to a current yield of 1.3%, which is on the low side of the eight dividend-paying stocks in the high-ranking Retail/Wholesale-Building Products group. The group is home to top-rated firms such as  Fastenal (FAST), Home Depot (HD) and Tractor Supply (TSCO).Despite the softer yield, W.W. Grainger has a Composite Rating of 97 and an Earnings Per Share Rating of 91. Both are among the highest of its peers.W.W. Grainger cleared a 156.95 buy point from a cup-with-handle base Sept. 13 in healthy volume. But it triggered the 8% sell rule about three weeks later.The stock staged a comeback after finding support near its 10-week and 40-week moving averages and has been in a sharp uptrend since. It has now formed a three-weeks-tight add-on pattern. The buy point is at 212.10, or 10 cents above the Feb. 28 peak.

Heavy equipment seller Titan Machinery (TITN) blew past analyst forecasts, thanks to flush farmers and a resurgent construction market in parts of the country. The new and used combine, tractor and excavator retailer posted fourth-quarter earnings of 84 cents per share, up 47% from a year ago. Analysts were expecting 53 cents per share. Revenue soared 65% to $607 million,…
Eric Fischman, manager of $4.6 billion MFS Growth Fund , invests with a long-term horizon.
But he'll add to a stock he likes if short-term volatility makes its price compelling.
And he's been doing that during the recent market pullback.
"We try to be consistent year in, year out," Fischman said. "But we can use volatility to our advantage and not get whipped around."
Going into Monday, his fund ranks in the top 22% of its large-cap growth category over the past three years and the top 21% over the past 12 months.
Year to date, it's in the middle of the pack. Its slow start this year is due to its focus on secular growth stories.

"The market has been in a strong cyclical rally. And we've been underweight in cyclical names like metals, mining and basic materials," he said. "The last six weeks we started to outperform as cyclicals cooled and secular areas got hot."
So far this year the fund's average annual gain is 13.74% vs. 13.56% for its direct rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. and 9.63% for the S&P 500.
Over the past three years the fund's average annual gain is 21.20% vs. 19.34% for its peers and 19.32% for the big-cap bogey.
Tech Tilt
His favorite area for seeking secular growth leaders is technology. "Fundamentals are very strong in several segments, especially wireless, mobile computing, smartphones and tablets."
Shares of VMware (VMW) gapped down last Wednesday, amid the broad market pullback, on news that CFO Mark Peek is leaving to work for a software firm planning an IPO.
Shares are still up 35% this year.
"We look beyond that and see VMware still well-positioned in the virtualization space," Fischman said. "We still like them long term."
The software firm has an 80% share of its industry.
Earnings-per-share growth has slowed for two quarters. But since reversing lower Tuesday, shares have bounced off their 50-day average. That lifted the stock's Relative Strength line near its high.
F5 Networks (FFIV) benefits from the increase in data being squeezed onto the Internet. "We'll need more networking companies like them that manage the flow of information," Fischman said.
In the broad pullback last week, F5 broke hard below its 10-week line in heavy volume.
EPS growth has slowed for four quarters. But its fiscal Q2 numbers are due out on Wednesday. EPS growth is seen reaccelerating.
Biotech Bets
Another place where Fischman finds secular growth is in a biotech name like Celgene (CELG).
Its EPS growth has accelerated for two quarters. Its key driver is Revlimid, a treatment mainly for blood cancer.
"New indications for the drug have enabled it to do well against some other forms of cancer," Fischman said.
Tractor Supply (TSCO) gapped up on Thursday, as it reported comp-store sales that beat expectations.
It's 20% over its 82.08 buy point in a four-weeks-tight pattern.
"The secular growth story is that they're still growing units and comp-store sales," Fischman said. "This growth looks sustainable for some time."

MSC Industrial Direct (MSM) is expected to continue a string of double-digit profit gains when it reports second-quarter results Wednesday morning.
The 14 analysts polled by Thomson Financial forecast EPS of 95 cents, up 22% from 78 cents a share the same quarter a year earlier.
When it released first-quarter results on Jan. 5, the company forecast second-quarter earnings per share of 92-96 cents.
The company projected second-quarter revenue of $548 million to $560 million. Analysts are looking for $554.7 million.
MSC shares fell 26 cents Friday to 83.28.

Elsewhere in the highly rated Retail/Wholesale-Building Products group, ranked No. 17 out of the 197 industries that IBD tracks, construction supply chain Fastenal (FAST) slid 16 cents to 54.10. Home Depot rose about 1% to 50.31.
Agriculture equipment chain Titan Machinery (TITN) was up more than 1.5% to 28.20, and rival Tractor Supply (TSCO) edged down 58 cents to 90.56.
MSC broadly distributes maintenance, repair and operating supplies, mainly in the U.S. and U.K. It also specializes in metalworking supplies to industrial customers.
The company is benefiting from general economic recovery in the U.S., including manufacturing and construction, offset in part by sluggish sales in Europe due to its ongoing debt crisis.
MSC's pace is seen slowing from earlier, headier growth. For the previous seven quarters, profit growth ranged from 27% to 71%, so the outlook for 22% growth would be the lowest rate in two years.
The company late last year revamped its management, naming Erik Gershwind, who had been with the company 16 years, as president. Gershwind also retained the post of chief operating officer.

Chief Executive David Sandler said at the time that Gershwind "has demonstrated himself to be a cultural leader with a passion for winning, for working cross-functionally, and for driving us to always do better."
At the same time, MSC promoted Eileen McGuire, a 26-year MSC veteran, to the post of executive vice president of human resources.

Stocks rapidly pared early gains ahead of Thursday's open after a soft read on weekly jobless claims and producer prices for March.Dow futures traded up 10 points but well off early highs. S&P 500 futures held just above fair market value and Nasdaq 100 futures trimmed their gains to four points.Initial jobless claims rose to 380,000 for the week ended April 7, the Department of Labor said. That was 13,000 above the prior week's upwardly revised total, and far past expectations for a decline to 355,000 claims. Ongoing claims continued to decline, down 98,000 to 3.251 million.Producer pricing strength did not improve in March, with prices unchanged for the month. Analysts expected a 0.3% gain. Prices had firmed 0.4% in February. Core prices, minus agriculture and energy, rose 0.3% — up from February's 0.2% gain and above expectations of 0.2%.On the positive side, the February trade balance narrowed to $46 billion. The deficit widened in January to $52.2 billion, and analysts had expected another gain in February, to $53 billion.Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) traded down 4% ahead of the open after reporting a light oil slick near two of the company's production areas in the Gulf of Mexico. The release reported a "light sheen," one by ten miles in size, between Shell's Mars and Ursa projects. The company said it had no indication "that the sheen originates from wells in either the Mars or Ursa projects." Shell notified the National Response Center and activated the Louisiana Responder, a Marine Spill Response Corporation (MSRC) vessel, as a precautionary measure.IBD 50 stocks traded in generally positive territory. Tractor Supply (TSCO) bolted 4% higher in premarket action. The company preannounced first-quarter results, projecting EPS of 53-55 cents, vs. consensus views for 32 cents. The company expects revenue of $1.02 billion, above the $937.4 million consensus forecast by analysts. The company cited the bulk of the gains on early spring weather. RELATEDThe stock closed Tuesday just below its April 5 high, after a strong rebound from its 10-week moving average.On the downside, Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) slipped 2%. The sports bar chain is wrestling for a second week to hold support at its 10-week moving average.Overseas, the Shanghai Composite jumped 1.8% a third straight gain. The gains followed the World Bank's downward revision to its outlook for growth in China, to 8.2% from 8.4%. The change boosted views that the government may turn its financial policy from restraint to stimulus. China is scheduled to report its first-quarter gross domestic growth data Friday.Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose 0.9%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 added 0.7%.In Europe, stocks carried modest gains through midday. The euro was little changed vs. the dollar after Italy saw reasonably healthy demand in a debt auction that sold near its 5 billion euro target.Oil rose fractionally to above $103 a barrel. Natural gas held near Wednesday's lows, below $2 per million British thermal units. Gold slipped less than 1%, to just above $1,650 an ounce.

Polaris Industries (PII) and W.W. Grainger (GWW) both reported better-than-expected earnings Wednesday, but investors had a mixed reaction. The two companies have little in common: Polaris an all-terrain vehicle maker while Grainger is a top distributor of facilities management products. But both are members of the elite IBD 50, which selects the very best companies based on fundamental and technical…
What's left to buy?

With the uptrend confirmed on Dec. 20, the market has had 25 trading days to serve up breakouts. Some stocks in the 85-85 screen are already 5% beyond their ideal buy points, which means the disciplined investor will wait for a new buy zone to emerge.
At this point in an uptrend, some investors might be tempted to lower their standards in order to find something to buy.
That's not a good idea. The opposite is true. As an uptrend ages, it makes more sense to keep to quality standards, especially in light of Thursday's weak action.
So, let's look at buy candidates in strong industry groups.
Biogen Idec (BIIB) is working on a base-on-base pattern. The base shows two weeks of net accumulation, a good sign. Trading was tight along the bottom of the base — also a good sign.
The stock has been trying to clear a long handle with an 117.65 buy point. On Jan. 20, it actually did so in 119% stronger volume. But Biogen has lingered near the buy point.

An investor who bought on the breakout hasn't made much progress. Other investors have a chance to enter while the stock is in a buy zone. But remember, don't buy this stock or any stock while it's retreating.
SolarWinds (SWI) is working on a new cup base. One drawback, though, is the lack of accumulation in the base. But it could add accumulation as it climbs the right side.
Unless the stock sketches a handle, the potential buy point is 33.78.
Tractor Supply (TSCO) could be working on a three-weeks-tight pattern, depending on Friday's action. If it completes the pattern, the buy point would be the high in the pattern plus 10 cents.
Dollar General (DG) popped above a 42.20 entry Wednesday, but volume was only 8% above average.
The above stocks were in top 20 industry groups as of Thursday's IBD.

With the market uptrend in place for nearly two months now, many leaders have already cleared bases and are extended from proper buy zones. But some are still in range or giving secondary buying setups. MasterCard (MA) is still within buying range after clearing a 385.09 buy point from a cup base cleared Feb. 3. Stocks got a leg up Tuesday, boosted by more suggestions of easy-money policy for years to come from the central bank's chief.

The Dow Jones industrial average turned a 0.5% loss into a 0.3% gain by the close. The S&P 500 moved from down 0.6% to up 0.2%. The Nasdaq, at one point showing a 0.6% decline, ended fractionally higher.
Volume increased 6% on the Nasdaq and 8% on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

Stocks turned up from the morning's small losses after Federal reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke offered remarks to the Senate Budget Committee that could only be seen as confirming his dovish monetary policies. After Friday's jobs report, many had expected Bernanke to scale back the easy-policy slant. Instead, he warned that the jobs news was not as good as it seems at first glance.

"It is very important to look not just at the unemployment rate, which reflects only people who are actively seeking work. There are also a lot of people who are either out of the labor force because they don't think they can find work," or are forced to take part-time jobs.
Consumer electronics retailers led the market, as Best Buy's (BBY) 3% climb fueled much of that advance.

Coinstar (CSTR) gapped up and soared 14% in monster volume as the stock broke out. Coinstar, which owns kiosk-based movie-renter Redbox, reported late Monday that Q4 profit jumped 47%, smashing estimates. Sales climbed 33%, also a pleasant surprise.
Coinstar also said it would acquire NCR's entertainment operations, which include Blockbuster Express rental kiosks, for up to $100 million.
Farm-and-ranch accessories retailer Tractor Supply (TSCO), an IBD Leaderboard stock, jumped 4% in heavy trade. The stock broke out of a four-weeks-tight pattern with a 82.60 buy point.

Several other Leaderboard stocks also fared well. IT management software provider SolarWinds (SWI) rocketed 9% after reporting that Q4 earnings climbed 21% vs. a year ago, beating views. Revenue surged 34%, accelerating for the third straight quarter. The company's Q1 earnings guidance was in line with expectations, while its revenue guidance topped analysts' forecasts.

SolarWinds cleared a 33.78 buy point in a base on Feb. 3. After years of being out of favor, construction stocks are making a comeback amid signs that housing starts are rebounding.

The Retail/Wholesale-Building Products group was ranked No. 1 out of 197 industry groups on Thursday, up from 90 seven months ago. Meanwhile, the building sector is ranked No. 2 out of the 33 sectors that IBD tracks.

The strong showing reflects data this week that showed homebuilder sentiment rising to its highest level since 2007. Also, housing starts are at their highest level in three years despite dipping last month. Granted, both are well below their pre-recession levels.
Your Weekly Review is sorted primarily by industry group rank, which is why some building stocks are atop the list.

Among the best stocks in the 16-member Retail/Wholesale Building Products group is Fastenal (FAST), a distributor of fasteners and other construction materials. The Minnesota-based company said Wednesday Q4 profit rose a healthy 36% on a 22% increase in revenue. The results were roughly in line with Wall Street forecasts.
The stock is trading near an all-time high after bouncing off its 10-week line in October.

Another of the group's leaders, Tractor Supply (TSCO), last week soared beyond buy points at 75.58 and 78.32 after boosting its full-year profit forecast. It's still in a buying range from the latter entry.
Both Tractor Supply and Fastenal have Composite Ratings of 99, the highest in the group.
Their Accumulation/Distribution Ratings and up/down volume ratios indicate that funds are taking up positions in the stocks.
Meanwhile,W.W. Grainger (GWW), a distributor of tools, lights and other building maintenance products, has hit new highs.

Its Relative Price Strength Rating is a lofty 96. However, profit for the October-December quarter is seen rising just 18%, which would mark the third straight quarter of deceleration. With a new market uptrend ushered in Tuesday, stocks may again be bought. But don't just buy any old name, focus on only fundamentally and technically sound issues showing accumulation.

TransDigm (TDG) is in a flat base with a 102.83 buy point. The base is the second part of a base-on-base pattern. TransDigm cleared a first-stage consolidation Nov. 8, but rose less than 20% before settling into another base. That's why the latest pattern is deemed a base on base.

During the formation of the current flat base the stock showed some positive characteristics. The stock showed some tight action and found support at its 10-week line. Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating has improved to B- from a worst-possible E in October.
The aircraft parts maker has delivered accelerating earnings and sales growth in recent quarters. TransDigm has a return on equity of 34% or double the 17% minimum seen in past big market winners.
Tractor Supply (TSCO) is also in its own base on base. Its buy point is at 78.32. The stock has slipped below its 10-week line this week in bone-dry volume.
Domestic mutual fund ownership of the farming gear retailer has swelled in recent quarters. In the latest reported period, 586 funds owned the stock. That's up from 418 funds six quarters ago.

GNC Holdings (GNC) has tested its 10-week line for the first time since clearing a second-stage base Nov. 2. Despite a recent choppy market, the stock has flashed a number of accumulation weeks, or up weeks in above-average volume.
The nutritional supplements retailer came public April 1 and has nearly doubled since.
Google's (GOOG) three-weeks-tight is turning into a possible four-weeks-tight. Either way, the stock's buy point is at 636.66.
Tight action is a positive trait. It signals support by institutions such as mutual funds and hedge funds.

Google cleared a 599.70 buy point in October. In spite of some volatility, it never triggered the 8% sell rule.With a new market uptrend ushered in Tuesday, stocks may again be bought. After a two-year slump, top home improvement chains moved back onto the fast track last year as consumers began spending more freely on items to fix up their dwellings.
At No. 1 Home Depot (HD), profits have grown by double-digit rates the past five quarters. Rival Lowe's (LOW) has seen double-digit profit gains for three of the past five quarters.

Still, sales growth remains modest at single-digit rates for both firms. But at least they're growing again after a tough stretch. Wall Street Strategies analyst Brian Sozzi says sales of smaller-ticket items like plants and lawn care products did well throughout 2010. Sales of bigger-ticket items, like appliances, began to "move a little better" in the year's second half, amid pent-up demand for products like high-priced power tools.
In Home Depot's fourth-quarter conference call, CEO Frank Blake noted that "the overall picture is one of a stabilizing business."

Craig Menear, executive vice president for merchandising, said transactions to big-ticket items of $900 and above rose 9.4% in the fourth quarter, driven by sales of products like windows and appliances.
First-Quarter Results
Sozzi expects both companies to report solid results when they issue first-quarter reports in the coming days as they benefit from a "mildly improved" housing market and strong expense controls.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters peg Home Depot's first-quarter earnings at 50 cents a share, up 11% from a year earlier. For Lowe's, they forecast a 9% gain to 37 cents a share.
"The first-quarter bottom-line trends are surprisingly strong," Sozzi said. Consumers have "come back after a bad, harsh winter and looked for items to spruce up their homes."
Sozzi says he wouldn't be surprised if both Home Depot and Lowe's beat Wall Street forecasts for sales and earnings.
BMO Capital Markets analyst Wayne Hood looks for Home Depot's first-quarter same-store sales to rise 0.5% vs. a year earlier against a difficult comparison last year when those sales jumped 4.8%.
He expects Lowe's first-quarter same-store sales to be flat against last year's strong increase of 2.4%.
"Adverse weather likely stalled the sales of outdoor seasonal merchandise and lawn and garden" during the first quarter for both companies, Hood said via email.
Last year, he says, the favorable weather helped "facilitate" some of the first-quarter growth.
Sozzi says both Lowe's and Home Depot are getting a lift from internal efforts. Recognizing that market conditions would be more challenging, Home Depot closed stores and cut jobs.

It's also taken steps to become more efficient. That includes rolling out so-called rapid deployment centers that make it easier for stores to keep the right products in stock when customers need them. Large quantities of goods from suppliers flow into these facilities and are quickly sorted and distributed to various stores.

Lowe's has implemented a "go local" strategy, by which it tailors its assortments to each market it serves. The company also throws local market customer-appreciation events. It selects markets where it sees the opportunity to gain share and invites commercial customers to an event to showcase what it can offer them through product demonstrations from key vendors.
IBD classifies Tractor Supply (TSCO) as part of IBD's Retail-Wholesale Building Products industry group (along with Lowe's and Home Depot). But the company serves a different niche and customer base.

Tractor Supply is the largest retail farm and ranch chain in the U.S. Its customers are typically hobby farmers living one or two counties away from a city who have a garden, own land and a home, and keep animals, says spokesman Randy Guiler.
Tractor Supply also serves the maintenance needs of tradesmen and small businesses. Stores offer products like pet and small-animal products, hardware, truck accessories and tools.

The company has been on a roll with double-digit sales and earnings gains the past four quarters. In the first quarter reported April 20, earnings popped 85% to 24 cents a share, topping views. Sales grew 18% to $836.6 million. Same-store sales increased 10.7%.
"We continue to have strong traffic in our stores," Guiler said. "The primary driver is the continued strength of what we call consumable, usable and edible products."
These are products customers need to support their everyday rural lifestyle: animal feed, work clothes, pet supplies.
These categories have performed well over the past few years, says Guiler, and have driven new and current customers into the stores more frequently.

To improve business and drive repeated customer visits as the economy turned south in 2008, Tractor Supply shifted gears. It switched its focus from big-ticket discretionary items like riding lawn mowers for $2,000-$5,000 to a bigger mix of lower-priced items people purchase every day.
Pet Products
As a result, animal and pet products increased to 39% of 2010 sales from 33% in 2007, according to Guiler.

"They've done a great job of managing their merchandise mix," Hood says. "A bigger piece of their business is coming from pet and livestock food, and that creates some stability in traffic and that carried them through the downturn."
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the company to stay on the fast track. They see second-quarter earnings rising 16% to $1.19 a share, with full-year earnings climbing 22% to $2.75 a share.

"We're very confident in our business," Guiler said. "We'll continue to watch closely the overall macro (environment) and gas prices. "We feel very good about about our performance over the last three years, and getting new customers and customers visiting more frequently. We're very optimistic about the business and the future."
Hood calls the environment for Lowe's and Home Depot "stable."
"They will be able to produce what I describe as slight or modest same-store sales growth," he said, "absent another downturn in the economy or a sharp increase in unemployment."
Hood sees Home Depot's 2011 same-store sales rising 2.6% from 2010, against last year's 2.9% gain.

He expects Lowe's 2011 same-store sales to rise 1.1% against last year's 1.3% increase.After a two-year slump, top home improvement chains moved back onto the fast track last year as consumers began spending more freely on items to fix up their dwellings.At No. 1 Home Depot (HD), profits have grown by double-digit rates the past five quarters.
