Stocks showed strength in midday trade Friday, as the indexes held near the day's highs in vigorous volume.The tech-heavy Nasdaq was up 0.7%, even though the Philadelphia semiconductor index was down 0.6%. The S&P 500 climbed 0.9% and the NYSE composite 1%. Volume was tracking higher on both major exchanges by more than 10%.As the indexes advance after bottoming in mid-March, it's beginning to look like the correction shuffled the deck.During the 7% to 8% market decline that began after the Feb. 18 peak, leadership changed. At the February peak, the Philadelphia semiconductor index was up 14% for the year while the major indexes were up by about half that gain.But as of midday trade Friday, the Philadelphia semiconductor index had lost the lead role. The SOX is now up only 6% for the year. The new leaders are the midcap S&P 400 and the small-cap S&P 600, up 10% and 8% respectively for the year.At midday, a slew of top-rated stocks were up in busy volume.Tractor Supply (TSCO) marked a new high in more than triple its usual trade as the stock rose 2%.  HealthSpring (HS) added 3% in more than double its average volume. NetEase.com (NTES) jumped 2% in heavy trade, though it had slipped from the day's high.Restaurant chain Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) cleared a 275.10 buy point early in the session but had retreated back in the base in midday action.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, 10 groups were up for every one that declined.

Stock futures were moderately higher Thursday on a busy morning of earnings reports.Dow futures rose 40 points before the bell. S&P 500 futures were up 5.6 points and Nasdaq 100 futures added 5.5 points.Initial jobless claims dipped by 6,000 to 403,000 for the week ended Oct. 15. That was in line with views. Continuing claims climbed 25,000 to 3.719 million. Analysts had expected 3.69 million claims.In stocks, Ebay (EBAY) fell hard despite topping third-quarter revenue estimates and meeting earnings expectations. The online auction pioneer saw its operating margin narrow to 25.3% from 28.7% the prior year, excluding some items. It offered Q4 and full-year earnings guidance in line with expectations.Among leaders, Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) rose more than 4% in pre-market trade after beating Q3 sales and profit views. The company lifted its full-year earnings guidance to above consensus views. The stock ended Wednesday 12% above a 59.17 buy point after clearing a cup base in September.Tractor Supply (TSCO) climbed 3% before the bell. It reported better-than-expected Q3 results late Wednesday. The building, feed and garden supply chain has been holding below a 70.20 buy point in a three-month, cup-with-handle base.Microsoft (MSFT),  AthenaHealth (ATHN), Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Informatica (INFA) are a few of the stocks expected to report quarterly results after the market close.European stocks carried moderate losses into afternoon trade, despite the euro slipping vs. the dollar. Oil rose a fraction. Gold dipped more than 1%, pointing to a possible fourth straight decline. Agricultural commodities were mixed.Markets in China fell hard overnight, as China's airlines sold off following reports that the country's Civil Aviation Administration had cut its 2011 passenger count growth estimate to 8% from 13%.The Shanghai composite dumped 1.9%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 1.8%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dipped 1%.

Stock futures pushed firmly higher Thursday on upbeat news about weekly jobless claims and second-quarter economic growth.Dow futures rose 141 points in the pre-market. S&P 500 futures gained 14.9 points and Nasdaq 100 futures added 28.75 points.The economy grew 1.3% in the second quarter, according to the Commerce Department's third revision for the quarter. Analysts had expected a revised number of 1.2%. Real consumption expenditures climbed 0.7% for the quarter, down sharply from the first quarter's 2.1% gain.Initial jobless claims decreased 9% to 391,000 in the week ended Sept. 24. That was much better than analyst expectations for 419,000 claims. Continuing claims dropped to 3.729 million from 3.749 million.In Europe, assurance against a Greek default took a big step forward Thursday as German lawmakers voted to approve expansion of the European Financial Stability Facility, nearly doubling its lending power to $595 billion.The remaining 16 euro-zone governments still need to approve the measure. But the support of Germany, which boasts Europe's biggest economy, was a necessary first step in the process.Elsewhere, oil edged higher, gold slipped a notch and agricultural commodities were mixed in early trade.Blue chips moved higher, led by American Express's (AXP) 2% gain.Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) plummeted 9% ahead of the opening bell after halving its Q3 sales guidance late Wednesday. Bank Of America Merrill Lynch also cut the chip maker's rating to underperform. Shares have been mired in a consolidation since May.Nokia  (NOK) rose 3% after announcing plans to cut an additional 3,500 jobs, most of which are tied to the manufacturing plant the cell phone maker intends to close in Cluj, Romania. In April, the company said it would eliminate 4,000 jobs as part of a cost-cutting program.Among leaders, Tractor Supply Co. (TSCO) jumped more than 2% in premarket action. The building, gardening and farm supplies retailer is just below a 67.34 buy point in a first stage, cup-with-handle base.

The new highs Monday were spread over a variety of sectors, from utilities to retail. But in media, there were some interesting chart plots. Major companies such as News Corp. (NWS), Disney (DIS) and Viacom (VIAB) joined smaller players such as Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) in reaching 52-week price levels. There wasn't much news in the sector, but Scripps Networks…
Stocks surged, and volume on the Nasdaq appeared to be just above Tuesday's level. If volume remains higher once final figures come in, Wednesday will be a follow-through day.

Wall Street's losses deepened in early afternoon trading Monday as weaker-than-expected U.S. factory orders outweighed hopes that Germany would come to the aid of embattled eurozone countries. The Nasdaq was down 0.6%, erasing an earlier slight gain, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.8% and the Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.6%. Volume was 10% lower on the Nasdaq and…

Farmer demand for combines and tractors in the upper Midwest boosted first-quarter sales for dealership chain Titan Machinery (TITN). But rising costs cut into earnings, and its guidance range merely bracketed analyst views. Shares tumbled 19.2% to 26.91. The equipment seller earned 36 cents, down from 40 cents a year ago and 2 cents shy of analyst forecasts. Sales climbed…

Fastenal (FAST) shares fell 9.5% to 39.23 in afternoon trading after it reported weak May sales, a sign the economy may be weakening. The industrial supplies distributor said sales rose 18.4% in May to $274.8 million. But investors were expecting more from the company during its historically strong month. Now Fastenal will have to post $288.35 million in June sales…

Stocks on Wednesday returned to their losing ways of the past month, giving up all of their gains from Tuesday's rally and some of last week's advance. The NYSE composite shed 1.9% and is back down for the year. The S&P 500 fell 1.4% and the Nasdaq 1.2%. Volume increased slightly on both main exchanges. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq…
Stocks slouched Wednesday as Europe continued to struggle to find a credible government-debt strategy.
The NYSE composite dived 1.9% while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average stumbled 1.4% and 1.3% respectively. The Nasdaq trimmed 1.2%.
Volume rose slightly on the Nasdaq and dipped on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

On the S&P 100, an index composed of bigger and well-established companies, drilling services provider Halliburton (HAL) took the hardest price hit. The stock fell 5%. Trade, though, was only 4% above average. The price of crude oil dropped more than 3% to its lowest level in almost seven months.
On the IBD 50, a proxy for leading stocks, more than seven stocks fell for every one that rose.

Ranch and farm supplies store Tractor Supply (TSCO) fell hard in heavy volume for a second straight day. The stock shed 3% in more than twice its usual volume. On Tuesday, it skidded 7% lower in 354% faster trade. The hard-hit leader is now 11% off its 52-week high.
Oil services provider Core Laboratories (CLB) sliced under its 50-day moving average in 156% heavier volume. The stock lost 6% to 128.97.
Big Cap 20 member eBay (EBAY) slammed almost 5%. The stock is consolidating above its 50-day line.
Chip designer Cirrus Logic (CRUS), which broke out of a square box Tuesday, gave back 3% in 35% faster action. The stock is barely above a 28.35 buy point.
Among IBD's 197 industry groups, only four rose even modestly. Oil, specialty steel and homebuilders were among the hardest-hit groups.

Homebuilders were hurt by news that pending home sales dropped 5.5%. The Street's consensus view was expecting a 0.5% gain, and even the most bearish estimated a 2% drop. Meanwhile in Europe, Spain was moving into the top slot for worries over government debt.

Thursday's economic calendar includes three readings on the jobs market: the weekly unemployment claims number, the Challenger layoff report and the ADP payrolls report. In addition, the Institute of Supply Management's Chicago-area survey will be out shortly after the opening bell. A late-hour slide saddled U.S. stocks with mild losses in mixed volume Tuesday. The sell-off snuffed out a very mild rally following news of a dip in U.S. home prices and consumer confidence. The Nasdaq reversed from a 0.3% intraday gain to a loss of less than 0.1%. It's up 19.8% with three trading days left in the first quarter…

The world's largest retailer on Monday launched its AmazonSupply, with more than 500,000 items that run the gamut from drill bits to laboratory centrifuges. Stocks were higher early Monday afternoon, shrugging off weaker-than-expected housing data, after Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke made dovish comments. The Nasdaq added to its six-week gain, rising 1.2% to a fresh 11-year high. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.9% each. Volume was tracking higher on the Nasdaq but lower on the NYSE from Friday's…
Stocks were higher at midday Monday, shrugging off weaker-than-expected housing data, after Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke made dovish comments.

The Nasdaq added to its six-week gain, rising 1.1% to an 11-year high. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1% each. Volume was tracking sharply higher across the board from Friday's pace.

Caterpillar (CAT) and IBM (IBM) were each up 1%, pacing the Dow. Caterpillar has struggled since clearing a 114.75 buy point. It's now 5% below the entry and is testing support at its 50-day moving average.
In economic news, the National Association of Realtors said pending home sales unexpectedly fell 0.5% in February. Economists expected a 0.5% rise.

IT management tools provider SolarWinds (SWI) gapped up and bolted 8% to a new high in heavy trading. It cleared a 39.85 buy point from a square-box base. The square box is one of the shorter patterns that takes only four weeks to form. SolarWinds is No. 10 in this week's IBD 50.

Polaris Industries (PII) followed through from Friday's breakout. It added 3% to a new high and stands 3% past a 70.41 buy point in a base-on-base pattern. The maker of snowmobiles and all-terrain vehicles will report Q1 earnings April 18. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit rising 15% vs. a year ago to 77 cents a share.
Tractor Supply (TSCO) jumped 4% to an all-time high in fast trade. It's now 9% past an 82.60 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern cleared Feb. 7. Tractor Supply cleared a flat base in January.

Nearly all IBD 50 stocks were higher. Another big winner was Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD), which rose 6% to a new high in strong volume. The IBD Leaderboard stock shot past resistance at 90 and is extended from all its recent buy points.
Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and Silicon Motion Technology (SIMO) were among a very small group of losers within the IBD 50.

Stocks reversed modest losses and scored small gains Tuesday on reports of progress over Greece's bailout. After the close, Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) surged after the company delivered Q4 earnings and sales that topped expectations. But Panera Bread (PNRA) was little changed after reporting mixed results. Profit met views, but revenue missed. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq rose 0.2% and…
Stocks climbed early Thursday afternoon after new claims for U.S. jobless benefits fell and Greece made progress toward a bailout to keep the government from defaulting on its debt.
The Nasdaq was up 0.3%, the S&P 500 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.1%. Volume rose 14% on the Nasdaq and was slightly higher on the NYSE compared with the same time Wednesday.

Greek politicians and creditors appeared to have reached an agreement allowing further financial assistance for Athens from European Union countries. The overdue agreement was considered crucial before a meeting of European Union ministers scheduled for this evening.
Meanwhile, new claims for U.S. jobless benefits fell by a greater-than-expected 15,000 last week to 358,000, the Labor Department said, the latest sign that the job market is healing.

Network solutions provider Akamai Technologies (AKAM) gapped up 9% after reporting Q4 earnings rose 12% to 45 cents a share, a nickel above consensus views. Revenue of $324 million was up 15% vs. the year ago quarter. Analysts had expected $311.3 million.
The stock has been climbing since October, building the right side to a 15-month consolidation.

Lorillard (LO) lit up more than 9%, clearing a 120.10 buy point in a flat base that may also be part of a base on base. The cigarette producer turned in earnings of $2.20 a share, up 26% and a quarter above the consensus estimate. A 10% revenue jump to $1.13 billion was also better than expected.

Drugmaker Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) rose 4% after releasing better-than-expected fourth-quarter results. Its 2012 revenue forecast was also on the high side of estimates. The company said strong demand for Soliris, used to treat a rare blood disease, drove earnings.

Meanwhile, Visa (V), the world's largest credit card processor, climbed 5% after fiscal first-quarter profit and sales topped forecasts. The company also announced plans to buy back $500 million of its shares this year.
Visa and Alexion were the top performers among IBD 50 stocks.

Nuance Communications (NUAN) was up 3% ahead of its fiscal first-quarter results. Profit at the maker of speech recognition software believed to be used in Apple's (AAPL)Siri voice-command system for mobile phones was expected to rise 29% vs. a year earlier.
The stock is extended past a 25.92 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Apple jumped 4% in strong volume following a report that it will announce its next-generation iPad tablet during the first week of March, about a year after it debuted the current model, iPad 2. The new tablet is expected to have a faster processor and higher resolution display, according to website All Things D.

On the downside, Groupon (GRPN) gapped down 13% after Q4 earnings trailed analyst estimates. Shares of banking giants and home improvement retailers were little changed in early trading in the stock market after August housing starts rose less than expected while weekly mortgage applications rebounded.

Housing starts in August rose 0.9% from the previous month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 891,000 units in August, the Commerce Department reported. July's starts were revised down to 883,000 units from 896,000 units. Economists expected 917,000 units in August.

Also Wednesday, applications for U.S. home loans rose 11.2% in the week ended Sept. 13, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. That followed a 13.5% decline the previous week to a five-year low. Refinancings have tumbled since early May, when Federal Reserve taper talk pushed rates higher. Applications for buying a home have also retreated, but not nearly as much.
Applications last week were helped by a slight dip in average 30-year mortgage rates, which eased 5 basis points to 4.75% from a 2013 high of 4.8% the prior week.

Both Wells Fargo (WFC) and JPMorgan (JPM) this month have warned of a big drop in mortgage originations this quarter, with Bank of America (BAC) cutting jobs due to slackening demand. Shares of all three banking giants were little changed in early morning trading, as investors awaited the Fed's policy announcement.

In terms of housing starts, the main negative involved starts for multifamily homes, which fell 11.1% to a 263,000-unit rate. On the upside, starts for single-family homes rose 7% to a 628,000-unit pace, the highest since February.
The decline in multifamily starts might be attributable to a months-long rise in mortgage interest rates.

Permits to build homes dipped 3.8% in August to a 918,000-unit pace, below estimates for a 950,000-unit pace. Again, the decline was mainly due to a 15.7% drop in multifamily permits. Single-family permits rose. And permits are above starts, suggesting more construction in the months ahead.
Housing starts are an important metric for home improvement retailers, which benefit from new construction.

Shares of Home Depot (HD), the nation's biggest home improvement retailer, rose 0.3% to 76.04 in early trading Wednesday. The Atlanta-based company's stock price has gone sideways since the second week of May despite its record of solid financial growth.

No. 2 Lowe's (LOW) fell 5 cents to 46.80. Its stock price has been trending higher all year and hit a record high of 47.58 on Sept. 11. Last quarter, Lowe's turned in its best performance in a year and a half when it boosted earnings 35% year over year and sales 10%.

The 15 stocks in IBD's Retail/Wholesale-Building Products group hit a record high on Monday. Companies in the group that have established new highs in recent weeks include W.W. Grainger (GWW), Tractor Supply (TSCO) and Lumber Liquidators (LL).
The housing starts report was the second of three industry reports to be released this week.
On Tuesday, the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index for September matched the prior month's reading but fell short of consensus estimates.

On Thursday, the National Association of Realtors releases its report on August existing-home sales. The stock market closed mixed Friday after indexes bounced back from an early slump. The Nasdaq rose 0.2% thanks to strength in biotechs, security software and solar stocks.The S&P; 500 fell 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average lagged with a 0.3% drop and closed near session lows.Small caps paced the market: The small-cap Russell 2000 climbed 0.6%. Volume rose on the NYSE and edged lower on the Nasdaq, according to early figures.After a serious decline the prior day, Friday's price reversals were encouraging. Yet the market remained locked in a long sideways trend.Stocks sank at the open as a better-than-expected jobs report for May triggered a slide in bond prices.Energy stocks rose after OPEC left its output targets unchanged, as expected. Solar shares jumped after China-based JA Solar 's (JASO) chief executive offered to buy the company and take it private.Financials also helped lead the stock market today. Bank of America (BAC) rose more than 2% and closed back near a 24.88 buy point. JPMorgan (JPM) rose 2% and hit a new high. Thinly traded BofI Holdings (BOFI) rose 2% and topped the 97.78 buy point of a long cup-with-handle base.It was a strong day for the IBD 50, with the average component up about 1.3%. Volume was just average or light for most of the 50 stocks, though.

Despite weaker-than-expected December retail sales, retail-related groups remain some of the market's best performers.This week's IBD 50 list has 14 retail stocks, the most from any industry group. Some top-ranked retailers are near buy points.Deep discount retailer Dollar Tree (DLTR) closed tightly for the sixth straight week and has support at its 10-week moving average. The stock is slightly below an 84.09 four-weeks-tight buy point cleared Dec. 27.Tight trading is a sign of support from professionals such as mutual funds and hedge funds. Domestic fund ownership has grown to 974 funds, up from 853 three quarters ago. Top funds including Columbia Marsico 21st and Fidelity Contrafund and Fidelity Magellan have positions in Dollar Tree.Rival Dollar General (DG) is just above a 40.81 flat base buy point. It found support at its 10-week moving average in the latest week. Dollar Tree initially cleared the buy point Dec. 1, but did so in weak volume. It didn't get very far before pulling back.One drawback among dollar-store chains is sales growth. Top-line growth at Dollar Tree and Dollar General have ranged from the low single digits to the low teens in the most recent quarters. Generally, CAN SLIM stocks should have quarterly revenue growth of at least 25%.Hibbett Sports (HIBB) tried to break out last week. It passed a 47.32 buy point from a square box in soft volume Thursday. Turnover should be at least 40% above average on a breakout. It's now about 2% below that trigger.The Birmingham, Ala.-based firm has found a niche selling sporting goods in small and midsize towns. In November, the retailer beat views with a 34% gain in Q3 earnings and an 11% gain in sales.For the week, IBD 50 stocks rose 2.3% on average.Tractor Supply (TSCO) was the best performing IBD 50 stock. An upbeat sales report and outlook helped the stock clear a base-on-base pattern. It blew past buy points at 75.58 and 78.32.A strong outlook also helped yoga apparel and accessories retailer Lululemon (LULU) to its best week in more than a year. Buyers have returned, but Lululemon is in a late-stage pattern.

Stocks remained mixed early Wednesday afternoon as investors weighed a strong gain in housing starts against weak earnings at IBM (IBM) and Intel (INTC). The S&P 500 rose 0.4% and the Nasdaq rose 0.3%. The Dow Jones industrial average fell a fraction. Volume was down 2% on the Nasdaq and 3% on the NYSE compared with the same time Tuesday.…

UPDATE ON TUESDAY, NOV. 15: A few Top 10 stocks were flirting with new highs, but volume was unimpressive in each case.
While a new high in low volume can be a sell sign, an investor can't reasonably expect every new high to come in strong trade. Look for a pattern in the stock's recent new highs.
Robotics surgery equipment maker Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) poked almost 2% higher in light volume. The stock has been trading in a tight range since its Oct. 19 gap-up breakout.
Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR)  also nudged upward almost 2% in light trade.
Randgold Resources (GOLD) was just under a new high. The stock didn't draw big volume on its breakout and hasn't seen it kick in bigtime yet.
MasterCard (MA) probed a new high in slow trade. The credit card stock hasn't attracted much volume in recent sessions.
All-terrain vehicle maker Polaris Industries (PII) rose in sluggish volume and was near a new high.
ORIGINAL STORY OF NOV. 14:
SolarWinds: Red Hot In Choppy Market
Headlines out of Europe have made for the tough market environment. But in spite of the volatility, some leaders are making headway.

SolarWinds  (SWI) has been on fire since clearing a 25.72 buy point from a double-bottom base Oct. 27. In a short period, the stock has rallied as much as 22% from the breakout. That puts its well extended from proper buying range.
But investors who are in the stock should take heed. SolarWinds triggered a key IBD rule: Stocks that rally 20% or more in three weeks or less should be held at least eight weeks.
The eight-week rule was designed to help investors avoid the agony of selling a possible big winner too soon.
Stocks that sprint out of the gate and rise 20% or more are showing you that buyers have a healthy appetite.

In SolarWinds' case, it's showing professional buying. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has climbed to B+ from E in late September. And its up/down volume ratio improved for the fourth straight week to 1.5.
Speaking of appetite, Panera Bread  (PNRA) is holding steady after surging out of a first-stage cup base. It's 2% past a 133.53 buy point and in the buy zone up to 140.21.
The stock's trading range has dramatically tightened after a big week three weeks ago. Panera's relative strength line is also near new-high ground.

In late October, the operator of bakery-cafes beat expectations with a 29% gain in Q3 earnings. Sales grew 22%, marking the second straight period of acceleration as well as the biggest gain in years.

Tractor Supply (TSCO) is rebounding off its 10-week line. That's its first test of the key technical area since breaking out of a cup-with-handle base Oct. 20. The stock closed at a new high Friday, but volume was light.

Deckers Outdoor (DECK) is also testing its 10-week line. It's doing so in quiet volume, which is good. For the week, 29 IBD 50 components finished higher. The average change was a scant 0.1%. Bellwethers such as Apple (AAPL), Baidu (BIDU) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) lost ground.

But Priceline.com (PLCN) mustered a 4% gain on a big spike in volume. The stock is still in a choppy, late-stage base.UPDATE ON TUESDAY, NOV. 15: A few Top 10 stocks were flirting with new highs, but volume was unimpressive in each case. Stocks rumbled ahead in rising volume Tuesday, but the checkered action among the day's breakouts still left doubts about the market's condition. Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video! The Nasdaq jumped 2.2%, the NYSE composite 1.5% and the S&P 500 1.3%. The average gain in the IBD 50…
Stocks weakened in late trading, with the major averages sinking back into negative territory, after the Fed's beige book.
The report of regional economic activity found modest growth in all 12 districts. Labor conditions, however, remained lackluster, thus leaving an uncertain outlook.

The Nasdaq widened its loss to 2%. Apple (AAPL) continued to be a drag. The stock accounts for about 8% of the tech-heavy index. The S&P 500 lost 1%, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.5%. Volume was tracking sharply higher on the Nasdaq. NYSE trade was tracking a touch lower.

First Cash Financial Services (FCFS) erased earlier gains and dropped 6% in heavy trading. It was up as much as 3% on the heels of better-than-expected Q3 results and a higher full-year profit outlook. The company announced plans to buy a pawnshop chain in Indiana. First Cash has met resistance at its 50-day moving average and the 45 level recently.

Wynn Resorts (WYNN) fell 2% ahead of its third-quarter results after the close. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see earnings bolting 203% to $1.18 a share. Sales are slated to rise 28% to about $1.29 billion. Results from operations in Macau will be key because the bulk of its revenue comes from China's special administrative region. The stock has also encountered resistance at its 50-day line in recent sessions.

Tractor Supply (TSCO) lost 2% ahead of its quarterly results after the close. The farming equipment retailer is expected to earn 52 cents a share, up 21% from a year ago. Sales are slated to grow 13% to $933.2 million. The stock is shaping a first-stage cup-with-handle base with a 70.20 buy point.

Nuance Communications (NUAN) pared an earlier 5% gain to 1%. Late Tuesday, the software maker boosted its Q4 sales outlook and announced a $600 million convertible debt offering. Despite the retreat, the stock is still 11% past a 21.48 buy point cleared Oct. 6.Stocks weakened in late trading, with the major averages sinking back into negative territory, after the Fed's beige book.The report of regional economic activity found modest growth in all 12 districts. Stocks continued to trade in mixed territory late Thursday.The NYSE composite and the S&P 500 fell 0.4% and 0.2%, respectively. But the Nasdaq continued to buck the trend, rising 0.4%. NYSE volume was tracking higher, while Nasdaq trade was tracking a little lower.Silver Wheaton (SLW) dropped 4% in heavy trading. The stock erased Wednesday's advance and breached its 50-day moving average. Silver Wheaton now sits 17% off its December record high. It nearly doubled after breaking out Aug. 26. Silver futures fell 1%.Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) fell 4% in fast trade after being downgraded. Macquarie cut shares to neutral from outperform, citing a currently balanced risk-and-reward scenario. The stock dipped under a 47.18 three-weeks-tight buy point cleared Monday. Check Point reports Q4 earnings Jan. 31. Analysts see the security software maker's profit rising 13% to 69 cents a share.Tractor Supply (TSCO) cut an earlier 5% loss to just over 1%. Still, the stock triggered the 8% sell rule intraday after clearing a 49.57 buy point from a three-weeks-tight formation cleared Monday.On the upside, Cavium Networks (CAVM) jumped 4% to a record high in heavy turnover. The stock is again following through after clearing a 40.22 buy point from a square-box base Monday. Cavium makes integrated circuits for the networking, storage and wireless markets.Elsewhere, metal recycler Schnitzer Steel Industries (SCHN) reports fiscal Q1 results after the close. Analysts see profit surging 209% to 71 cents a share. Sales are slated to rise 72% to $676.5 million.

Stocks ended a ho-hum session with a bang Monday, finishing near session highs ahead of Alcoa's earnings report after the close. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each rose 0.6% and the Dow lagged slightly, rising 0.3%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in about 15-20% lower than Friday.

After the close, aluminum producer Alcoa (AA) reported mixed results. The company earned 11 cents a share, up 10% from a year ago and 3 cents ahead of views. But sales fell 3% to $5.83 billion, slightly below the consensus estimate of $5.89 billion. Shares fell 1% in early after-hours trading.
Overall, it's fairly quiet this week on the earnings front but two high-profile financials report on Friday: J.P. Morgan Chase & Company (JPM) and Wells Fargo (WFC).

Speaking of financials, in the stock market today, asset managers BlackRock (BLK) and Affiliated Managers Group (AMG) outperformed. BlackRock added 1.5% in light volume and Affiliated Managers Group rose 2% in average volume. Both stocks have been consolidating gains for just over three weeks and continue to hold just above their 10-week moving averages.

On the merger and acquisition front, General Electric (GE) announced plans to buy oilfield pump maker Lufkin Industries (LUFK) for $3.3 billion. The deal values Lufkin at $88.50 per share, a premium of 38% above Friday's close. Shares of Lufkin surged 38% in big volume. GE added 08% in heavy volume. GE's presence in the oil and gas industry continues to grow. The segment is now the third-largest by revenue behind GE's power/water and aviation units.

Other gainers Monday included Dunkin' Brands (DNKN). It extended gains after last week's breakout from a second-stage base, rising 1% in quick trade, but still has its all-time high to contend with at 40. Dunkin's chart is bullish and growth prospects are pretty good as the company continues to expand, but earnings and sales growth has decelerated for two quarters in a row.

Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) recovered after last week's 6% loss, rallying 3% in light volume. The stock hasn't looked back after a big breakout in November over 33.25. It continues to hold above its 10-week moving average around 51.

United Rentals (URI) outperformed Monday, rising 3% in slightly below-average volume. It's been consolidating gains for just over six weeks. While trading has been somewhat erratic in recent weeks, it's only corrected about 15% off its recent high. That means its current structure still qualifies as a flat base.

Tractor Supply (TSCO) extended gains after Friday's low-volume breakout, rising 2.5% in double-average volume. Its weekly chart might look like a late-stage breakout, but Tractor Supply reset its base count in August 2011 so it's not as late stage as it looks.

Finally, at the New York Mercantile Exchange, June gold settled at $1,572.50 an ounce, down $3.40 or 0.2%. May crude oil added 66 cents, or 0.7%, to settle at $93.36 a barrel.Stocks ended a ho-hum session with a bang Monday, finishing near session highs ahead of Alcoa's earnings report after the close. Stock futures eased lower ahead of Friday's open, as the dollar gained and Q4 GDP data came in below expectations.Dow futures slipped 17.2 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were off 2.3 points. Nasdaq futures shifted from gains to a 1.5-point loss an hour before the start of regular trade.Stock Market TodayThe stock market today starts with the Nasdaq steering toward its worst week since October, down 3.2% through Thursday. The S&P 500 opens with a 2.5% loss for the week. Both indexes are testing support at their 50-day moving averages while toting a hefty count of seven distribution days each.The Nasdaq may be gathering itself to again challenge resistance at the 5000 level. But maintaining support at the 50-day line will be the crucial test on Friday.Economic NewsThe Commerce Department reported its estimate for Q4 GDP growth was 2.2%, unchanged from prior estimates, but below economist projections for an upward revision to 2.4%. The GDP price deflator inflation gauge held steady, up 0.1%, in line with expectations.A final reading on March consumer sentiment is expected from the University of Michigan at 10 a.m. ET. Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen is scheduled to speak in San Francisco, beginning at 3:45 p.m. ET.StocksOlin (OLN) rocketed 20% higher on news that Dow Chemical (DOW) would merge its chlorine operations with Olin. The companies expect the deal, valued at $5 billion, to form an industry leader in chloralkali processing, producing vinyl, chlorinated organics and epoxy.Dow shares rose 6% in premarket trade. Olin had pulled back below a 15-month high after briefly clearing a long-term consolidation. Dow has been consolidating since September.Restoration Hardware (RH) slumped more than 4% ahead of the opening bell. The Corte Madera, Calif.-based chain reported late Thursday a narrow Q4 earnings beat and sales in line with expectations. Q1 guidance was below analyst targets. The stock has been forming a base-on-base cup, ending Thursday back above its 10-week line of support.Yahoo (YHOO) added nearly 2% after its late Thursday announcement of a $2 billion share buyback initiative. The company reported the new program was in addition to the $726 million in buybacks still active under its previous plan.Morgan Stanley launched coverage on the stock with an overweight rating and a 55 price target. Yahoo shares have been working to retake their 10-week moving average, within a four-month consolidation.OverseasChina's markets ended relatively flat on Friday after a week that left the Shanghai Composite up 2% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index with a 2.7% gain. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dipped 1% on Friday to end the week little changed.Leading indexes in Paris and Frankfurt were up nearly 1%. London's FTSE 100 showed a 0.3% loss near midday. For the week, the CAC-40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX were tracking toward 1% losses. The FTSE 100 traded 2.1% below last Friday's close.Currencies/CommoditiesThe dollar gained on the yen and sent the euro back below 1.09. Oil pulled back, almost 2% for the U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude, to below $51, and 1% for Europe's Brent crude, to below $59.

Stocks traded in a tight range Tuesday in quiet action, but top-rated stocks told a different story.The Nasdaq added 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and the NYSE composite trimmed 0.2% and 0.3%, respectively. The Philadelphia semiconductor index slid 1.1%.Volume was down about 10% on both major exchanges — sleepy action considering Friday's pre-holiday pace.Leaders, however, were showing strong action. Fifteen stocks in the IBD 50 were attracting heavy volume — mostly on the upside.Hitting new highs in fast trade were payday loan chain  EZCorp (EZPW), mattress maker  Tempur-Pedic (TPX), managed care provider Amerigroup (AGP) and farm-equipment store chain Tractor Supply (TSCO).On the downside, soda and energy drink company Hansen Natural (HANS) slipped 1% in 45% quicker trade.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, gold and oil stocks were strong. Super regional banks were weak.

After some early choppiness, stocks found their footing Tuesday and climbed into positive territory.The Nasdaq was up 0.3%, the S&P 500 and NYSE composite each rose 0.1%. The Philadelphia semiconductor index jumped 2.7%, bringing it just under its 50-day moving average.Advancing issues, though, were narrowly trailing losers on the Nasdaq, while winners had a modest advantage on the NYSE. Top-rated stocks were about evenly split between winners and losers.Retail apparel chain Lululemon Athletica (LULU) pressed ahead 3% in almost triple volume.  Tractor Supply (TSCO) was up about 1% in 42% quicker action; it appears to be en route to its 10th straight daily gain.Quite a few leaders, however, were slipping in fast trade. Software stocks Aruba Networks (ARUN) and  OpenText (OTEX) skidded 6% and 4%, respectively. Mining equipment maker Joy Global (JOYG) fell 3%.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, retail, chips and gold stocks were strong. Farm equipment stocks were weak.

Stock futures continued plowing deeper amid concerns over Japan and the Middle East.Dow futures swooned 269 points before the bell. S&P 500 futures fell 35 points and Nasdaq 100 futures backed off 69 points. All were below fair valueOil prices dipped lower, trading in a range between $96.71 and $101.87 a barrel. Gold fell below $1,386 an ounce. The dollar fell vs. the euro but climbed off its four-month low against the yen as the Bank of Japan pumped more funds into its ravaged economy.The Empire State Manufacturing Index for the New York region had a reading of 17.5 in March, up from 15.43 in February. Analysts expected a reading of 17. The New York State Reserve Bank reported the new order index slipped to 5.8, down from 11.8 in February.The National Association of Home Builder's March housing market index is due out at 10 a.m. EDT. The Federal Open Market Committee is scheduled to announce it decision on interest rates at 2:15 p.m. EDT.Leading stocks faced stiff selling pressure in pre-market action. Among the worst hit were Silver Wheaton (SLW), Aruba Networks (ARUN), Tractor Supply (TSCO) and Northern Oil & Gas (NOG). All dropped more than 7%.Netflix  (NFLX) was the only IBD 50 stock to gain ground in pre-market trade, adding almost 1%. The online and mail delivery movie rental service has been correcting for four weeks. It is working to regain support at its 10-week moving average.

Stocks eased in late trading Wednesday, but all of the major averages continued to hold gains of 1% or better.The NYSE composite climbed 1.5%, Dow 1.4%, S&P 500 1.2% and Nasdaq 1%. Volume was tracking lower on both exchanges.SXC Health Solutions (SXCI) gapped up, rallied 6% and regained its 50-day moving average. Before the open, the provider of pharmacy benefits management services signed a three-year contract valued at $720 million. The stock is working on a new base and its Accumulation/Distribution Rating has improved to B- from C- in late September.Netflix (NFLX) reversed earlier losses and rose 2% ahead of its quarterly results after the close. According to Thomson Reuters, the entertainment firm is expected to earn 71 cents a share on $550.9 million. The stock broke out from a double-bottom base in August and is settling into another consolidation.Tractor Supply (TSCO) and eBay (EBAY) will also report Q3 results after the close.On the downside, Altera (ALTR) lost 3% after shedding early gains. It turned lower despite late Tuesday's strong Q3 report and outlook. The stock fell below a 29.15 buy point from a base-on-base pattern.

Stocks stepped back in light volume Thursday as the market awaited Fed chief Ben Bernanke's speech Friday. The Nasdaq lopped off 1.1%, while the S&P 500, NYSE composite and Dow Jones industrial average each fell 0.8%. The small cap S&P 600 index fell 1%, ending a four-session win streak. The IBD 50 fell 1.1%. Volume declined on both major exchanges.…

The nation's largest home improvement and building supplies retailer is slated to announce second-quarter earnings results Tuesday before the market opens. Investors will look to see whether Home Depot (HD) and other building supplies companies like Lowe's (LOW), Fastenal (FAST) and W.W. Grainger (GWW) are participating in the housing industry recovery, which has picked up steam in recent monthshttp://news.investors.com/article/621442/201208081553/housing-recovery-gains-steam-pushing-builders-higher.htm?Ntt=homebuilder. Building materials supplier Fastenal (FAST) is expected to record a 16% jump in profit to 37 cents a share when it reports second-quarter results before the market opens Thursday. The company operates more than 2,500 construction supply stores, and is seen as a bellwether for the construction and housing industries. Fastenal has set a high bar for performance, having met…
While the Nasdaq pared some losses, stocks still traded firmly in the red in late-afternoon action Wednesday. A raft of discouraging headlines continues to weigh on sentiment.

The S&P 500 lost 1.3%, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.2%. The Nasdaq shed 1%, after trading as much as 1.6% lower. Volume was tracking down slightly from Wednesday's levels on both main exchanges.
Cirrus Logic (CRUS) slid 3% in big trade, giving up some of its gains from Wednesday's 7% pop. The chip designer is also holding above a 28.35 buy point that it cleared Wednesday.
Facebook (FB) also lost ground, slipping 2%. The stock, which began trading on the Nasdaq on May 18, has touched a new low Wednesday. The social network is about 25% below its offering price of 38.

Tractor Supply (TSCO) continued its recent sell-off, falling 3% in heavy volume and hitting a two-month low. The retailer had been consolidating above its 50-day moving average, but it's tumbled below that level this week.

Teavana (TEA) dropped 17% in heavy volume, as the specialty tea retailer reported first-quarter revenue that missed forecasts, even as revenue grew 27% to $44 million. Earnings per share rose 11% to 10 cents, matching estimates but slowing from gains of 33% and 100% in the preceding quarters. The July IPO has dropped to an all-time low.

Research In Motion (RIMM), the former stock market leader turned basket case, tumbled 7% in huge volume after the company on Tuesday predicted an operating loss for the current quarter. Wall Street had been expecting a profit. The BlackBerry smartphone maker's IBD Composite Rating is a weak 15, not far from the worst-possible grade of 1.

On the upside, Fresh Market (TFM) soared 13% in huge turnover, as the upscale grocer reported first-quarter profit rose 33% to 40 cents a share, 4 cents over views. Revenue grew 23% to $325 million, also above forecasts. The company hiked its full-year profit target. The stock cleared a 55.07 buy point from a somewhat odd-shaped square-box pattern out of the gate Thursday and is currently holding above that level.

In economic news, the National Association of Realtors reported a worse-than-expected 5.5% decrease in pending home sales for April. The consensus view was for a 0.5% gain. Even the lowball estimate for a 2% drop proved far too bullish.

Reuters reported that yields on 10-year Spanish bonds moved closer to 7%, the level at which other nations in the eurozone were forced to seek a bailout. Italian 10-year yields topped 6% for the first time since a January bond sale.

The latest poll from Greece showed a leftist party has taken the lead over the pro-bailout forces ahead of a national parliamentary election next month. China's official news agency Xinhua reported government officials were backpedaling on a large-scale stimulus.While the Nasdaq pared some losses, stocks still traded firmly in the red in late-afternoon action Wednesday. A raft of discouraging headlines continues to weigh on sentiment.The S&P 500 lost 1.3%, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.2%. The Nasdaq shed 1%, after trading as much as 1.6% lower. Volume was tracking down slightly from Wednesday's levels on both main exchanges.Cirrus Logic (CRUS) slid 3% in big trade, giving up some of its gains from Wednesday's 7% pop. The chip designer is also holding above a 28.35 buy point that it cleared Wednesday.Facebook (FB) also lost ground, slipping 2%. The stock, which began trading on the Nasdaq on May 18, has touched a new low Wednesday. The social network is about 25% below its offering price of 38.Tractor Supply (TSCO) continued its recent sell-off, falling 3% in heavy volume and hitting a two-month low. The retailer had been consolidating above its 50-day moving average, but it's tumbled below that level this week.Teavana (TEA) dropped 17% in heavy volume, as the specialty tea retailer reported first-quarter revenue that missed forecasts, even as revenue grew 27% to $44 million. Earnings per share rose 11% to 10 cents, matching estimates but slowing from gains of 33% and 100% in the preceding quarters. The July IPO has dropped to an all-time low.Research In Motion (RIMM), the former stock market leader turned basket case, tumbled 7% in huge volume after the company on Tuesday predicted an operating loss for the current quarter. Wall Street had been expecting a profit. The BlackBerry smartphone maker's IBD Composite Rating is a weak 15, not far from the worst-possible grade of 1.On the upside, Fresh Market (TFM) soared 13% in huge turnover, as the upscale grocer reported first-quarter profit rose 33% to 40 cents a share, 4 cents over views. Revenue grew 23% to $325 million, also above forecasts. The company hiked its full-year profit target. The stock cleared a 55.07 buy point from a somewhat odd-shaped square-box pattern out of the gate Thursday and is currently holding above that level.In economic news, the National Association of Realtors reported a worse-than-expected 5.5% decrease in pending home sales for April. The consensus view was for a 0.5% gain. Even the lowball estimate for a 2% drop proved far too bullish.Reuters reported that yields on 10-year Spanish bonds moved closer to 7%, the level at which other nations in the eurozone were forced to seek a bailout. Italian 10-year yields topped 6% for the first time since a January bond sale.The latest poll from Greece showed a leftist party has taken the lead over the pro-bailout forces ahead of a national parliamentary election next month. Stocks climbed broadly Thursday after two Fed policymakers said to expect low interest rates through 2014. But volume failed to keep pace with the averages' solid gains.The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each leapt 1.4%, while the Nasdaq added 1.3%. But volume fell 5% on the Nasdaq and 4% on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.After the close, Google (GOOG) topped profit expectations for the first quarter. Its shares were little changed in the initial minutes after the report. RELATED"I consider a highly accommodative policy stance to be appropriate in present circumstances. But considerable uncertainty surrounds the outlook, and I remain prepared to adjust my policy views in response to incoming information," said Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Janet Yellen in a speech.Meanwhile, New York Fed President William Dudley told a conference in Syracuse, N.Y., that the economy is not yet on safe ground.In addition, more Americans than expected filed for first-time jobless claims last week.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) jumped more than 6% in high volume. A Gartner report released Wednesday said the computer maker increased its market share to 17.2% in the first quarter from 16.9% a year ago. Gartner said PC sales rose 2% during the quarter, and said HP's performance suggested the company had resolved its internal management issues.HP shares were above September lows, but remained deep in a two-year correction. The stock is 40% off a 52-week high of 41.74.Tractor Supply (TSCO) jumped 6% to a new high in massive trade after boosting its first-quarter earnings guidance. The IBD Leaderboard stock is extended 18% past an 82.60 buy point from a four-weeks-tight pattern.Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT) climbed 5% in fast trade, notching a new high in the process. The provider of wireless networking gear is extended after a rebound from support in March at the 10-week moving average.Firearms maker Sturm Ruger (RGR) rose 3% in heavy trade, adding to Wednesday's rebound from support near its 10-week moving average. The stock is at the top of the week's trading range after an 8% dive Monday and Tuesday. The company said it sold 382,500 firearms during the first quarter, putting it over the 1 million mark over the past 12 months.Polaris Industries (PII) surged 4%, adding to its rebound from the 10-week line. The move, in strong volume, put shares at the top of the week's trading range after a 6% drop Monday and Tuesday.

He's five for five over his small-cap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. And he's outperforming so far in a young 2012. This year going into Monday, his…

Think of some of the themes you've found in leaders in the past few years: technology, retail and high-growth economies. A good number of winners thrived on the wave of at least one of these themes, some enjoyed two.MercadoLibre (MELI) sits in the nexus of all three.The Argentina-based company is a sort of Latin American  eBay (EBAY), operating platforms that allow for auction-style sales and virtual stores in a dozen Latin American and Caribbean countries.MercadoLibre facilitates payments in six of these markets with its MercadoPago system, which works a lot like PayPal.This column in Tuesday's edition noted the rash of retailers that led the market's recent uptrend. They included  Lululemon Athletica (LULU), GNC Holdings (GNC), Tractor Supply (TSCO) and Michael Kors (KORS).Each of these retail stars found a niche to help it stand out. After all, if there's one thing we have no shortage of, it's stores.For example, GNC grabs prime retail space to sell its line of high-priced nutrients to the health-conscious workout crowd. Michael Kors has targeted the concept of affordable luxury fashion. And Lululemon Athletica sells its own line of yoga-themed exercise apparel and accessories.These niches are unique.But MercadoLibre, or the vendors that operate on any of its platforms, can sell anything or everything, just like eBay. What's special about everything?We're really looking at the upside of tapping into a fast-growing emerging market.True, introducing an online business in a region where penetration is rising and has room to grow seems like a winning idea.But that seems a normal part of the bigger story. Latin America is largely a fast-growing region. A middle class is emerging in countries such as Brazil (the region's anchor economy, which accounted for 56% of sales last year). Wealth is being created and spent.Nearly 76 million Brazilians were Internet users as of June 2011, according to Internet World Stats. That's 37.4% of the population. The government says the number of Internet users will grow 13.9% this year.Urban unemployment fell to 4.7% in December, an all-time low.And, crucially, per-capita GDP rose to $11,600 in 2011. That's up 2.6% for the year — and 53% in the past decade.The World Bank says Brazil's economy rose 7.5% in 2010. Credit-rating agency Fitch Ratings said in December that Brazil's GDP likely rose 2.8% in 2011.Morgan Stanley thinks growth will rise to 3.5% this year. The central bank is easing after a series of rate hikes. The new posture should help restore consumption and growth, Morgan Stanley said in December.MercadoLibre earned 47 cents per share in Q4 on sales of $86.5 million. Both results missed estimates, which seems to be traced to currency movements.MercadoLibre's chart shows a flat base developing, and a recently formed handle points to a buy point at 103.08.Volume has been light during the five-week correction, which combines with the tight price action to form a sound pattern.

In a stock rally, almost every pick looks like a winner. Now that the market is in correction, it's easier to spot leaders, as the laggards fall away.Tech giant Apple (AAPL) is near the top of IBD's latest Bolting Relative Strength Lines Screen of the Day. The screen measures a company's performance against the S&P 500. Those hitting new highs are leading the rallies and are outperforming their peers when markets turn.Many reside in high-ranking sectors, giving them strong macro tail winds.Here are five with top fundamentals, outperforming the market:AppleThe iPad and iPhone maker is single-handedly driving a large share of the expected modest growth in first-quarter S&P 500 earnings growth. The iPad and iPhone maker is expected to grow earnings per share by 53% when it reports fiscal Q2 on April 24. It more than doubled earnings in its last report, en route to becoming the world's largest company by market share.Even as the overall market sold off, Apple shares climbed slightly to fresh record highs.Apple is in the computer hardware and peripherals group, which ranks No. 7 among the 197 industry groups IBD tracks.GNC Holdings (GNC)Health-conscious Americans are driving double-digit sales for this vitamin and supplement retailer. GNC, featured in IBD's New America section, is in IBD's No. 65-ranked specialty retail group. Shares closed down 1% Monday at 35.29.Select Comfort (SCSS)The specialty mattress seller helps deliver customers a good night's rest with its pricey adjustable firmness products. Its double-digit sales and EPS growth gives investors comfort.It resides in IBD's No. 9-ranked home furnishings retail group.Shares dipped Monday, but less than the overall market.(Another specialty mattress maker, Tempur-Pedic International (TPX) also rests near the top of the list.)SXC Health Solutions (SXCI)The company once focused on selling medical-records software to pharmacy benefits managers. But in 2008, it began buying those customers to become its own PBM. That's driven triple-digit sales growth, though at lower margins that equate to double-digit EPS growth.Still, the firm is trading near an all-time high. It closed Monday down slightly at 77.86.Its medical services group ranks No. 73 among IBD's 197 groups.Priceline.com (PCLN)The online travel agency leads the No. 8-ranked leisure travel booking group.Pacific Crest analyst Chad Bartley initiated coverage Monday with an outperform rating and an 885 price target, and thinks the firm can continue to sustain high margins and outperform peers.Its shares closed up 1%, hitting fresh record highs.Others at or near the top are WellCare Health Plans (WCG), which tumbled 7.4% Monday after Ohio opted not to renew it and three other health insurers' Medicaid contracts.Celgene (CELG), which develops cancer treatments, also ranks highly, as does Tractor Supply (TSCO), an equipment retailer benefiting from flush farmers.Related Story7 IBD 50 Stocks With Faster EPS Growth Expected

An investor learning to spot bullish chart patterns might do well to start with the easiest one: the flat base.As its name implies, a flat base is a shallow price contraction on a chart that forms as a stock digests an earlier advance.Simple enough, right?Of course, nothing in stock investing is quite so simple. Not every sideways consolidation is a flat base. From IBD's decades of studying successful stocks, here's what is known about the proper framework of the flat base:• It needs at least five weeks to form. Shorter patterns are not adequate enough to flush out weak or impatient shareholders.Usually, start counting with the first down week on a weekly chart.• The stock's price declines no more than 15% from its intraday peak to intraday trough. This means that in some cases, the "flat" base has kind of a "U" shape and doesn't look so flat. Yet, it is still a proper base.• The optimal buy point is determined by finding the highest price in the pattern and adding 10 cents to it.Usually, that highest price is at the start of the correction.But every once in a while, a stock forms a significant resistance area that's a bit lower than the prior high. This can provide an earlier entry point.As with the breakout from other key chart patterns, the stock should clear the buy point in volume at least 40% above its 50-day average.Flat bases tend to form as a second or third base in a stock's major advance, following a double bottom, cup with handle or another, larger base. Rarely, flat bases are the first base.In late 2011 and early 2012, Tractor Supply (TSCO) had all the makings of a good flat base: It had climbed from a cup-with-handle breakout, it corrected 14%, and it consolidated for eight weeks.The buy point was 78.32 (1) but an alternative buy point could be traced at 75.58. (2) The midcap stock broke out above both in heavy trading on Jan. 12, 2012, in volume nearly five times its average. (3)The farming supply chain rallied 29% from the higher buy point until it peaked three months later.When it broke out, Tractor Supply's Earnings Per Share Rating was a solid 94, meaning that its long- and short-term profit growth exceeds 94% of all stocks in IBD's database. Its Relative Price Strength Rating was 92.

U.S. farmers are set to plant their largest corn crop since World War II, lured in by high prices for the commodity and tight supplies.
The report from the U.S. Department of Agriculture on Monday sent agriculture and grain stocks higher, including Archer Daniels Midland (ADM), Monsanto (MON) and Bunge (BG).
Shares of fertilizer makers CF Industries (CF) and Agrium (AGU) were also up in intraday trading.
Farm equipment companies Deere (DE) and Tractor Supply Co. (TSCO) also were trading higher.
The report forecasts 94 million acres of corn to be planted this spring, up from 91.92 million acres planted in 2011. That would be the largest crop since the 95.48 million acres planted in 1944.
Corn stocks are expected to end next summer at 1.6 billion bushels, almost twice this year's supply, which are the lowest in 16 years.
That rising supply should ease prices for restaurants and food manufacturers, who are facing sharply higher commodity costs, and for consumers who grapple with higher grocery bills.

The government expects corn prices to average $5 per bushel in the 2012-13 marketing year, down from the current $6.70. It expects that price to continue lower to $4.30 the following year, before starting to climb again.
Last week, grains and oilseed processor Bunge and ingredients maker Corn Products International (CPO) forecast rising crop demand in 2012, as both posted higher-than-expected fourth-quarter results.
USDA's latest report projects the amount of corn for feed at 5.225 billion bushels, up from 4.6 billion this year. Corn for ethanol is seen slipping to 4.950 billion from 5.0 billion this year.

Exports are expected to climb to 1.875 billion bushels from 1.7 billion this year. The U.S. is the world's largest corn exporter. Demand is expected to rise in China as growing wealth fuels appetites for meat, requiring more feed.

Monday update: Apple Inc. rose 4% Monday, rebounding from an 11-week low Friday as investors await Tuesday's likely iPad Mini unveiling and Thursday's quarterly earnings. report. Alexion Pharmaceuticals fell 3.3% Monday, extending Friday's 5.3% tumble below its 50-day moving average. Gilead Sciences edged down 0.3%. Web.com edged up 0.2%. Resmed rose 0.8%.
Apple (AAPL) earnings are hard to miss. But it's among one of 12 top-rated IBD 50 stocks that are slated to report results this week.
A barrage of earnings releases are on tap this week, many of mediocre or lagging stock. Investors need to focus on the creme de la creme of stocks.
Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), ResMed (RMD), Web.com Group (WWWW), and Gilead Sciences (GILD) are all highly rated tech or medical firms reporting this week.

Five million people bought Apple's latest iPhone smartphone in the first three days following its debut. Still analysts thought the figure was lower than they expected. The global consumer electronics leader is holding a media event Tuesday where it's widely expected to announce a smaller, lighter and cheaper mini iPad.

Apple is slated to report fourth-quarter earnings after the market closes on Thursday. Analysts are expecting the company to post a 25% jump in EPS to $8.85. Sales are seen rising 28.2% to $36.2 billion.
Apple is ranked No. 21 on the IBD 50 list, which ranks companies based on superior earnings, strong price performance and leadership within industries.
But Apple shares have fallen hard, losing 3.2% last week — the fourth straight weekly decline.
Alexion is a biotech known for its drug Soliris, which is used for treating two rare blood diseases. It is ranked No. 4 on the IBD 50 list and is slated to report earnings on Wednesday.
The biotech is expected to report a 27% gain in EPS to 47 cents. Sales are seen jumping 43% to $293.2 million. It has posted double- or triple-digit EPS gains the last 14 quarters.
Alexion hit a record high Oct. 5 but has pulled back since. The stock fell 5.3% on Friday, closing below its 50-day line for the first time since early June.
ResMed, ranked right below Alexion on the IBD 50, makes breathing devices to help treat disorders like sleep apnea.
Analysts see its quarterly earnings jumping 31% to 46 cents when it reports earnings on Thursday. Revenue is seen rising 8.7% to $342.2 million.
ResMed shares gapped higher after the previous earnings report and continued to rise sharply until Oct. 5. The stock has since pulled back modestly.

Web.com, which provides website design and other online services for small businesses, is ranked No. 10 on the IBD 50 list. Analysts expect Q3 EPS of 39 cents, a 34% jump vs. 2011 results. EPS has risen at double-digit rates for the past eight quarters. Revenue is seen rising 164.8% to $123.54 million.
Web.com shares just closed below their 50-day line on Friday.

Gilead produces drugs to help make HIV a manageable disease. It is ranked No. 47 on the IBD 50 list. Analysts are expecting to see a 8.5% dip in earnings to 94 cents per share. Revenue is seen rising 10% to $2.34 billion.
Gilead shares have fallen about 2% in each of the past two weeks, but they remain comfortably above their 50-day line. The stock is nearly at its early October high.

Other IBD 50 stocks reporting include: Texas Capital Bancshares (TCBI), Jarden (JAH), Panera Bread (PNRA), Tractor Supply (TSCO), Under Armour (UA), Ancestry.com (ACOM) and Sherwin-Williams (SHW).Monday update: Apple Inc. rose 4% Monday, rebounding from an 11-week low Friday as investors await Tuesday's likely iPad Mini unveiling and Thursday's quarterly earnings. report. Stocks gained ground Wednesday as a stunning gain in housing starts added to the impression that the economic recovery is finally taking hold.

The S&P 500 climbed 0.4% and the Nasdaq added a scant 0.1%. Even the Dow Jones industrial average eked out a tiny gain despite serious losses by IBM (IBM) and Intel (INTC), which had put out poorly received earnings reports after Tuesday's close.
Volume increased slightly on both exchanges, according to preliminary data.

Housing starts surged 15% in September, that gauge's best performance so far this year: an annualized rate of 872,000 vs. an upwardly revised 758,000 rate in August. Analysts had expected a 765,000 annualized rate.
The Census Bureau also reported building permit activity jumped to a rate of 894,000. That was 12% above September's rate, easily outpacing consensus views for 810,000.

Homebuilder MDC Holdings (MDC), one of the leading names in a red-hot group, jumped 3% despite being cut to market perform from outperform at Raymond James. The stock has been consolidating gains since late September. MDC is forming a potential flat base. The company will report Q3 earnings Oct. 30. Analysts see it earning 20 cents a share vs. a year-ago loss of 68 cents a share.
Other names in the building group also put up solid gains: Ryland Group (RYL) and D.R. Horton (DHI) each leapt 4%; Lennar (LEN) and Toll Brothers (TOL) each added 2%.

Elsewhere, Tractor Supply's (TSCO) early 3% gain got whittled down to small change by day's end. The stock regained its 50-day line in the morning, but that victory didn't hold. But it's still 5% below a 101.38 buy point from a cup-with-handle base cleared Oct. 5.

Tractor Supply at one point was down nearly 8% below that buy point Monday. The farming-gear company will report Q3 results after the market's close Oct. 24. Analysts see earnings rising 16% to 67 cents a share. Sales are slated to grow 9% to $1.07 billion.

On the downside, Sourcefire (FIRE) tumbled 12% to a two-month low as fellow security software firms Fortinet (FTNT) and Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) reported lackluster results and outlooks. The stock gapped below its 200-day line in big volume.
Ulta Beauty (ULTA) shed 2% in modestly above-average trade, erasing its early gain. The cosmetics retailer, No. 44 in Wednesday's IBD 50 lineup, continues to run into resistance around the 100 level.

Mellanox Technologies (MLNX) slumped 10% in heavy trade, dropping below support at the 100 level. More ground was lost after hours in the wake of the company's earnings report, even though the Israeli tech company beat estimates.Stocks gained ground Wednesday as a stunning gain in housing starts added to the impression that the economic recovery is finally taking hold. Google (GOOG) is a formidable competitor in most places. In China though, Baidu (BIDU) dominates the search realm. But Qihoo 360 (QIHU) is taking market away from both.

The Chinese browser maker's software is installed on 425 million PC desktops. The company also has about 120 million people talking and texting on its budget smartphones. And now it's expanding into search, having replaced Google's search tool in its browser.
The Chinese company was one of six names to rejoin the elite IBD 50 list in Monday's edition. It's No. 24.

The others were data management and storage firm CommVault Systems (CVLT) at No. 30; fleet fuel card issuer Wright Express (WXS) at No. 38; backup generator maker Generac Holdings (GNRC) at No. 42; bakery and restaurant chain Panera Bread (PNRA)at No. 44; documentary broadcaster Discovery Communications (DISCA) at No. 45; and the plastics and chemical firm PolyOne (POL) at No. 49.

Investors with an interest in Retail - Miscellaneous stocks have likely encountered both Office Depot (ODP  -  Free Report) and Tractor Supply (TSCO  -  Free Report). But which of these two stocks presents investors with the better value opportunity right now? Let's take a closer look.We have found that the best way to discover great value opportunities is to pair a strong Zacks Rank with a great grade in the Value category of our Style Scores system. The Zacks Rank is a proven strategy that targets companies with positive earnings estimate revision trends, while our Style Scores work to grade companies based on specific traits.Right now, Office Depot is sporting a Zacks Rank of #2 (Buy), while Tractor Supply has a Zacks Rank of #3 (Hold). This means that ODP's earnings estimate revision activity has been more impressive, so investors should feel comfortable with its improving analyst outlook. But this is only part of the picture for value investors.Value investors also try to analyze a wide range of traditional figures and metrics to help determine whether a company is undervalued at its current share price levels.The Value category of the Style Scores system identifies undervalued companies by looking at a number of key metrics. These include the long-favored P/E ratio, P/S ratio, earnings yield, cash flow per share, and a variety of other fundamentals that help us determine a company's fair value.ODP currently has a forward P/E ratio of 8.88, while TSCO has a forward P/E of 18.99. We also note that ODP has a PEG ratio of 0.51. This popular metric is similar to the widely-known P/E ratio, with the difference being that the PEG ratio also takes into account the company's expected earnings growth rate. TSCO currently has a PEG ratio of 1.43.Another notable valuation metric for ODP is its P/B ratio of 0.73. The P/B ratio pits a stock's market value against its book value, which is defined as total assets minus total liabilities. For comparison, TSCO has a P/B of 7.32.These are just a few of the metrics contributing to ODP's Value grade of A and TSCO's Value grade of C.ODP stands above TSCO thanks to its solid earnings outlook, and based on these valuation figures, we also feel that ODP is the superior value option right now.

Tractor Supply Company (TSCO  -  Free Report) delivered lower-than-expected results in first-quarter 2018. However, both earnings and sales increased year over year. Also, management reiterated its guidance for 2018.Following the soft quarterly results, shares of this leading rural lifestyle retail store chain were down 1.8% in pre-market trading. In the past three months, this Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) stock has lost 21.4% wider than the industry’s decline of 11%.Q1 HighlightsTractor Supply reported quarterly earnings of 57 cents per share, missing the Zacks Consensus Estimate by a penny. However, the bottom line increased 23.9% year over year backed by its growth initiatives.Also, the company’s revenues increased 7.6% to $1,682.9 million but fell short of the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1,690 million. This year-over-year growth can be attributed to rise in comparable-store sales (comps), which improved 3.7% against a decline of 2.2% in the year-ago period. While comparable store transaction count grew 3.2%, average ticket inched up 0.5%. Furthermore, traffic and sales growth were aided by the company’s ongoing efforts to build customer loyalty and enhance digital capabilities. Additionally, comps gained from improvement across all geographic regions as well as major product categories.Tractor Supply also witnessed strength in everyday basic products across the consumable, usable and edible categories as well as winter seasonal products. Improvement in comps was somewhat compensated with soft sales across spring and summer seasonal products. Tractor Supply Company Price, Consensus and EPS Surprise  Tractor Supply Company Price, Consensus and EPS Surprise | Tractor Supply Company QuoteMargins & CostsGross profit rose 8.8% year over year to $563.6 million in the quarter, with gross margin expanding 36 basis points (bps) to 33.5%. The upside was driven by robust sell-through of winter seasonal products, somewhat offset by higher transportation costs due to a rise in carrier rates and diesel fuel expenses.Additionally, selling, general and administrative (SG&A) expenses, including depreciation and amortization, as a percentage of sales, grew 89 bps to 27.9%. This increase can be primarily attributed to investments in team member wages, increased store expenses and investments in infrastructure and technology to support the strategic long-term growth initiatives.Financial PositionTractor Supply ended first quarter with cash and cash equivalents of $132.4 million, long-term debt of $679.6 million and total stockholders’ equity of $1,313.2 million.In the quarter under review, the company repurchased shares for $157.5 million. Additionally, it incurred capital expenditures of $45.1 million and generated cash flow from operating activities of about $21.9 million.Store UpdateIn the first quarter, Tractor Supply opened 15 namesake stores and four Petsense stores.As of Mar 31, 2018, the company operated 1,700 Tractor Supply stores in 49 states and 172 Petsense stores.GuidanceManagement remains impressed with its first-quarter results that witness margin expansions, comps growth and greater sales. Going ahead, it remains optimistic about the spring selling season. Further, Tractor Supply expects to balance investments between new store growth and ONETractor strategic initiative, alongside investing in everyday businesses to provide a seamless experience to its customers.However, Tractor Supply reiterated its guidance for 2018. The company continues to project net sales in the band of $7.69-$7.77 billion reflecting 6-7% growth year over year. Comps growth is anticipated in the range of 2-3% for the year. Further, earnings per share are envisioned in the band of $3.95-$4.15. The Zacks Consensus Estimate for 2018 is pegged at $4.09.Interested in Retail? Tractor Supply Company (TSCO  -  Free Report) is slated to release first-quarter 2018 results on Apr 26. Last quarter, the company reported a positive earnings surprise of 4.6%.Moreover, Tractor Supply delivered an average positive earnings surprise of 2.2% in the trailing four quarters. Notably, the company has been witnessing sales and earnings growth for more than two years now. Let’s see how things are shaping up prior to this announcement.What to Expect?The question popping up in investors’ minds is whether Tractor Supply will be able to deliver a positive earnings surprise in the quarter to be reported. The Zacks Consensus Estimate for the first quarter is pegged at 59 cents, reflecting growth of 28.3% year over year. Moreover, earnings estimate for the current quarter has climbed in the last seven days, reflecting a positive momentum ahead of earnings.  Also, analysts polled by Zacks expect revenues of $1.70 billion, up about 8.4% from the year-ago quarter.Tractor Supply Company Price, Consensus and EPS Surprise Tractor Supply Company Price, Consensus and EPS Surprise | Tractor Supply Company QuoteFactors at PlayTractor Supply remains focused on store-growth initiatives, ONETractor plan and investment in everyday businesses. Evidently, it remains on track to attain the long-term domestic-store growth target of 2,500 stores. Further, the company is focusing on integrating its physical and digital operations to offer consumers a seamless shopping experience.The company remains on track with its “ONETractor” initiative that is aimed at connecting store and online shopping. In this regard, the company is reaping significant benefits from its Buy Online Pick Up in Store program while it continues to expand its Neighbor’s Club customer rewards program. Management expects both strategies to play a major role in boosting the top line. It also expects long-term results to benefit from its mobile POS and stockyard initiatives.Moreover, the company is benefiting from solid comps, driven by strength across all regions and major product categories, which fueled its fourth-quarter 2017 results.Going into 2018, Tractor Supply expects to balance investments between new-store growth and ONETractor strategic initiative, alongside investing in everyday businesses, to provide a seamless experience to customers. This will provide significant growth opportunities as the company will gain market share and leverage its physical stores while expanding digital capabilities. Consequently, it provided an encouraging guidance for the first quarter and full-year 2018.The company anticipates stronger comps and earnings per share in the first half of the year compared with the second half. Hence, it forecasts comps for the first half at or above 2-3% for 2018 while the second half comps are likely to be below this range.Further, the company revealed that the first quarter will include one extra comp day as its stores were open on New Year’s Day for the first time. This extra day is likely to add about 60-70 bps to comps for the first quarter and 10-15 bps to full-year comps. Additionally, the company projects highest comps growth and lowest operating-margin compression in the first quarter.However, the company expects continued cost pressures from rising freight rates, due to a shortage of drivers and higher diesel prices as well as inflationary wage pressures across retail locations and the supply chain. These headwinds, along with the company’s investments to grow business, are likely to keep operating margin for 2018 under pressure. Consequently, operating margin is anticipated to be nearly 8.8%, the mid-point of the company’s guidance range. Additionally, gross margin is anticipated to be flat to marginally down in 2018, with significant impact on SG&A expense.Further, the shares of Tractor Supply have declined 26.9% in the last three months, wider than the industry’s decline of 12.4%. However, the company’s focus on growth initiatives helped it to outperform the industry in the past year.Given the above iterations, let’s wait and see if the company’s strategic efforts can offset the margin-related constraints.What the Zacks Model Unveils?Our proven model does not conclusively show that Tractor Supply is likely to beat estimates this quarter. This is because a stock needs to have both a positive Earnings ESP and a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy), 2 (Buy) or 3 (Hold) for this to happen. You can uncover the best stocks to buy or sell before they’re reported with our Earnings ESP Filter.While Tractor Supply has a Zacks Rank #3, an Earnings ESP of -5.50% lowers the chances of a beat in the ensuing release.Stocks With Favorable CombinationHere are some companies that you may want to consider as our model shows that these also have the right combination of elements to post an earnings beat:KAR Auction Services Inc.
