About a month has gone by since the last earnings report for Tractor Supply Company (TSCO  -  Free Report). Shares have added about 10.4% in that time frame, outperforming the market.Will the recent positive trend continue leading up to the next earnings release, or is it due for a pullback? Before we dive into how investors and analysts have reacted of late, let's take a quick look at its most recent earnings report in order to get a better handle on the important drivers.Tractor Supply Misses on Q2 Earnings, Cuts Outlook Tractor Supply reported second-quarter 2017 results, wherein the company’s earnings of $1.25 per share were below the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.27, but it increased 7.8% year over year.The top line advanced 8.9% to $2,017.8 million, while it missed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $2,020.7 million. Comps improved 2.2%, against a 0.5% drop witnessed in the year-ago period. Well, comps growth was hurt to an extent of about 60 basis points (bps) due to lesser sales days this quarter, as compared to second-quarter 2016.The rise in comps was backed by 2.2% growth in comparable transaction count, while average ticket remained flat year over year. Further, comps growth was fueled by improvement in several product categories, with Livestock and Pet topping the list. Also, transaction count growth across all geographic regions contributed to comps.Margins & CostsThe gross profit rose 8.5% year over year to $704.7 million, while gross margin declined 10 bps to 34.9%. The Gross margin was hampered by greater freight costs, stemming from higher diesel fuel prices as well as mix shift toward products that are more freight intensive.Selling, general and administrative (SG&A) expenses, including depreciation and amortization, as a percentage of sales, increased 50 bps to 22.1%. This increase was primarily due to increased payroll expenses, infrastructural and technological investments and costs related to Petsense integration. In dollar terms, SG&A expenses (including depreciation and amortization) escalated 11.7% to $446.8 million.Consequently, operating income margin contracted 60 bps to 12.8% in second-quarter 2017. Nonetheless, operating income, in dollar terms, jumped 3.5% to nearly $257.9 million.Financial PositionTractor Supply ended the quarter with cash and cash equivalents of $67.8 million, long-term debt of $433.7 million, and total stockholders’ equity of $1,382.6 million.The company repurchased 2.2 million shares for $134 million in the quarter. With this, Tractor Supply bought back 3.8 million shares for $248 million on a year-to-date basis. Further, the company incurred capital expenditure of $96.6 million in first-half 2017, while it generated cash flow from operating activities of about $227.5 million.Store UpdateDuring the second quarter, Tractor Supply opened 14 namesake stores and closed one Del’s store. Further, the company opened eight Petsense stores during the reported quarter.Including these, the company inaugurated 38 namesake stores, closed one Del’s store and converted two Hometown Pet stores to Petsense stores in first-half 2017. During this time frame, Tractor Supply opened 17 Petsense outlets (including the aforementioned conversions). As of Jul 1, the company operated 1,630 Tractor Supply stores in 49 states, and 160 Petsense stores across 26 states.The Road AheadAs mentioned earlier, management remains impressed with the early third-quarter trends, given the continued solid demand for spring season products – thanks to favorable weather. Thus, the company is set to exploit the advantages of this extended spring selling period. Additionally, the company remains on track with its “One Tractor” initiative that is strengthening the connection between its physical and digital operations, thus augmenting the top line. Evidently, the company closed the rollout of its Buy Online Pick Up in Store program and continued to expand its Neighbor’s Club customer rewards program in the second quarter. Notably, the Buy Online Pick Up in Store program was well-received and contributed more than 55% to online sales.However, based on the overall first-half 2017 results, the company lowered its 2017 guidance.Updated Numbers Management now projects net sales in a band of $7.13–$7.19 billion, compared with $7.22–$7.29 billion expected earlier. Comps growth is now guided in a range of 1.1–1.7%, down from the previously guided range of 2–3% growth. The updated comps view includes a negative impact of about 30% from deflation.Gross margin is anticipated to be flat to down in 2017, owing to the dismal numbers in the first half. Both, SG&A expenses (including depreciation and amortization) and operating margin are expected to decline by 80 – 100 bps.Finally, Tractor Supply now envisions earnings per share in a band of $3.22–$3.27, as against its old forecast of $3.44–$3.52. Tractor Supply also updated its capital expenditures target for the year, from $270–$290 million to $250–$270 million.How Have Estimates Been Moving Since Then?Following the release, investors have witnessed a downward trend in  fresh estimates. There has been one revision lower for the current quarter. The consensus estimate has shifted by  lower by 6.6% due to these changes.Tractor Supply Company Price and Consensus  Tractor Supply Company Price and Consensus | Tractor Supply Company QuoteVGM ScoresAt this time, Tractor Supply's stock has a great Growth Score of A, though it is lagging a lot on the momentum front with a D. The stock was allocated a grade of B on the value side, putting it in the second quintile for this investment strategy.Overall, the stock has an aggregate VGM Score of A. If you aren't focused on one strategy, this score is the one you should be interested in.Our style scores indicate that the stock is more suitable for growth investors than value investors.OutlookEstimates have been broadly trending downward for the stock. The magnitude of this revision also indicates a downward shift. It's no surprise that the stock has a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell). We expect below average returns from the stock in the next few months.

Tractor Supply Co (TSCO  -  Free Report) led the Focus List this week after the company reported excellent Q4 results. Shares were up more than 9% on Thursday alone.
Earnings per share came in at 67 cents, beating the Zacks Consensus Estimate by 8%. Sales were up almost 20% year-over-year driven by a 13% increase in same-store sales.
Management expects to earn between $2.54 and $2.62 per share in 2011. The Zacks Consensus Estimate is currently $2.56, but expect that number to inch higher over the next couple of days.
It is a Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stock.
Meanwhile, managed healthcare company Amerigroup Corp (AGP) climbed nearly 12% this week thanks in large part to a strong quarter from competitor Molina Healthcare (MOH).

Amerigroup continues to steadily climb higher and is up more than 70% since late July. Despite the huge run up, valuation remains attractive with shares trading at 13.3x forward earnings and a PEG ratio of 0.9.
The company reports its results for the fourth quarter on Friday, Feb 18. It is a Zacks #2 Rank (Buy) stock.

Tractor Supply Co (TSCO  -  Free Report) recently delivered another strong quarter marked by solid same-store sales growth and an expanding gross margin. Management also raised its guidance for the rest of 2010, prompting analysts to revise their estimates higher.
Since its addition to the Focus List on August 5, 2010, TSCO has gained 20.4%.
Third Quarter Results

The company reported its results for the third quarter 2010 on October 20. Earnings per share came in at 43 cents, a 43% increase over the same quarter in 2009. This beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate by 6 cents.
Net sales grew by 10.9% year-over-year, driven by an impressive 5.0% increase in same-store sales. Sales of animal and pet-related merchandise were particularly strong.

Meanwhile the gross margin expanded from 32.9% of sales to 33.7% in the quarter primarily due to markdown management and more effective pricing. The company also managed its corporate expenses well, as selling, general and administrative expenses improved from 28.1% of sales to 27.5%.
These factors led to an excellent 42.1% increase in operating income year-over-year.
Outlook
Management raised its guidance for 2010 following the strong quarter. The company now expects to earn between $2.09 and $2.13 per share, up from its previous guidance of $2.00 to $2.05.
Analysts have been raising their estimates higher over the last several months as Tractor Supply continues to deliver impressive results. Take a look at the company's Price & Consensus chart:
The Zacks Consensus Estimate for 2010 is $2.14, representing 36% EPS growth compared to 2009. The 2011 estimate is currently 13% higher at $2.42 per share.
Fundamentals
Shares have risen over 75% in the last 12 months.

Despite the huge run up in share price, the stock trades around 20x trailing earnings, roughly in-line with its peers. Its price to book ratio of 3.6 is a premium to the industry average of 1.6, but this is justified by the company's above-average profitability. Return on equity, for instance, is a stellar 19.9%, more than double the industry average of 9.8%.

Tractor Supply Co is headquartered in Brentwood, Tennessee and has a market cap of $3.1 billion. As of September 25, 2010 the company operated 976 stores in 44 states. It is a Zacks #3 Rank (Hold) stock.
Todd Bunton is the Growth & Income Stock Strategist for Zacks.com

Snooty, too-hip-for-their-own good urbanites may not think of a company that caters to recreational farmers and ranchers as a growth stock, but that would be a mistake. Take a look at Tractor Supply Company (TSCO  -  Free Report), which late last month announced its ninth consecutive quarter with a positive earnings surprise.
Earlier in the month, the company raised its outlook for 2010, and we can still observe the sharp increase in earnings estimates that followed.

The good news in July convinced us to add TSCO to the Focus List on Aug 5. It was really a no-brainer in a lot of ways. The company is a Zacks #1 Rank ('strong buy') and enjoys a longer-term "Outperform" recommendation. Plus domestic agriculture could see a favorable shift that could help rural consumers as weather causes havoc on global crops.  Earnings Estimates for Tractor Supply Company

As impressive as its second-quarter results were, it was rather anticlimactic when it came to earnings estimates. A few weeks before the earnings announcement, Tractor Supply announced sales results for the quarter and, more importantly, raised its 2010 earnings and sales guidance.

Now the company expects earnings per share between $4 and $4.10, instead of $3.48 to $3.60. Sales are now anticipated between $3.49 billion and $3.53 billion, compared to the previous outlook of $3.44 billion to $3.5 billion. As a result, the sharp gain in earnings estimates of late can be traced back to this announcement, rather than the second-quarter results.

The Zacks Consensus Estimate for this year is $4.10 per share, which is up 10.2% from 2 months ago. Out of 17 total estimates, there has been only one upward revision in the past 30 days, which led to a three-cent improvement in that time, or less than 1%.

Meanwhile, the Zacks Consensus Estimate for next year is $4.63 per share, or nearly 13% better than 2010. The outlook has advanced by 9.7% in the past two months. Unlike this year though, there has been a lot more interest lately. In the past 30 days, five estimates were revised upward out of 19 total estimates. Theres even been a downward revision in that time. The result of this activity is a 1.3% improvement in the past month. Second-Quarter Report

For the second quarter, Tractor Supply earned $2.05 per share, compared to $1.50 last year. The result moved slightly past the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $2.03 by 1%. While not dramatic, the result continued an impressive streak of better-than-expected quarterly profit that has now stretched for nine quarters. The surprise over the last 4 quarters is 7.4%.

As TSCO had previously announced, net sales reached $1.07 billion in the quarter, or 12.6% better than last year's $946.5 million. Same-store sales were up 6.1%, driven by continued strong results in core consumable categories, including animal and pet-related products, and agricultural and seasonal products, including outdoor power equipment.

"Our ability to generate outstanding results consistently demonstrates that Tractor Supply Company is a growth company that is able to succeed in varying economic climates," said TSCO Chairman/CEO Jim Wright.
For much more on this quarter, click: Tractor Supply Beats. Outperform

As mentioned earlier, we have a longer-term "Outperform" recommendation on Tractor Supply Company. More specifically, we believe that its future operating performance will be helped by its unique market position, initiatives to boost margin and its debt-free balance sheet.

TSCO's stores are focused on supplying the lifestyle needs of recreational farmers and ranchers. Shares and earnings estimates for Barnes & Noble, Inc.  are on the rise as the bookseller heads to its fiscal second-quarter report tomorrow.
At the moment, the Zacks Consensus Estimates for the quarter is 10 cents per share, which is up a penny, or 11.1%, over the past 7 days.
With a gain of about 5.5%, BKS is a Zacks #1 Rank Top Performer for Wednesday. Volume is nearly 1.2 million shares, which is above its daily average of approximately 950,000.

BKS is part of the very broad retail-miscellaneous/diversified industry. It is 1 of 5 companies from that space on today's 232-stock Zacks #1 Rank List, but none of the other companies are booksellers. (This eclectic group includes home products retailer Bed Bath & Beyond Inc. (BBBY  -  Free Report), equestrian products specialty retailer Dover Saddlery, Inc. (DOVR), crafts specialty retailer Jo-Ann Stores, Inc. (JAS) and farm products company Tractor Supply (TSCO  -  Free Report).) Earnings Estimates

BKS has enjoyed upward revisions from analysts in the past 7 days. The Zacks Consensus Estimate for this fiscal year, ending January 2010, is at $1.35 per share, which is up 3.8% from $1.30 in the past week. Meanwhile, the Zacks Consensus Estimate for next fiscal year, ending January 2011, has advanced 5.1% from $1.37 in that time.
Therefore, analysts currently expect profit for next fiscal year to advance about 6.6% from this fiscal year.
Earnings estimates have been on the rise for a while now. In fact, the past 2 months have seen gains of 8.9% and 11.6% for this fiscal year and next, respectively. Barnes & Noble College Booksellers
BKS made some news earlier this month when it announced an agreement to acquire Barnes & Noble College Booksellers, Inc. for $596 million.
B&N College Booksellers has a leading market position in the $10 billion college bookstore industry. For fiscal 2009, it generated revenue of $1.8 billion and same-store sales growth of 1%.
This acquisition will provide BKS with a stake in the growing digital textbook space; an important avenue for the company given the very challenging conditions for booksellers.

"In a rapidly changing environment, both companies will benefit from a unified digital platform and brand, which will enable the combined company to capitalize on the growing online college textbook and electronic book markets," said Irene Miller, Chairperson of the Special Committee of the Board.
(The Special Committee was established by the BKS Board of Directors due to the related-party nature of the transaction.) Fiscal First Quarter
BKS reported a loss of 4 cents per share for its fiscal first quarter, which bettered the Zacks Consensus Estimate of a 15-cent loss by more than 73%.
The result also exceeded the company's guidance, thanks to better-than-expected revenues, gross margins and expense management.
Total sales declined 4% to $1.1 billion. Barnes & Noble store sales of $989 million were down 3.5%, while same-store sales declined 5.7%. Sales at Barnes & Noble.com were off 7%.

From November 20, 2008 to January 6, 2009, the S&P Retail Index [RLX] rose 41%. Not a bad move for a group of stocks that had one of the worst holiday shopping seasons in recent memory. It appears that investors became more bullish on retailers because of seemingly cheap valuations, anticipated benefits from a federal government stimulus package, and a better economy in the second half of 2009.

In our view, the 50-day upward move in retail stocks was a bear-market rally. Investors should begin to lighten up on exposure to retail stocks. We expect the group to give back those gains as it becomes apparent that many retail stocks are not cheap, that the stimulus will provide at best a short-term boost, and the economy will not turn until 2010.

Our negative view of the group is based on the awful 2008 holiday season, a reduction of leverage in the financial system and, most importantly, consumer attitudes shifting away from borrowing to make discretionary purchases. These factors all point to continued pressure on consumer spending.

As a result, we believe that consumer and retailer trends that began in 2008 will continue throughout 2009. Consumers will focus their spending on necessary items such as food, clothing, and staples. Discretionary purchases will be made when items are significantly marked down. In turn, retailers will focus on reducing square footage, reducing leverage and reducing inventory. This will lead to further negative earnings estimate revisions for retailers for the next few quarters.
OPPORTUNITIES

We see few opportunities in the near term. That said, investors looking for exposure should focus on retailers with stable revenue and earnings. These include defensive plays including discounters, retailers with debt-free balance sheets, and supermarkets.
Two stocks we like in this environment are Kroger (KR  -  Free Report) and PetMed Express (PETS  -  Free Report).

Krogers sales should remain relatively intact. Consumers will still need to shop for groceries even with in a weak economic environment. Kroger is doing a good job of gaining market share by competing on price and selection.

PetMed Express operates the nationwide pet pharmacy 1800PetMeds.com. The company markets its health products for dogs, cats and horses. PETS revenue is holding up well in this challenging retail environment. The company continues to manage its operating costs, which has enabled the company to produce strong earnings growth.

Another long-time favorite of ours is GameStop (GME  -  Free Report), which reported blow-out numbers for the holiday season with same-store sales up 10%. The company also increased its EPS guidance for the fourth quarter.
WEAKNESSES

We would avoid most names in retail. The stocks that are least attractive in this environment are those companies with levered balance sheets, marginal businesses, or those retailers that rely on the credit markets to buy inventory or sell its merchandise. We have Sell ratings on department stores including JC Penney (JCP  -  Free Report) and Nordstrom (JWN  -  Free Report), specialty retailers Cost Plus (CPWM) and Tractor Supply (TSCO  -  Free Report), and e-commerce firms Overstock.com (OSTK  -  Free Report) and Priceline.com (PCLN).

First-quarter earnings season is off to a good start from the standpoint of earnings surprises. Among the 249 companies within the S&P 1500 (S&P 500, S&P Midcap 400 and S&P Smallcap 600) to have reported as of Thursday evening, 151 have exceeded expectations and 64 have missed estimates. (The rest have matched forecasts.) This equates to a surprise ratio of 2.4, which is better than the 1.88 ratio we saw about the same time during fourth-quarter earnings season.

Growth rates, however, have been notably slower. Average growth, excluding outliers, has been running at 4.3% versus 14.1% in the fourth-quarter. Banking and semiconductor companies have been a drag on the average growth rate. Investors should keep in mind that less than a quarter of companies have reported, so both the surprise and growth numbers are not fully representative of all industries. The expectation is that the average growth rate will rise as more reports come in.

Nearly 850 companies are confirmed to report during the week of Apr 23 - 27, 174 of which are members of the S&P 500. Dow components 3M (MMM  -  Free Report), Boeing (BA  -  Free Report), Du Pont (DD), Exxon Mobil (XOM  -  Free Report) and Microsoft (MSFT  -  Free Report) are on deck.

Optimism appears to be creeping back into the retail sector at just the right time.  The second half of the year has been historically the most important for these companies, due to the usually vibrant holiday season.  While big department store chains like  Dillard's  (NYSE:  DDS ) and  J.C. Penney  (NYSE:  JCP ) were likely ecstatic at the positives displayed in the month of July, for those retailers that deal in miscellaneous and diversified merchandise (a.k.a. specialty retailers) the news was just icing on the cake.  It was these retailers that performed best during the darkest days of the downturn, and they still enjoy a Zacks Industry Rank of 2.74, according to Nick Raich's  "Weekly Earnings and Sector Update,"  placing it 35th out of more than 200 industries.  With conditions apparently improving, analysts are seeing plenty of profit potential for starved investors.

Figures for July showed a more than +4% rise in same-store sales for the retail industry.  While such an improvement was surely a welcomed sign, analysts took heart more with what it could mean for the future.  Such an advance was reflected in the S&P Retail Index, which finished the August 27th session at 360.99.  That's less than four points off of its 52-week high.  Furthermore, major retailers such as  Wal-Mart  (NYSE:  WMT ) and  Sears  (NYSE:  S ) offered up encouraging outlooks for the month of August and second half.  This leaves many analysts very excited that the second half of 2003 will show the more traditional spending bonanza, rather than the 2002 performance that registered the most anemic sales gain in 30 years.

Miscellaneous and diversified retailers plan to be part of the uptrend.  These retailers, which focus more on one particular type of product or lifestyle, has been the most fashionable in regards to consumers' changing tastes.  These companies find a niche and develop an attractive concept to drive traffic and sales.  The most successful (or lucky) of which are able to latch onto segments of the economy that are thriving.  For example, Bed Bath & Beyond sells home décor items, which means that the impressive performance of housing over the past several years has brought millions of homebuyers into their stores.  Furthermore, with DVD rentals surging, Blockbuster has made itself into the Wal-Mart of its specific space.  The industry's narrower focus gave it an edge on the larger, more traditional department store chains, whose product offerings were slimmer than the specialties and oftentimes more expensive.

Better weather conditions, a strengthening economy, and easy comparisons are several of the reasons why analysts feel that the second half will show improvement.  Furthermore, since most Americans love to spend, tax cuts and still-discounted prices are expected to bring in more traffic in the coming months.  One could only hope that the employment situation (which is a lagging indicator) and consumer confidence figures can push forward.  But, in the meantime, investors should be aware that the retail space is still on shaky ground.  However, there is plenty of opportunity out there.  Many miscellaneous and diversified retailers have proven themselves to be consistent and steady growers for years now.  Several of them performed well while others struggled, and with an improving outlook for the overall retail space, investors would be wise to pay attention to what the All Stars have to say.  You may be in line for a shopping spree thanks to profits made with these intelligent and proven retailers.  What Do the All Stars Recommend?

Although there's a good deal of optimism surrounding retail in general right now, the space remains challenged.  However, if you were to totally ignore this industry until the economy comes back strong, you would miss out on a great deal of profit potential.  By consulting analysts, you can find the stocks that are ready to rise, while staying away from those that are running in place. Tractor Supply Company  (NASDAQ:  TSCO ) is a specialty retailer that supplies the daily farming and maintenance needs of its target customers: hobby, part-time and full-time farmers and ranchers, as well as rural customers, contractors and tradesmen.  Despite conditions that made the second quarter quite challenging, especially a late spring and cool, wet weather, Tractor Supply was still able to report earnings that slightly exceeded the consensus while also improving upon last year.  Net sales of $449.4 million were approximately +14.6% higher than the year-ago performance, as same-store sales increased by +1.2%.  The company felt that it's sales performance would have been better were it not for the two above-mentioned factors, which impacted seasonal products such as lawn mowers and lawn tractors.  Tractor Supply said neither economic nor competitive factors had a significant impact on the sales performance.  The company was able to maintain strong top line performance in its core offerings, while keeping its overall bottom line performance in line with expectations.

More recently, in late July, Tractor Supply's Board of Directors approved a two-for-one stock split of the company's common stock.  The number of outstanding shares of common stock will increase to approximately 37.2 million from about 18.6 million.  Joe Scarlett, Chairman of the Board and CEO, stated, "The Board's decision to approve a stock split recognizes our confidence in the ability to grow the Tractor Supply Company chain from 460 stores to approximately 700 stores over the next four years as well as the significant long-term opportunities for the business." Blockbuster seems to be in the right place at the right time.  According to the Video Software Dealers Association, DVD rentals revenue doubled in 2002, and more Americans than ever have a DVD player in their home.  In late July, the company reported second quarter net income of 34 cents per diluted share on total revenues of $1.39 billion.  That earnings result came in almost +47% ahead of the year-ago performance and beat the consensus by more than +41%, while total revenues advanced by +9.5% thanks to the net addition of 535 company-operated stores.  Furthermore, worldwide same-store revenues advanced by +1%.  The company's leading position in an industry that appears to have excellent momentum moving forward is one of the main reasons why All Stars are keeping their attention on this company.

Furthermore, Blockbuster recently won a lawsuit brought on by independent video retailers.  The suit was brought against Blockbuster and the motion picture studios, which challenged the company's revenue sharing deals with the motion picture studios.  The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit upheld a lower court's decision from June of 2002.  The Court stated that a company can set ambitious goals without slipping into illegal means.  Ambitious goals are certainly what Blockbuster has been using to improve operating margin while maximizing profitability and cash flow.  To further research Blockbuster, Inc., click  BBI .

With the economy improving and the stock market rising, consumers are feeling more confident about opening their wallets again.
This trend can be seen in monthly retail sales:
This is great news for the retail industry, but does this mean that all retail stocks are worth buying?
Not So Fast
While the industry is expected to see solid growth overall this year, there will certainly be some retailers who see tremendous growth and those who get left behind.
But how do you know which ones to buy and which ones to avoid?
One important item to look at is same-store sales. This metric compares sales across stores open at least a year. This is also known as comp sales.

This is beneficial because it allows investors and analysts to compare sales between different retailers and can alert them to shifts in consumer demand. Total sales growth, while important, will naturally be higher among retailers who are rapidly opening new stores. Same-store sales ignores this, however, and only focuses on sales at existing stores.
It's also beneficial in that it excludes the "honeymoon phase" of strong sales typically experienced shortly after stores are opened in new locations.
Early Warning Signs

It can also make it easier to spot shifts in consumer tastes or preferences. Although overall sales for a company might be up, a few consecutive months of negative comp sales can signal trouble ahead.
Compare high-end retailer Nordstrom with off-price retailer TJX Companies, which owns T.J. Maxx, Marshalls and HomeGoods stores, during the heart of the recession:
Clearly, consumer habits shifted away from luxury retailers and towards more value-oriented companies during the Great Recession.
As the economy continues to pick up, however, which companies are now seeing consistent increases in same-store sales?
Here are 4 companies seeing strong same-store sales:PriceSmart (PSMT  -  Free Report)

PriceSmart operates 28 U.S.-style membership warehouse clubs in Central America and the Caribbean. Many might question whether this business model would work in Latin America. The same-store sales numbers speak for themselves:
The company will be expanding into South America later this year with the opening of a store in Colombia. It is a Zacks #2 Rank (Buy) stock.
Limited Brands (LTD)

LTD operates well-known brands Victoria's Secret and Bath & Body Works. Same-store sales have been strong over the last several months, including a remarkable 24% increase in January (35% at Victoria's Secret):
Valuation is attractive with a PEG ratio of 0.97. It is a Zacks #3 Rank (Hold) stock.
Zumiez
Zumiez (pronounced "zoomies") is a retailer focused on action sports like skateboarding, surfing, snowboarding, motocross and BMX. Same-store sales have been surging over the last several months:
The company carries no long-term debt and is a Zacks #3 Rank (Hold) stock.
Tractor Supply Co (TSCO  -  Free Report)
This rural-focused retailer has been on a tear lately. Estimates have been surging after it recently delivered a strong fourth quarter in which EPS came in 8% above the Zacks Consensus Estimate.

Rising agricultural prices have certainly played a role in Tractor Supply's strong results. The company reports sales each quarter rather than on a monthly basis, and the results have been impressive:
Q4 Same-store sales: 13.1%
Q3 Same-store sales:  5.0%
Q2 Same-store sales:  6.1%
Tractor Supply is a Zacks #2 Rank (Buy) stock.
Conclusion

When evaluating retail stocks, it's important to look at a company's recent same-store sales trends. These 4 are seeing strong demand for their products in existing locations, which should lead to rising earnings estimates and rising stock prices.
Todd Bunton is the Growth & Income Stock Strategist for Zacks.com.

This trend continued in the fourth quarter, in which the company reported an amazing 13.1% increase in same-store sales. It is a Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stock.

On January 26, the company reported fourth quarter earnings per share of 67 cents, beating the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 62 cents. It was a 31% increase over the same quarter in 2009.
Net sales were up 19.7% driven by an incredible 13.1% same-store sales increase.

The only weak spot in the quarter was the gross margin, which fell slightly from 32.9% of sales to 32.6%. Meanwhile, operating income surged 36.0% year-over-year as the company was able to leverage its selling, general and administrative expenses.
Outlook
Estimates have been surging over the last several months as Tractor Supply continues to deliver impressive results:
It is a Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stock.

The company expects to earn between $2.54 and $2.62 per share in 2011 on same-store sales growth of 2.5% to 4.5%. The Zacks Consensus Estimate is at the upper end of guidance at $2.62, representing a 17% increase over 2010 EPS.
The 2012 consensus estimate is currently $2.98, equating to 14% growth.
Valuation
The stock has been on a tear, more than doubling in the last 12 months:

Because earnings estimates have been soaring too, valuation remains in check. Shares trade at 20.3x forward earnings, a premium to the industry average of 16.3x, but its PEG ratio is a reasonable 1.3.
Tractor Supply operates 1,001 rural-based stores in 44 states throughout the U.S. Since it was added to the Focus List on August 5, 2010, TSCO is up 52%.
Todd Bunton is the Growth & Income Stock Strategist for Zacks.com.

The market's recent positive momentum reflects the solid second-quarter earnings season and the relatively reassuring guidance from management teams about the coming quarters. There is ample evidence that the economy appears to be moving into a moderate patch of economic growth in the next few quarters, but will most likely avoid some of the more dire outcomes.

The emerging narrative of moderate but sustainable domestic economic growth, solid corporate profitability, low interest rates and a robust emerging-market growth outlook should help the equity markets drift upwards in the coming months. While I am not necessarily looking for straight upward moves in the benchmark indices going forward, I do envision the overall trend to be positive.

But risks remain to this favorable view; the biggest being reversal in the recent positive, albeit very slow, improvement in private-sector hiring, as well as fears of deflation. Moderate Economic Growth

In-line with recent soft economic reports, estimates for second-half economic growth have been steadily coming down in recent days. These lowered market expectations put third- and fourth-quarter GDP growth rates at 2.2% and 2.8%, respectively. In the first and second quarters of this year, the economy generated growth rates of 3.7% and 2.4%.

An unbiased reading of the economic reports point to a temporary growth moderation in the next couple of quarters with enough fundamental support to resume normal growth next year and beyond. The corporate sector remains in excellent financial health, with growing evidence that firms have started using their record cash hoard towards capital investments. Corporate outlays for equipment and software continue to expand  with a gain of 17% in the second quarter after a 7.8% increase in the first quarter. As such, even though manufacturing activity levels appear to have softened lately, investment spending should remain supportive to growth in the coming quarters.  Slow-Healing Labor Market

While the corporate balance sheets remain in excellent shape, the same can't be said of the household sector. It is this lack of a clear handoff of the recovery from the corporate side to the household side that has been the source of uncertainty for the economic outlook. Deleveraging households in a backdrop of long-lasting labor market weakness remains the weakest part of this economic recovery.

In the absence of a solid turnaround in the labor market, we need the trend of positive private sector job creations in the last seven months to remain in place. Gains in temporary hirings, hourly earnings and the workweek all point to a slow-healing labor market. Reversal of these trends remains a major risk factor to our market outlook.  Supportive Fed
With benchmark short-term interest rates at historically low levels, many pundits are bemoaning the lack of arrows in the Fed's quiver. But counting the Fed out may be premature.

They can engineer quantitative easing through a number of ways in response to the moderating growth outlook and continued labor market issues. The most readily available tool being a resumption of the treasury-bond purchases that they discontinued in the spring. At a minimum, the markets can remain assured that the Fed's continued usage of the extended period reference means that interest rates will remain low for quite a long period.

I was initially looking for an early-2011 timeframe for the onset of the Fed's tightening phase. But now, I don't think the Fed will start removing the monetary stimulus before late 2011. An environment of low interest rates and a supportive Fed are key positives for stocks. Solid Corporate Profitability

As referred to earlier, the turnaround in corporate profitability remains firmly in place. We had solid earnings reports in the second quarter, with year-over-year gains in excess of 40% and more than 75% of companies beating expectations. And not all of the gains have come from cost cutting alone. More than 59% of the firms have beat revenue expectations, with overall top-line gains in excess of 10%.

Not only have second-quarter earnings been solid, but management teams have been coming out with reassuring guidance for the coming quarters. Given the tendency for management teams to be inherently conservative with respect to guidance  often under-promising and over-delivering  the odds are looking good that current earnings expectations will be met, if not surpassed. Current expectations for full-year 2010 and 2011 earnings gains are approximately 34% and 19%, respectively.Portfolio Update

We made four changes to the Focus List portfolio last week; adding and deleting two each. We didn't make any changes to the Growth & Income portfolio. There were changes to the Timely Buys list as well.
A quick comment on the year-to-date performance of the Focus List and G&I portfolios is in order here. Returns on both the portfolios handily beat the S&P 500.

We added Carbo Ceramics (CRR  -  Free Report) to gain exposure to the fast-growing shale natural gas development scene. This $1.8 billion oilfield service player is a major supplier of a key chemical that is used in the development of shale natural gas fields, in addition to other services. A favorable outlook for shale natural gas development underpins the company's solid earnings prospects.

We added Tractor Supply Co. (TSCO  -  Free Report) to gain exposure to a favorable outlook for the rural economy given positive prospects for agricultural commodities. This $2.8 billion market operator of 930 retail farm and ranch stores in 44 states has a solid earnings track record, with beats in the last 9 consecutive quarters and estimates on the rise.

We dropped Cracker Barrel Old Country Store (CBRL  -  Free Report) after the stock fell to a Zacks # 4 Rank ('Sell'). While estimates have held up and the investment story remains intact, we don't see any near-term catalysts that can aid the stock price over the coming days. We had added the stock in June and took a roughly 2% loss on this one.

We exited our Parker Hannifin (PH  -  Free Report) position to get ahead of negative estimate revisions in the coming days, in our view. We had a 2.5% gain in the stock. The company reported solid results, but provided an under-whelming guidance for next year. We think that estimates would be coming down in the coming days to reflect the weak guidance.

We're going to stick with retailers a little while longer and today highlight Jo-Ann Stores, Inc. (JAS), a home decorating and crafts company that just surprised in its fiscal second quarter while boosting its full-year outlook.
Shares of this Zacks #1 Rank Top Performer are up approximately 9% Thursday. Volume is well above normal at about 715,000 shares, compared to the daily average of 187,000.

JAS is 1 of 4 companies from the retail-miscellaneous/diversified industry on today's Zacks #1 Rank List, which includes 229 stocks in total. The other 3 companies are Dick's Sporting Goods, Inc. (DKS  -  Free Report), Dover Saddlery, Inc. (DOVR) and Tractor Supply Company (TSCO  -  Free Report).Fiscal Second Quarter Results

Yesterday, JAS announced a loss per share of 13 cents in its fiscal second quarter. This loss was narrower than both the year-ago loss of 47 cents, and the Zacks Consensus Estimate for a loss of 39 cents.

Meanwhile, net sales advanced 4.1% to $419.4 million from $403 million, which sets JAS apart from many retailers who are beating quarterly profit expectations but still suffering through steep year-over-year declines in revenue.
Same-store sales were up 1.8%.
The company gave credit for its quarterly performance to continued sales growth, margin expansion and expense leverage.

"We continue to plan cautiously for the remainder of fiscal 2010, but our progress in the first half leaves us confident that sales and earnings will exceed our original expectation for the full year," said Chairman/President/CEO Darrell Webb. Fiscal 2010 Outlook

JAS is so confident in its full year performance that it raised its EPS guidance to between $1.35 and $1.50, compared to its previous outlook of 70 cents to 85 cents. The company also expects same-store sales to be flat to up 1%. Earnings Estimates
The Zacks Consensus Estimate for the fiscal year ending January 2010 is currently at $1.08 per share, which is up 9% over the past month.

For next fiscal year, the Zacks Consensus Estimate has advanced to $1.37 from $1.29 - an improvement of 6.2% in the past 30 days. The result also suggests year-over-year profit growth of as much as 27%.
Tractor Supply Company (TSCO  -  Free Report) just jumped beyond a key level of resistance at $45 after reporting strong second-quarter results in late July.
Company Description
Tractor Supply Company operates retail farm and ranch stores in the United States. The company was founded in 1938 and has a market cap of $1.69 billion.

Shares of TSCO have been on a nice rally for the last month as optimism has swung back into the market. The company helped its cause on July 22 when it reported solid second-quarter results that were ahead of expectations.
Second-Quarter Results
Revenue was up 5% from last year to $946.5 million. Earnings came in at $1.50, one penny better than the Zacks Consensus Estimate.
Tractor Supply has beat the consensus in each of the last 4 quarters by an average of 4 cents, or 34%.
Margin Expansion
The company's results were helped by a dramatic improvement in its gross margin, which jumped 10.5% to 31.9% of sales.
Estimates Jump

After word of the good quarter hit the street, analysts were quick to boost their earnings targets. The current year added 23 cents, climbing to $2.87 per share. The next-year estimate is projecting 9% earnings growth.
Valuation
Not only does Tractor Supply have nice sales and earnings growth, it is also reasonably priced, trading with a P/E multiple of 16X, a slight discount to the overall market.
The Chart
Shares of TSCO have been rallying since bottoming out with the overall market in early March. More recently, this stock jumped past a key level of resistance at the $45 mark. Take a look below.
Earnings season will hit full stride with reports from nearly 500 companies. Approximately 1 out of every 4 earnings release will be from a firm in the financial sector.

Large-cap stocks will once again dominate the headlines, as 139 S&P 500 members are on the docket. Included are Dow components 3M (MMM  -  Free Report), American Express (AXP), AT&T (T  -  Free Report), Boeing (BA  -  Free Report), Caterpillar (CAT  -  Free Report), Coca-Cola (KO  -  Free Report), E.I. Du Pont (DD), Merck (MRK  -  Free Report), Microsoft (MSFT  -  Free Report) and Pfizer (PFE  -  Free Report).

The highlight of the economic calendar will be Ben Bernanke's semi-annual report on monetary policy (aka Humphrey-Hawkins). The Fed Chairman will appear before a House committee on Tuesday and a Senate committee on Wednesday.
Otherwise, there will not be much news on the economic front.
Monday: June Leading Indicators
Wednesday: weekly crude inventories
Thursday: weekly initial jobless claims
Friday: Revised July University of Michigan consumer sentiment
Atlanta Fed President Dennis Lockhart will discuss his economic outlook with the Rotary Club of Nashville on Monday. No other Fed officials are scheduled to speak.

The market really has not reacted much to better-than-expected earnings. Though a big rally did occur last Wednesday, volume outside the semiconductor group was generally light. And yesterday's afternoon rally was in reaction to comments made by Nouriel Roubini that were taken out of context.

This raises the possibility that we could see more of the same for the coming week. If traders are not expressing joy over blowout earnings from Goldman Sachs (GS  -  Free Report), then it seems unlikely that Jefferies Group (JEF) could say anything that would move the markets.

If there is going to be a move to the upside, tech will have to be the catalyst. And we do have a handful of large-cap tech companies reporting (e.g. MSFT, Texas Instruments (TXN  -  Free Report), etc.), so there is the possibility of some good daily moves.
But, investors should continue to eye volume, which continues to signal a willingness among many to simply sit on the sidelines.

Companies That Could Issue Positive Earnings SurprisesIntersil (ISIL) raised its second-quarter revenue guidance late last month. The majority of the covering analysts responded by hiking their quarterly profit projections. These revisions led to a 5-cent increase in the consensus earnings estimate, to 9 cents per share. The semiconductor company has topped expectations during 5 out of the last 6 quarters. Intersil is scheduled to report on Wednesday, Jul 22, after the close of trading.

Qualcomm (QCOM  -  Free Report) is a riskier pick, given that it has disappointed investors for 2 consecutive quarters. But, the company did raise its fiscal third-quarter guidance last month, citing strong demand for wireless broadband. Furthermore, one analyst upped his quarterly forecast this week. The consensus estimate now calls for profits of 45 cents per share (up 2 cents from a month ago). The most accurate estimate is more bullish at 46 cents per share. Qualcomm is scheduled to report on Wed, Jul 22, after the close of trading.

Last month, Texas Instruments (TXN  -  Free Report) updated its second-quarter forecast. This resulted in a sharp increase in the consensus estimate to 19 cents per share, the midpoint of TXN's suggested range. Could this forecast still be too conservative? Judging by the fact that 2 brokerage analysts just raised their second-quarter forecasts and the bullish results from other chip makers, the answer could well be yes. TXN has topped expectations for 2 consecutive quarters. Texas Instruments is scheduled to report on Monday, Jul 20, after the close of trading.

Tractor Supply (TSCO  -  Free Report) anticipates reporting second-quarter earnings of $1.48 to $1.50 per share. The recent guidance was far above the consensus estimate and caused all of the covering analysts to revise their projections. Though the consensus estimate now calls for profits of $1.49 per share, there is still room for further upside given TSCO's streak of 4 consecutive positive earnings surprises. Tractor Supply is scheduled to report on Wednesday, Jul 22, after the close of trading.

Companies That Could Issue Negative Earnings SurprisesCaterpillar (CAT  -  Free Report) has disappointed investors during 2 out of the last 3 quarters. Though the slowing pace of economic contraction should be a positive for CAT, 5 analysts have cut their second-quarter profit forecasts within the past 30 days. The revisions have caused the consensus earnings estimate to fall by 3 cents to 21 cents per share. The most accurate estimate is more bearish at 14 cents per share. Caterpillar is scheduled to report on Tuesday, Jul 21, before the start of trading.
Charles Rotblut, CFA is the senior market analyst for Zacks.com.Earnings Calendar
